text: At some point during Star Wars, Luke Skywalker's story evolves from his individual quest and struggle to being part of the Revolution as he dons a pilot's uniform and joins a squadron of star fighters battling The Empire.  It works.In Mocking Jay, Katniss Everdeen battles not in an Arena for her individual life, but joins the Rebel Army in District 13, first as a rally-symbol (the Mockingjay) and later as infantry when the rebels make their final assault on the Capital of Panem.  It doesn't work as well.The author was better at portraying the individual combat in the Arenas in the first two books than she was at fitting Katniss into a larger enterprise.  I thought the battle scenes were not as clear in my mind in this book as the very engrossing pictures she painted of the individual contest zones in Books 1 and 2.  The Rebel headquarters seemed awfully small, as did the population, for it to be successful in battling President Snow's army and rallying the other districts to an uprising.  It just didn't work as well for me.Not that this book isn't interesting and worth the time.  If you enjoyed Books 1 and 2, this is fairly enjoyable and carries forward the themes of what freedom means as well as the relationship between the individual and the state.  The love triangle is also brought to a conclusion and loose ends are tied up and resolved.  Readers are introduced to a heretofore unknown District 13 population that has checkmated the Capital since the revolt seventy years before.  Hidden from the rest of the country, Katniss' rebelliousness and connection with the oppressed citizens of Panem as a result of her success in the Hunger Games sparks an uprising that allows the District 13 forces to literally come out of their holes and fan the flames of a budding uprising.Katniss is largely a spectator to that process in the first part of the book.  Anointed the Mockingjay, she is used as a propaganda symbol to rally rebels to the cause.  She continues to struggle with Gale and Peeta and what each means to her as well as her place in her new world for most of this book.While the book is entertaining in parts, there is much less action (save for the final chapters) and more pondering than in the first two parts of the series.  Still, the author does successfully broaden the themes that span her first two efforts and conclude the story with surprises and plot turns that do make it overall a satisfying experience.

This is my first Nicholas Sparks book, though I have seen a few of the movies made from his work.Overall, I liked the book.  I thought he did a fine job of capturing the reactions of two kids to the breakup of their family, as well as the daughter's coming of age occurrences over the course of a summer.  Being a Dad, I also liked the way he portrayed Steve, the Dad, who is struggling to remake himself as well as deal with his grave illness.Ronnie, the seventeen year old daughter who is at the center of the story, arrives at her father's beachfront home under protest.  She's almost eighteen, just a few months away from not having to be ordered to spend time with a parent she feels abandoned by and is angry at.  This book is the story of Ronnie discovering Ronnie and confronting her reality.  She is aided in this process of realization as she interacts with the youth in her Dad's town, confronts her abandoned gift of music she shares with her Dad, and grows to appreciate her Dad and the finality that his grave illness confronts her with.Other characters such as the outcast local girl Blaze, her ne'er-do-well boyfriend Marcus, the town's chief hoodlum, and new boyfriend Will provide the personalities and situations that enable Ronnie to move beyond attitude and embrace her future as well as her past.  The Marcus/Blaze/Will line was well-done and I thought (from the distant perch of a parent's perspective), portrayed some of the challenges faced by youth in sorting out love, peer pressure, fitting-in and rebelliousness in an interesting and believable manner.This book was a quick read, with good characters, believable situations and as Nicholas Sparks apparently does well, heart-wrenching situations and occurrences that must be faced by the main characters as the story heads towards its bitter-sweet end.

One hopes that "Escape from Camp 14" acts like a clarion call in the night and motivates the world to address the sustained evil that is the Kim Family's North Korea.While Hitler's Concentration Camps lasted no longer than the twelve years of his "Thousand Year Reich," North Korean concentration camps are reaching their sixty year mark.  That time, along with the original Kim's dictum that enemies of the state should have "three generations of their seed removed" from his fiefdom means that there are thousands of Koreans who have been born - indeed bred - in concentration camps and know nothing of life outside the wire.So it was with Shin Dong-hyuk, the product of a father who was awarded a wife and allowed (as all prisoners so rewarded are allowed) to spend five nights a year with his bride.  Shin was the offspring of that arranged pairing and literally never new anything except guards, beating, privation and work from his earliest years.  Enrolled in "school" until his mid-teens, Shin's schooling consisted for the majority of the time of work in the camp at various chores.  Rudimentary Korean letters and math were provided, but he grew to maturity literally not knowing anything about the outside world.  He never heard of China, the United States, South Korea or had any context at all in which to compare his bleak world.  He knew only guards who were in total charge of his life and his class of prisoners who were his competitors for food and the other necessities of survival.So thoroughly controlled by the camp system, Shin witnessed the killing of a six year old classmate over five kernels of corn, turned in his fellow students for infractions, participated in beatings of his classmates as he was beaten - and knew no remorse, guilt or feelings.  Kim even turned his mother and older brother into the guards when they talked of escape, furious that their efforts would lead to his execution under the assumption that he would have known of their plans (he was arrested and tortured anyway, as the guard he tattled to failed to inform his superiors that Shin was the one who exposed the escape attempt).  Kept in a perpetual state of exhaustion and starvation, clad in rags and subject to the beatings and humiliations of the lowliest guard at anytime for any reason, Shin was an animal reduced to thinking constantly of survival.By luck he met a political prisoner who had served North Korea abroad before running afoul of the regime and who was able to paint a world outside the wire for Shin.  Even luckier, Shin and his friend concocted an absurd escape plan that gained for Shin his freedom when his friend's body hung on the electric wire of their camp fence and Shin was able to climb over it to the world outside.Blaine Hardin has written a thin, but powerful and necessary book chronicling Shin's experience and escape to and adjustment in the West.  He intersperses Shin's story with facts and descriptions of life in North Korea and the camp system that keeps hundreds of thousands of North Korean's behind wire and struggling daily to avoid death from starvation, execution, beating, overwork, the amusement of jailers and/or neglect.  It is truly a fascinating glimpse into a world rarely seen by the outside and about which few specifics are known.North Korea is truly a bizarre place that has seen organized evil practiced on its citizens by a small, ruling clique.  The government deserves to be overthrown by whatever means that could be accomplished and these North Koreans deserve the world's sympathy and attention.  Blaine Hardin by this book and the gripping story of Shin Dong-hyuk has hopefully made that needed attention more likely.

A very fine history that fills in the life story of a famous American event that is known to many but not known in detail.The debate over John Brown - Freedom Fighter or terrorist or both? - will remain one of the touchstones of discourse regarding his time.  This fine book by Tony Horwitz does not seek to answer the question.  What it does is provide a well written history of the man, his Kansas activities and the Harper's Ferry raid that bears his name.Fans of Tony Horwitz may be surprised that this book carries none of the witty asides found in his "Confederates in the Attic", "Blue Latitudes," "Baghdad Without a Map," or any of his other works (at least those known to me).  In those books, Horwitz has a bit of Bryson in him, mixing travel, history, tidbits and witticisms.  This book is a straight history, and well done.Brown is a fascinating figure.  Wedded entirely to abolitionism and one of the few willing to advance the cause with action as well as thought, Brown's single minded focus consumed his life and that of his family.  He was an early immigrant to Kansas, to counter the Border Ruffian immigrants seeking to turn the territory into a Slave state.  Brown had his first taste of blood there in reprisal for pro-slavery raids on free-staters.  His actions spawned a national recognition earning for him the nickname Osawatomie Brown (for the battle there as well as using the area as a base for his raids).His life work culminated as a planned thrust into "Africa" as he termed the slave holding South.  Brown recruited men, materials and money and formed his raiding party, only thirty some strong, intent on seizing the federal armory at Harper's Ferry, Virginia.  He sought to provoke a slave uprising, and - as he stated to his followers - create a great guerrilla army that would operate in the mountainous regions around the Shenandoah, spreading south and eventually rooting slavery from its base.His plan was that of a starry-eyed zealot, his tactics and execution lacking of military thought or continued action once implemented.  Personally fearless and unflappable, and with a commanding presence, he was unable to translate those qualities into effective action.  Sitting in the Harper's Ferry armory after successfully taking it, Brown dawdled, faced a growing militia from the town and outlying areas and was quickly overrun by US Marines led by Robert E. Lee (then Col.) and J.E.B. Stuart (then Lt.)Brown's trial was swift and his execution soon followed.  He did have enough time, as well as a rapt audience eager to hear from this man, to explain and write with great moral clarity about his cause and his motivations for action. He succeeded in galvanizing focus on slavery and its evils as well as the willingness of a righteous man to take action against what abolitionists (and even others uncomfortable with the institution) saw as a great cancer on our democracy.Horowitz addresses the tantalizing question of whether or not Brown in his own mind wanted to succeed with his stated military plan.  Or, the author contemplates, did he see his raid as a useful focal point; destined to succeed in bringing on the great question of slavery in our country and its path to extinction by failing and forcing the South to defend with arms and the legal system America's 'peculiar institution.' We cannot know for sure, but Horowitz does a fine job framing the question in this very good history.

Besides being an interesting and mysterious serial killer story, "The Monster of Florence" impressed me most with an understanding of the protections those accused of crimes in the United States take for granted. Certainly the Italian system where prosecutors have much more power to hold suspects and power over the appeals process leaves a lot to be desired in terms of civil liberties.Over a twenty year period ending in the mid-1980's parking and necking - the common culmination of early dates - had been a deadly amorous activity in the countryside outside of Florence, Italy. A killer or killers had murdered a number of couples out at night on lonely lanes. The police could not crack the case, though numerous suspects came and went over a period of years.An American author met Italian journalist Mario Spezi (who had been doggedly tracking the case) and became captured by the mystery. The two set out to investigate and themselves came under suspicion by Italian authorities who by all accounts were deeply embarrassed by their failure to solve the crime or even come up with a good theory of who was committing these crimes against passion. With Spezi jailed, the focus of the book becomes the Italian justice system, where rights are enjoyed not as enshrined in our Constitution but by the sufferance of the state.This is two tales in one; the murder story and the investigation of the same; and, the byzantine travel through the Italian justice system as a suspect.I thought the book was enjoyable and informative, though uneven in parts. All in all, an ok read.

I am not usually a literature guy (preferring non-fiction and popular novels), but I read this because it is a classic and I wanted to experience Hemingway beyond my high school reading of "The Old Man and the Sea." (and honestly, because while dating my wife she revealed this as one of her favorite books and that aroused my curiosity.)This is a story that deals with the larger questions of life (and essential truths) and man's place in the world or at least in a challenging situation.  So that qualifies as literature according to my wife's definition when I asked her what made literature "literature" a while ago.Protagonist Robert Jordan is an American volunteering with the Republicans fighting Franco's Fascists in the Spanish Civil War.  A demolitions expert, Jordan's task is to blow a key bridge as part of a larger Republican attack.  While waiting with a small band of guerilla's he meets and falls in love with Maria, a victim of the war and symbol for all innocents caught in aggression's path.Thus we have a literary work that addresses commitment to cause, love, and the battle between individual wants and the needs of and obligations to a larger cause.Hemmingway has a way with description and his prose is very well done and evocative - particularly one passage I liked when he described holding Maria's hand with ripening grain in an untrammeled field.  His story is slow, however, for my tastes and the descriptions and inner conversations of Jordan are much more prevalent than scenes where anything called action could be said to be occurring (though the action scenes are pretty good when they do occur).  I imagine the ending will be unsatisfying to some, but for literary minded folks be the source of discussion as to how the final scene may have played out and what it meant in terms of tying the story's themes together.

Genghis Khan is one of those figures from the past who is widely known but most don't know much more about him than his name and reputation as one of the great ravagers of history.Jack Weatherford has described the world and empire of Genghis Khan in this wonderful book that I found enjoyable and very well written.  The story of "The Great Khan" is remarkable.  He rose and lifted a people who were backward, remote and possessing few resources to a dominant position in  Asia and astride the great trade routes of the late twelfth and early thirteenth centuries.  Weatherford demonstrates how the hardened Mongols (who eked out a living in very demanding environment) possessing fierceness, horse skills and ability to live off the land and operate fluidly and with mobility, became master empire builders when wedded to one of history's gifted leaders.Weatherford describes Genghis Khan's life and generalship of the empire but also the methods and management of that empire during its rise and rule.  It is a fascinating story that leaves the reader with a very full picture of the Mongol nation and Genghis' leadership.  Let's face it, if Genghis Khan is known at all it is as a brute who led a brutal nation from his saddle.  While this is true and Genghis led one of history's bloodiest armies ever let loose to conquer, the author fleshes out that picture and both Genghis and his empire's story are told in fullness.This is a very well written and interesting history that filled in a gap in my knowledge.

Fans of "Band of Brothers" should enjoy this book focusing on one of the commanders of Easy Company and bringing the whole Dick Winters story to light.Winters embodied the iconic everyman hero of World War II - a young man called to do a job who performed it excellently, selflessly, without braggadocio.  This Winters dominated the original book, but in "Biggest Brother," the author gives Winter's life story.Obviously a lot of the story turns on Winter's service in the European Theater of Operations, but this also delves into his upbringing and his experience after the war and ultimately as a hero thrust into the role by Stephen Ambrose's' wonderful book and the exciting mini-series upon which it was based.Winters was no Sgt. York or George Patton, but the ability for many readers to see themselves (at least themselves on a good day) in Dick Winters as he performs excellent service in the deadly pursuit of war proved to be uplifting and helped underscore the story of our citizen army called to do a very tough job in World War II.  I am glad this book was written so that Winters could get his due in a full biography.

This is one of those quirky little works that is fascinating and you learn lots of interesting tidbits about a subject you never would have thought would have made a book.Mary Roach has written all about dead bodies throughout history and how they are used, misused and brought to their state of room temperature.  It turns out that bodies have been and always will be used to demonstrate "stuff."  They have tested methods of execution, taught doctors (the section on plastic surgeons practicing on bodiless heads is creepy but fascinating), been used as crash test dummies and provided the raw research on alternate methods of disposal such as composting (you can, in a sense, reemerge as a flower every year if your composted body fertilizes the garden).  The famous "Bone Yard" in Tennessee where bodies are left to decay to aid forensic science is explored as well as the employees who have jobs there (and undoubtedly never lack for bar talk when asked "so, what do you do?").This is so different and quirky that it fascinated and I had a tough time putting it down.  An enjoyable read that will undoubtedly be a departure from your usual repertoire.

This book is informative and accessible.  For the non-clinician, it gives a very good history of the development of the field of medicine, broadly construed.I've always kept in mind that physicians killed George Washington by bleeding him, the established practice of the day to rid the body of the "bad humors" that were thought to cause illness.  Much of the history of the development of medicine focuses on many wrong ideas and false starts with the occasional beneficial treatment or practice stumbled upon and largely misunderstood.  For much of history, healing was a matter of luck that was enhanced for those who avoided physicians or hospitals.This little gem of a book traces the development of surgery, hospitals, pharmaceuticals, and the like over the last couple of thousand years to the present.  It also discusses modern practices and the reader will certainly come away thankful that they live in an age where some of the body's functions and chemistry are understood enough to make a trip to the hospital on the whole a good risk, rather than the life threatening experience it was up until the modern era.

As other reviewers have noted, this is a different kind of history that is interesting in part but disappoints.While purporting to be about "The Dinner" that saved America, it is mostly about the events leading up to the dinner and the issues and personalities involved in striking a deal that legitimized the American experiment in 1790.American finance and stability had to be created in order for the new government to gain a footing soon after Washington's inauguration.  The need for credit worthy public debt and the problem of state debt incurred as a result of The Revolution vexed the Federalist leader Alexander Hamilton and the anti-Federalist leaders James Madison and Thomas Jefferson (this even though Hamilton and Jefferson both sat in Washington's Cabinet during this episode).Jefferson invited the other two to his famous dinner where a deal was hatched that Congress ended up embracing - assumption of state war debt by the Federal Government (which Hamilton wanted) in return for the eventual placement of the permanent Capital of the Government on the Banks of the Potomac River on land ceded by Virginia and Maryland (which Jefferson and Madison wanted).  The essence of political compromise and on an issue that really was crucial to the viability of the Republic.This book doesn't offer any new insights or ground as many reviewers have noted.  It tilts heavily toward Jefferson in the never ending debate of who was the statesman and who was the opportunist between Hamilton and Jefferson (I think the book is unfair to Hamilton).  And, the author has included recipes of food found at Jefferson's table that is out of place in a book like this, but does have the virtue of adding something different to the tome.All in all, an ok summary of the assumption and public debt issue and the story of a great compromise forged at Thomas Jefferson's table.  But ,  I did find the book disappointing and the writing less than engaging in my opinion.

This modest book is not a biography of Churchill per se, but a description of what made Churchill tick by examining momentous experiences in this most momentous of lives to get at the essence of the man.Johnson, who knew Churchill and had the opportunity to observe him closely during the great statesman's career, shows how Churchill's tenacity, drive, energy, great ability to communicate and incredible self confidence kept his position significant in or near government for most of the period form World War I through the mid-1950s.  There are conclusions drawn from Churchill's many successes as well as his failures - the Wilderness years in the 1930's and the disastrous Gallipoli campaign he championed in the First World War - that show how the mettle of the man was forged.As Johnson admits, this is not meant to be an exhaustive biography, and in less than 200 pages, there are many parts of the Churchill story that do not get mentioned or are mentioned only briefly.  What Johnson does, and does extremely well, is create a vivid impression of the man himself and illustrate what it was that made Churchill the towering figure he became.

As other reviewers have noted, this easy to read book is more about Sherman's March to the Sea than the occupation of Savannah.Sherman was an innovator.  Having learned from Grant's campaign to the back door of Vicksburg by way of Jackson, Mississippi, Sherman proposed to cut the eastern Confederacy in two after his 1864 captue of Atlanta by cutting his supply lines and communications and living off the land to move his army of 100,000 across a broad swath of Georgia to the coast at Savannah.  It was audacious, but Grant and Lincoln agreed and General Sherman undertook his famous march that "made Georgia howl."The March was imposing, with only scattered troops opposing him. His deft movements and broad front convinced the Confederate commander to slip away from Savannah as Sherman approached and the northern army was able to occupy this vital port easily.  Sherman's announcement to Lincoln begging to present as a Christmas present the City of Savannah buoyed the North and the President.This is a good overview, not as thorough as some treatments of the March but easily accessible and written in an engaging manner.

This excellent little book is a "how to" for getting elected to local office.  Yes, it was written 2,000 years ago and the office was Counsul of Rome in 64 BC, but the lessons are the same as one would use to describe successful campaigning today. (I say local, because travel time and distance meant that only citizens of the City of Rome voted and of course females, slaves and others classes were excluded.  It really was a "press-the-flesh" campaign that needed to reach a manageable number of people for success).The lessons are the same then and now because the subject is "how to get humans to vote for you", which translates into "how to work with human nature"  This book is about how to make a connection, curry favor, get others to help you and how to avoid making people not want to support you.Written by one brother to another who is questing election to Rome's highest office in the Republic period, the slim guide lays out its advice in a series of fifty or so numbered maxims.  These are short paragraphs that speak to things to do and things not to do if you want to be a successful candidate.  Each maxim contains a couple of sentences of explanation/rationale which makes this a superb guide because it not only advises, but convinces the reader of the credibility of the advice.  Thus, we get instructions about making friends; about soliciting the opinions of those whose support you covet; about learning about your opponent's weaknesses and past and using that information to knock the opponent before undecided voters; that it is better to make promises and leave voters with hope and later disappoint them than to tell them "no" and disappoint them prior to an election; that being hopeful and building the hopes of voters is a winning strategy.  These truisms are very cynical, but the reader needs to keep in mind the sole objective of the book is to instruct on the waging of successful political campaigns and not on statesmanship.This is a quick read (an hour, hour-and-a-half or so) with the original Latin on one page and the translation on the facing page. The translator also provides a glossary and brief historical context that bridges the specifics of Rome 20 centuries ago for the modern reader.  Any contemporary observer of politics will recognize the lessons and "how to's" contained in this ancient tract and how true they are for the most part in contemporary politics.

This superb biography by the Heidlers is informative, detailed and provides not only a full examination of the life of one of America's great legislators but also a summary of the great events facing the United States between the War of 1812 and the Compromise of 1850.Henry Clay's career is almost Zelig-like in his involvement in or close observation of every major event occurring in American government over almost fifty years of public service (most, but not all in elective office).  Clay has the distinction of both being the only person elected to the Speakership of the US House on his first day in office as a freshman representative, but also for consolidating power in that office and making it an effective legislative lever for the first time. So dominant was Clay, that he arguably was the person who cast the lot of the United States for war against the British in 1812.  Known as the Great Compromiser, Clay fashioned the Missouri Compromise as well has had a significant hand in the Compromise of 1850.The book is well written, thoroughly documented and tells the fascinating story of this man's life in a highly enjoyable manner. There are many lessons to learn from Clay's life.  Great evidence is given to show Clay as the master of personal politics.  He was genuinely a "happy warrior" who left sharp words on the floor of the Senate and had no trouble sharing a drink with fierce legislative opponents (this is a general statement - there were exceptions; occasionally Clay could be sharp and nasty during debates and had a few long running feuds with individuals that he carried into the social sphere of life - notably John C. Calhoun).  Witty, personable, able to carry conversation late into the evening and flatter without seeming insincere, much of Clay's power derived from his ability to cultivate friends and relationships.But as good a personal politician Clay was, he reveals himself a poor organizational politician.  In his quests for the Presidency and as leader of the Whigs, Clay was slow to adopt new styles of campaigning introduced by Jacksonians.  He took years to get off the front porch and out into the hustings to personally campaign for national office - a practice revealed as successful and expected after Jackson revealed its effectiveness.  He also is revealed as weak in terms of building organizations, seeming to leave organizational politics to the whims of trusted acquaintances and allies around the country long after his Democrat opponents had revealed the efficacy of strong campaign managers and tight organizations extending to the county level.Impressively, Clay is revealed as a man of principle and never waivered on his core beliefs in the American System (infrastructure and tariffs), the balance on slavery (personally seen as wrong, but Constitutional - the same as Lincoln's stance pre-1863), need for a national bank and a president consigned to carry out the will of Congress rather than dictate to it (However, knowing Clay through this book, one can well imagine him as a very involved and active President had he been successful in any of his five quests for the office).  His highest priority, always, was preserving the Union.  Clay could see the sectional pull and the threat it posed to national unity early and always worked to keep sectional interests from tearing the country apart.  He supposedly said on one occasion that he would "rather be right than president" (leading many wags to say he would get his wish), and his effort to stick to core principles while pursuing the presidency gives some support to that mind set.  The book does show how an artful politician tries to emphasize and smooth positions around the edges as this border state man attempted the difficult task of keeping northern anti-slavery, pro-tariff voters and southern pro-slavery, anti-tariff voters with him during national campaigns.A very well written, detailed biography not just of a significant man but also a significant time with many lessons regarding the art of politics.

"Better" continues the story and meditations that Gawande started in his first book "Complications" regarding surgery and healthcare from the perspective of a doctor.  Written in the same engaging easy-to-understand manner as his first book, "Better" is similarly interesting and timely given the focus on healthcare as an issue in our polity.This book examines some of the issues that perplex and dominate aspects of healthcare delivery.  Gawande speaks of simple things that the healthcare system could do better - such as ensuring hand washing by personnel as decreed by every hospital and provider facility.  He also addresses issues such as physician compensation (noting surgeons are pieceworkers) and the weight of malpractice litigation and insurance costs on the healthcare system.  A missed tumor on the x-ray of a son of a doctor provides a specific counterpoint to the general argument about malpractice tha serves to bookend the topic well.His topics are varied; differences in cure rates at different clinics; public health and the campaign to eradicate polio; and, a very interesting chapter on doctors who serve as physicians attendant to death penalty executions and the intersection of their training and the necessities of performing this job that seems to contradict the Hippocratic oath.Overall, his book serves to illustrate an often miraculous and wondrous system that serves many with lifesaving interventions but that also could do better in many ways and still has issues to resolve.

Atul Gawande is a very engaging writer with a fascinating subject - which produces a very informative and interesting book.Gawande writes from a surgical resident's perspective on his training and the practice of his craft.  His book does an excellent job of humanizing a profession that seems distant and elevated to many who consume surgical services.  With case studies as well as meditations on some of the ethical and larger questions related to interventional medicine, Gawande draws a fascinating portrait of what it means to be a surgeon - at least from his perspective.This is a warts and all book.  The miracles are here, but so are the "bad outcomes." The reader will be amazed at what medical science can accomplish in terms of fixing and healing; and also frustrated - as is the author - with the current limits of understanding that render some cases, behaviors and situations perplexing.Obviously a very smart man, Gawande has also a very talented pen that renders "Complications" an important and enjoyable work

This is my first Lonely Planet guide and I'm very impressed.If you are planning a visit to the Grand Canyon that is more than just a one or two day drive by, I would say this book is a must.  Nicely sized with good photos and lots of maps, it is meant to travel along with you instead of just sit on your desk during the trip planning stages.The book is well organized.  There are helpful sections on traveling with children, regional activities and suggestions, and tours within the park (both north and south sides).  The hikes are a central part of this book and are well described with usual information: maps, elevation changes, degree of difficulty, etc., etc.  There are all manner of hiking options described, so anyone who wants to explore the Grand Canyon of foot will benefit from this book.  I liked the layout; the book is very visual and easy to access.  All in all, a very good guide.

I bought this atlas as an in-car guide for the various around-the-country trips taken with family over the last ten or so years.  It is an excellent atlas that adds locations of parks, sites, and attractions greatly aiding those who wander the roads and are willing to wander off to stop and visit something that catches your eye.For example, when driving US 85, a long, straight road uniting western North and South Dakota, the map showed the "Geographic Center of the US" close to my route.  This diversion provided a memorable stop and pictures with my four young kids.  These types of locations are not shown on other atlases I'm aware of, making the National Geographic Adventure Edition perfect for those with the time and inclination to see some of the country while traveling.For a car atlas, it is durable and the pages turn easily on the spiral binder.  Readability is good, though large states of course don't get quite the detail possible on maps for Delaware, Vermont, Rhode Island and other small states, but I didn't find this to be a problem in terms of guidance or options for attractions and sites.Four stars because it hasn't been updated since 2004 and needs to be.

In the words of my almost fourteen year old, "very cool pics."  National Geographic has produced another book that sucks the reader in with incredible photographs and a good adventure story.Ed Viesturs is a rock star among mountain climbers - at least to those of us who know the activity through the printed page and film.  His quest to summit all fourteen of the world's giant mountains (above 8,000 meters) without supplemental oxygen is chronicled in his own words (this book covers the first twelve of those mountains; the latter two he bagged subsequent to this volume).  While the story is enticing and well written, the pictures are simply stunning.  I've read quite a few books about adventures in mountaineering (although my experience is entirely through the printed page), and I've not seen a better and more inspiring collection of top-of-the-world photography.  Viesturs is also a solid descriptive writer who offers a good journey in his own words.While good writing can convey adventure and a sense of place, nothing beats photos like these for showing how stark, lonely and dangerous it is atop the world's highest peaks.

It worked fine for the first few days on my iPad 3, but then I started getting messages like "this device may not be supported."Now, while using my iPad, I notice that my device is not charging. When I replug the cable in for a tighter fit, it clicks as though it is in place. Yet, a couple of seconds later, I see that my device is not charging.The cable feels tight in the connection, but something is wrong. I cannot get the cable to maintain a connection with the iPad.I was very hopeful about this cable, because it has a strong reinforcing plastic next to the plug, which is where my Apple cable got worn. I also like the price.However, after my experience, I would caution potential buyers to look elsewhere. I have had good luck with Amazon Basics cables for the most part, but not with this one.

I had high hopes for this feeder. I hung it outside two weeks ago. Initially it appeared to be doing a good job, as the squirrels would climb onto it and the squirrel's weight would cause the feeder to close.Within days, the squirrels had figured out that if they stood on the base, they could eat freely to their heart's content.The leaves on the feeder are already starting to rust from squirrels chewing on them.A spring came loose from squirrel mischief. I reattached it several times but it continues to be dislodged by squirrels.The springs are no longer as bouncy as they were, with the result that the feeder ports are only partially open, not enough for birds to access.  I called and spoke with Perky Pet's friendly and helpful tech support: they suggested numerous "fixes" which didn't work.This feeder is not well-built and is not squirrel proof. Save your money and get something else.

This is a beautiful set of cards and accompanying book.THE PACKAGING AND UNWRAPPING:The box is a two-piece box with a lift-off lid. Box dimensions are 2 inches deep x  8 1/2 inches x 6 inches. The book measures 5 1/2" x 8". The cards are arranged in two packs in two indented wells in the box.THE CARDS:The images are beautiful and surreal. The four suits are Airships (Swords), Engines (Wands), Submersibles (Cups), and Leviathans (Pentacles). The cards measure 4 3/4" high x slightly wider than 2 3/4" wide. The image on each card measures 4 1/8" high x 2 5/8" wide. There is a white border with a title at the bottom.The Court cards are: Messengers = Page, Navigator = Knight, Lady = Queen, Captain = King. The Major Arcana, or the "Gods of the Machine," have been renamed, except for the Empress and Emperor (the Tower is the "Stricken Tower" and the Moon is "Moon Voyage"). Strength is VIII "The Engineer" who "calmly tends a mighty robot," and Justice is XI "Brazen Head," which was "made to judge and discern everything within its intelligent workings."Some of my favorite cards: Ace of Airships, being piloted through the sky: the massive ship looks as if it is passing directly overhead and has caught us in its wake. The Five of Airships depicts a mighty battle in space between warring ships: is the fate of our world affected below? The Eight of Airships shows a lookout piloting an Airship, fogbound, while threat of attack looms, with a beautiful skyline as a backdrop. The Seven of Engines illustrates a majestic machine which looks like a goddess: the card meaning reads, "an operator looks to keep the engine alive as the workers strike." The Ten of Leviathans shows two machines: "an older crew and her captain encounter the power of a newer vehicle." The Two of Submersibles portrays two divers entwined. The Seven of Submersibles depicts a lost underwater city.Of the Major Arcana, I like XIII the Spring-Heeled Jack (Death), who graces the cover of the book. Upon reading about him in the book, I learned he is "the scavenger that sees off things that have run their time. No one knows whose roof he will land on." One cannot bargain with this fellow, apparently! Other standouts are Solarium (The Sun), Regeneration Machine (Judgment), and the Aviatrix (High Priestess). My favorite is Moon Voyage, a travelling machine pointed at the moon.THE CARDSTOCK:The cardstock is matte, with a slightly glossy protective finish applied. They feel smooth to the touch. It has a nice thickness to it; not too thick and not too thin. It looks durable and has an attractive finish. They feel good in the hand when shuffling.CARD BACKS:Card backs are a reversible pattern of silvery white winged cogs and gears and a planet design on a deep blue-green, almost teal, background with a thin gold border. There is a tiny copyright on either side. On the main gear it reads, "Dei ex Machina." This symbol is also on the back of the book.READING THE CARDS:One can read them using the authors' system, which is described in the book. One can also read this deck using the RWS system, after a little time spent with the book. For example, the Three of Airships (Swords): "A crew member falls from an airship and is thrown a lifeline. ... The Three of Airships often represents an irretrievable loss ..." The Four of Airships (Swords), which might mean rest in a typical RWS deck, indicates: "The airship is grounded for awhile, allowing the captain to take some down-time while repairs are completed." The Matthews have constructed their system so that it conforms with RWS while at the same time it is their own system. Or, one can read these cards intuitively.THE BOOK:The 160-page book by John and Caitlin Matthews is a solid accompaniment to the deck, and creates an alternate reality which centers around the Imperium. "You inhabit but one part of a much vaster cosmos, and are perhaps ignorant of the Imperium," it asserts. "We urge you to acquaint yourself with its co-existence beside your own world, for it is but a step away."It refers to the capital city of the Imperium, the twenty-two Gods of the Machine (the Major Arcana) that are "the sacred presences which keep the machine of life turning in this world" and which at one time in ancient history once "walked among us, and we spoke directly to them--and they to us."Vehicles enable them "to roam the earth through the four elements." The vehicles are the four suits of the deck. "Airships fly through the air, Engines govern fire, Submersibles plumb the depths of the waters, Leviathans explore earth's pathways," according to the book.Part One introduces the deck's system. "Exploring the Imperium" covers the Major Arcana, The Leagues (cards numbered Ace through Ten) and their Legates (the Court Cards), and a chart which maps out the Courts of the Four Leagues, further discussed in Laws of the Imperium. The Laws of the Imperium links each suit with specific Major Arcana cards into a system of government. The Seven Initiates of the Apprentice subdivide the Major Arcana into seven triads. The Matthews' system is cohesive and thoughtful. It makes a great backdrop for these cards.There are 26 fantastic spreads in this book. Each of the 22 Major Arcana card has its own four-card "micro-spread." For example, The Apprentice (The Fool) has "Apprentice's Try-Out Spread." The positions are: 1. What does this adventure offer? 2. What can I trust? 3. What do I risk? 4. Where does the vision lead? Each of these spreads is unique "so that you may test for yourself the power of each archetype."In addition to the 22 spreads, one for each of the Major Arcana, there are four supplementary, larger spreads in Part Three of the book, "Blueprints": The Control Panel Spread, The Steam Goggles Spread, The Keys of Wisdom Spread, and The Cosmic Blueprint Spread, with sample readings for each.In addition to these spreads, under the triads section, the authors show a clever way to create a layout for each of the seven triads. There are also complementary opposites in the Majors, and a suggested way to create a layout based on them.Two pages are devoted to the Major Arcana and one for the Minor Arcana with black-and-white photos.CONCLUSION:There is a cohesive rhythm to this deck. The Steampunk Tarot transports one into another world. The images are lush and manifest this alternate reality beautifully. One can work with the marvelous system devised by the Matthews, and which is wonderfully suited for this deck, or one can work intuitively or using RWS. I am really enjoying my adventure with this tarot created by John and Caitlin Matthews, and the illustrations by Wil Kinghan are elegantly and skillfully rendered. This is a great choice for any steampunk or scifi fan.  This is both a useful and enjoyable addition to my tarot collection, and I look forward to the journey.

I can highly recommend The Hobbit Tarot for anyone who is a fan of "The Hobbit" and J. R. R. Tolkien. In order to read with this deck, a working knowledge of the book, "The Hobbit," is very helpful. I re-read the book, and find that it has been a great study aid with the deck, in addition to the 96-page LWB which comes with the deck.Most of the cards directly refer to characters and scenes from the book (a couple of the Queens are an exception, as one, the Queen of Coins, "represents all the mothers, sisters, daughters, and beloved of those in Esgaroth!" and the other, the Queen of Cups, is a reference to Tom Bombadil's wife.) It is more of an intuitive reading deck than a RWS clone, although some RWS similarities can be found, such as Bilbo in The Fool card. But this is a themed deck, and to enjoy it, knowledge of the subject matter is helpful.This deck will be more easily read by intuitive readers who are well-versed on "The Hobbit." For those, and for collectors, this is a recommended deck and a real treat. The cardstock is lovely: matte and substantial. The backs are nonreversible, but it is hardly noticeable in the design. Strength is VIII and Justice is XI.For more Middle-Earth fun, there are some neat spreads in the back of the LWB: The Ring of Gollum Spread, The Sword of Aragon Spread, and The Arkenstone Spread.A great deck for Hobbit-philes.

By far, one of my favorite decks I have purchased this year.The imagery is charming and resonates with me. I love the costumes and the atmosphere of the deck.The people in the deck, to me, are soft and gentle. Their faces, similar to the Hudes, do not show a lot of range of expression, but I like this. I feel like I can fill in their emotions in this deck. To me, their expressions often look as though they are bordering on a smile. Sometimes they are neutral. It depends on the reader what they will see in a face on a card.I love the cardstock. It has a matte finish, but the cards feel substantial in the hand, like they will last. The borders are reversible. I thought the green border might be too bright, but it is fine. Strength is VIII and Justice is XI.This is a RWS clone, yet it has subtle differences in some cards. On the Fool card, the dog stands beside the Fool. The Wheel shows a spinning wheel and a girl with the thread tangled in the wheel. The Queen of Pentacles is napping with a baby in her lap and curlers in her hair. The Three of Pentacles is a figure alone with three Pentacles, gold pieces, falling out of her hat, while she seemingly does not notice.I have enjoyed this one, and it is in my regular rotation. If you like this style of artwork and you want something a little different in an RWS clone, consider picking this one up.

This tarot knocks my socks off. The art style and theme will either suit you or not. If it suits you, it is great for intuitive readings. It is moody and atmospheric. Like some other Lo Scarabeo offerings, it does not closely follow RWS, but I get wonderful readings from it.I will mention that the cardstock, to me, seems a little less sturdy than it did in decks made a couple of years ago by Lo Scarabeo.. These are noticeably thinner, though not by much -- and the cardstock is still of good quality. But I can see where the corners of the cards have been cut; the corners do not have an entirely smooth finish as I have seen in, say, Lo Scarabeo decks that were printed several years ago. When I weigh the deck, the deck weighs a few grams lighter than some of my older Lo Scarabeo decks.Card backs are nonreversible: a man's hand reaches toward a woman's hand, but the design is subtle and beautiful, and for me, it is not a distraction. Strength is VIII and Justice is XI. The LWB is in multiple languages, typical of LoS LWBs: this one is in English, Italian, Spanish, French, and Dutch. Each section is about 12 pages long.There is one spread included, a five-card spread called "The Path of the Five Houses," also called "The Road of the Five Doors."This is already one of my favorite decks. If you like this theme, and this sort of imagery, and can read intuitively, pick this one up and see what Ludy has to say to you.

The Mystic Dreamer has some beautiful imagery. As others have mentioned, the imagery is smaller than I would have liked once I saw the cards in person. This set is particularly well suited to beginners, although readers of any level, from beginner to advanced, can enjoy it. Many reviews here are from new readers using this set as their first deck. For that, they get a book and deck kit to help them on their way.There is some repetitiveness to the moon and raven images throughout the deck. The CGI effects are a bit obvious at times. And the borders are a bit intrusive.Still, this deck has its charm, and I will use it from time to time, although if the images were larger, I would be tempted to use it more often. Although, there are many who are fine with the size of these images and will use it as a daily deck, so if you are okay with slightly smaller images and you are interested in this style, pick this one up. Like other Llewelyn offerings, plan to make some room for the deck and box kit, as they do take some storage space if you are a collector with a lot of decks. On my wish list is for Llewelyn to offer their decks as deck-only options one day.

My "Lord of the Rings Tarot Deck & Card Game," has grown on me over time. When I first got it, I thought it was more a game. I looked at the cards but could not find any serious meanings within them regarding tarot. But that has changed.This is one you have to take a close look at, or it can pass you right by without one even realizing what an nice LOTR collector's piece it is, plus what an important tarot reading tool it is.The box itself is quite tricky to manage. To keep it in its best collector's shape, one should leave it in place and simply slide the cards and their tuck box out of the pocket they are in along one side of the box to examine them.This set is published by U.S. Games.Inside the tuck box, you will find a LWB entitled "The Lord of the Rings Tarot Deck & Card Game: Tarot developed by Terry Donaldson, Artwork developed by Peter Pracownik, Game rules by Mike Fitzgerald," along with a Title card, 78 "tarot" or "game" cards, plus an extra card entitled "The Lord of the Rings Tarot Card Game A Quick Guide to Victory Points" which has to do with playing the game.The game play is explained on pages 28-39 of the LWB and is explained beginning in the following section: "The Lord of the Rings Tarot Card Game - Rules by Mike Fitzgerald" It states "For 2-6 players, Ages 10 to adult." Object of the Game is stated to be: "In their quest to reach Mount Doom, players try to acquire the highest number of Victory Points." As a round ends, the players reach Mount Doom. The journey is represented by cards discarded from your hand into the Journey Pile (the discard pile).Along the way, players can be influenced by forces from Middle Earth or by Dark Forces. There are Dark Points involved and these appear on certain cards with what is known as a "Dark Forces" symbol. Other cards have a "Free Peoples" symbol which represents Gandalf. Other cards have a Neutral symbol which can be associated with either good or evil. One card has a One Ring symbol: the Wheel of Fortune, which represents the Ring in this game. It determines who is the Ring Bearer.Now that I have described some of the game play to you, let me go back to describing these cards to you as tarot cards. This is why I originally purchased them: that and my love of Lord of the Rings.However, as a tarot deck, when I first got the deck they did not work for me for a number of reasons, and I will state some of their shortcomings here:Let's take a given card as an example. How about The Fool card?1. They use Gollum as the Fool. To me, it would seem that Frodo would be the Fool, as he is the one setting off on the great Adventure with the Ring. (More card examples below.)2. Also on these cards, there are very heavy borders, at least 1/2 inch thick on one side, and along the bottom even thicker. However, as I got to know the cards, I began to better accept these borders. They are almost used as "scenes" or, if you will, think of it as pulling back a curtain and looking onto a stage. It is as though the border is framing the action and is in fact part of the action. So the borders do not bother me so much anymore.3. If you do not like keywords on your cards, these go beyond keywords. These put entire sentences on their cards. The Fool card reads: "Gollum, by a pool of water, considers the many possibilities open to him." While many tarot readers know that the Fool card *can* indicate possibilties, (a) it doesn't always indicate that; that is only one of a myriad of meanings; and (b) I don't really associate that phrase with Gollum at all. I think of many things when I think of Gollum, but that is not one of them. Gollum was fixated, trapped, but he was not "open to possibilities" in my book.4. The symbols for use in playing this game are quite big on the cards and add to the busyness and clutter on an already cluttered card.5. By the time you subtract the: (a) wide border, (b) keywords/sentence, (c) game play symbols - you are left with what is a relatively small piece of artwork.Despite these flaws, the cards are charming. The idea of having a game combined with a tarot deck is charming. And I cannot help myself: I do enjoy having the keywords/sentences on *these* cards: I find myself reading them. They have particular meaning to me because I love Lord of the Rings. So as a Lord of the Rings collector, I find value in their meanings. And those meanings would translate nicely over into tarot readings.I actually find this to be a perfectly readable tarot deck, if one chooses to work with it.Would I have changed some of the cards around? Yes. I still would have made Frodo the Fool. Lady Eowyn is The High Priestess in this deck, but I think Galadriel would have been better suited, as the High Priestess is generally one of "secrets and the subconscious" and "understanding the possibilities," for without Galadriel's gifts and her gazing into the mirror (thus her knowledge of what to give) the quest would have failed.  Galadriel is secretive and magical.And I simply do not like their interpretation of the Death card at all. "Wormtongue's insidious advice poisons the mind of good King Theoden." This is not a traditional Death card meaning. The Death card is about uprooting, about going through a transition, about being in the path of sweeping change, about a rebirth, about an ending: closing one door and another one opening. None of those things are portrayed in this Death card.THE BOOK:Let me say a few words about Terry Donaldson's excellent companion book. It begins with a section on "Welcome to Middle Earth" in which he introduces us to Tolkien, Middle Earth, The Hobbit, and Lord of the Rings. Next is "The Significance of Tolkien's Genius" in which he discusses Tolkien's Silmarillion and more of the history of the Lord of the Rings. Donaldson ties the Lord of the Rings characters into society and into each one of us. He speaks of the weapons and the Rings as well.The Major Arcana and Minor Arcana are then discussed. Approximately 7 pages are devoted to each of the Major Arcana, including Lord of the Rings meanings, tarot meanings, negative aspects (reversals), astrological associations, and even a wonderful section in which the card "speaks" to us.In the Minor Arcana on page 182, one page per card lists meanings. The Minor Arcana, unfortunately, do not get the full treatment that the Major Arcana get: they get a very short paragraph on what their Lord of the Rings meaning is, and about two sentences on what their tarot meaning is. No reversals, astrological, or "card speaking" sections are given.Lastly, "Reading with the Lord of the Rings Tarot Deck" includes a section on meditating with the deck, reading for yourself, reading for others (this section gives some excellent advice!), and gives some really nice spreads, including a 7-card Gandalf spread and a Hobbit spread.WHAT YOU GET:1. 80-card deck in a tuckbox2. Paper Fold-out spreadsheet "Gandalf Spread" in the form of the Elvish Letter "G"3. 268-page book by Terry Donaldson "The Lord of the Rings Tarot"4. All inside of an outer box, published by U.S. GamesWHO SHOULD GET IT:1. Lord of the Rings collectors2. Tarot collectors3. Definitely Lord of the Rings collectors who are tarot readers4. Tarot readers who are looking for something different5. Board/card game players looking for a new card game6. Anyone, and I mean ANYONE, who LOVES Lord of the Rings! :)There is some wonderful stuff here for any collector or tarot reader who likes Lord of the Rings. Despite its minor shortcomings, it is a nicely done tarot deck and quite an appealing collector's piece. Don't let that it has "game" in the title throw you. This one should be in any Lord of the Rings collector's tarot collection, plus you can actually read with it.Recommended.

Just got my deck!! I LOVE it. This is by the same fine folks that designed the tongue-in-cheek Housewives tarot.Initial impressions: First of all, what can I say about the box! It is quite the presentation in itself. With faux printed bullets lining the paper rim, there is your ammunition for the Zombie Apocalypse. The box is meant to be an ammunition box so you have bullets to "kill" the zombies. ;) Very clever!Inside, tucked away and surrounded by black velvet-like material, is the deck. The cards are somewhat stiff, with a nice cardstock that will last for awhile. The cardstock has a matte finish.The 96-page instruction booklet lies on top of the deck. Each page is chock full of zombie apocolyptic goodness. Not a LWB and is not too big a book that you can't -- pardon the pun -- digest it. It's just right!I did a 4-card deck introductory reading. It was very revealing and fun at the same time; an interesting spin on the tarot!The imagery is extremely witty and clever. Anyone who enjoys zombies or horror should enjoy this deck. :) Anyway ... the imagery is loads of fun. When I first received my deck, I didn't even look through all of the cards ... I just started shuffling the deck because I wanted to be surprised by my first reading! Which was a blast!The cardstock is nice: expect thick, unbending, and matte. The black backs have a bit of a retro vibe. The imagery, cardstock and packaging combined gives a sort of 50s/60s feel to this tarot.Recommended for zombie fans, those with a sense of humor about horror, expecting a fifties/early sixties touch.

First of all, I am thrilled that I went ahead with my purchase despite some misgivings I had.This is a really nice set of cards. I just got mine today, and I have already done my yearly spread.I was concerned that 200 cards would be a lot to handle.I like the quality of the bag. I wasn't sure with various reports of it getting torn, but I used the bag to shuffle my cards and I did not have any problems.The instructions in the book are straightforward. I did the yearly reading because the book says to start out with that one before doing my first weekly.Shuffling is easy with the bag. There is no need to make piles of cards. The bag is plenty sturdy.  I don't see it tearing unless someone is super rough with it.This is a really nice set of cards, and I am looking forward to seeing how accurate the readings are with it! I can see it being useful for daily or weekly draws or to supplement a tarot reading.Each month in the yearly spread gives you four cards which you read to make up that month's reading. A very pretty circular layout and with 48 cards, 4 for each month, it gives you a very good picture of what the year will be like. The author also encourages you in her book to look for relationships and patterns in cards between different months.Here is a sample month reading from the yearly spread: November. Bag - Somthing important, such as a new job or a raise. Tiger - Doing something risky. Taking a chance. Egg - Success assured with good plans and hard work. Tower - Solid foundation. Success with effort. Putting those four cards together, it sounds like a career- or work-oriented challenge will present itself in November. It is a risky move, but I have a solid foundation in the field, and success is ensured if I apply myself. Strategic planning is also a factor in my success. December shows Throne, a position of authority, and Arrow, being on the right path, so the cards look like I succeed.This is an excellent set and, if you have been on the fence about ordering it as I was, I would definitely say this one is worth having in any collection.

I bought this as a replacement for the OXO GOOD Grips Soap Dispensing Palm Brush. I much prefer this brush due to the hefty weight of the item, the stainless steel look of the item which actually looks like stainless, and the extra height of this brush makes it feel good in the hand and makes it easier to use. It also fixed some problems with the older style soap dispensing palm brush which a previous reviewer alluded to. I had that brush and was never happy with it because it did not dispense soap properly, although it was a pretty brush.I have been using this brush for about 4 years without any problems.There is one reviewer who states "don't bother with the replacement brushes." I have had zero problem replacing the brushes on mine. Mine has not developed any leaks, and the top is not at all difficult to remove. That reviewer must have received an entirely different brush! My brush has been fine.One thing about this stainless steel brush that is not as good as the clear style soap dispensing one is that with the clear style, you could easily see the soap level. With this brush, the stainless steel accent mostly hides the soap level. It is not really an issue, as you can tell when the soap is running low.This is very handy for washing dishes or scrubbing pots and pans. It has various types of replaceable brushes you can twist on and off: sponge pad, plastic mesh, and the regular bristle. It lasts a long time due to the replaceable heads and goes well with many kitchen decors.

6:14 MinsVIDEO:Hi everyone, this is a video review of this lovely tarot bag I received for my Steampunk Tarot deck by Barbara Moore and Aly Fell.In the video, I show you the satin bag and talk a bit about it.If you are a fan of this deck, it is a really nice bag and beautifully complements the deck. The back of the bag is brown and matches the card backs; a nice touch. The inner lining is grey with grey tassels.Only special decks get bags in my collection. This deck has already proven it is a workhorse deck and not just another pretty face!

It is described as "5 B&W TV AM/FM/weather (7-band) radio Fine tuning knob for weather band Double fluorescent bulb light Bright-beam flashlight Mosquito repeller Emergency siren Splashproof Includes AC & car adapters Requires 9 C batteries.""Mosquito repeller"? Not sure how that one got thrown into the description. Never saw a mosquito repeller on it. I would have been happy if, out of all those things on that list, it had just tried to do ONE thing well! Like be a good lantern.Clearly the B&W TV won't work anymore. But even when the TV would work, the thing just wasn't a good idea, because it's trying to do too much and the lights are positioned poorly. It uses unpopular and harder to find C batteries.The lights are positioned with one in front and one cockeyed off to the rear / side. The rear light is lopsided and not nearly as nice as the light I ended up using the most frequently of all the emergency lanterns I have tried, the eGear 10-DAY Lantern, Silver. The lights could not, pardon the pun, hold a candle to that light. They are not as bright, will not last as long, and are not positioned as conveniently.Very happy with the eGear 10-DAY Lantern, Silver!

By far I would recommend this storm lantern over any of the others I have tried.I live in a city directly next to the Gulf of Mexico where we get hurricane threats all during that season.I need a lantern that is long-lasting like this one, and that can handle extended power outages that might last for days.What I did not expect was for this lantern to still be working -- 8 years after I purchased it on Amazon in 2004!The adjustable ultra-bright 12-LED light is amazing. You can set it to get only the minimum light in a room, or turn it up for more brightness. This light does not produce heat. This is very important in the hot and humid climate where I live, especially if you are going for days without electricity or A/C.I highly recommend this lantern to anyone looking for a reliable storm lantern that will last them for years to come!

I had this for a short while before it broke. It didn't last six months.This was under light usage. It was put behind my desktop monitor, in a spot where it had plenty of room.The ports, however, stopped working one by one.It is unreliable.And the "light" that plugs in at the top is useless. Pretty, but doesn't throw off as much light as the customer photo that is shown. The light appears at the end of the Flylight, but does not shine far or bright. You'd get better light using a backlit keyboard or even a lit flash drive plugged in as this FlyLight doesn't throw off any light.Do not waste your money!

I'm a hypoglycemic and this product has done wonders for me and my blood sugar.As far as Nature's Way having someone rude in customer service, there are rude jerks in customer service in every company. What I notice in reading the product label is that Xylitol is listed under "other ingredients" at the bottom, so it is unclear how much is in it. It would be nice if they would list a percentage for those sensitive to it!What I do is mix Metabolic Reset with skim milk in a blender. I add about six ice cubes. This makes it into a thick shake. That keeps my hunger at bay. If you are sensitive to milk, you can change that to lactose-free milk, or a dairy-free product if you are vegan such as rice milk. I find it fills me up a lot more than just mixing the product with water.I can't just mix it with water, as I get really hungry, too. So that is my secret. Hope it helps you!

I've had my Battery Tender for a couple of years now and I don't know what I would do without it.When I need my car to start ... it's a good thing the Battery Tender is connected!And when I get back into the garage, the first thing I do is hook up the Battery Tender!What I love about it is that I never have to worry that it will overcharge or fry my battery.It won't jump a dead battery, but I didn't buy it for that. I wanted a trickle charger, and it does the job beautifully.If you're a person who walks out and realizes you haven't driven your car for awhile, then this is the perfect solution.Battery Tender will take care of it all for you!

I do not recommend these for two reasons:One, they have a short battery life.Two, the call quality is terrible with these batteries after a short while. It is because they are rated 800mAH. Don't even bother with a battery unless it is rated 850mAH. The battery life may still be short on an 850mAH battery, but at least the volume on your calls will sound louder and you will have fewer dropped calls.I bought a battery rated 850mAH. The call quality was significantly better, which is why I will not go back to ordering these. I do not feel, however, that the 850mAH-rated battery extended battery life.BOTH will have short battery life. These will have lousy call quality. The 850s will at least give you good call quality.

This shampoo is a fantastic shampoo for dogs who are sprayed by skunks!It can also be used on cats and produces a rich lather.It is easy to rinse off, and leaves your pet's coat with a healthy glow and a nice fragrance.I have cats, and I was very pleased with the way they looked and smelled after using this shampoo.It is gentle.Would buy again!

This is a great little Sony DVD player and it has been going strong for 2 1/2 years!It has a very small footprint. It is easy to set up.I had some trepidation, because my last Sony DVD player died with a read error; the Sony player stopped being able to read discs. So I was concerned about whether I should stick with Sony.But so far, I have had only great experiences with this little player!It is extremely lightweight. It has played every disc without complaint; discs from the library and from Netflix.It shows no signs of letting up and has just been really solid in every way!The only thing I am not as happy about is the new remote that came with it. It is not a big deal: it doesn't have an eject button on it; but it's sometimes a nice feature. Also missing is the commercial skip button. The remote is also not glow-in-the-dark like the previous remote.One thing I really like a LOT about the new remote is its size! It is half the size of the other remote. It is a lot easier to keep on my coffee table, or toss in a drawer.Overall, I recommend this because I've had really good luck with this Sony DVD player and its longevity, and I think it's a solid model. It is quiet, and when it is off, there are no lights to contend with. If something happened to it, I would want the same player; it's been just that solid.

The imagery on this deck is rich and will be appreciated if you are a goth fan -- and may even earn the appreciation of some non goth fans.Llewelyn states, "Alchemy 1977 is famous around the globe for their stunning gothic artwork and steampunk accessories. Fans of this iconic brand will recognize and appreciate the powerful and seductive images in this extraordinary tarot deck. This captivating mix of art from world famous gothic illustrators ranges from traditional horror to lush supernatural scenes to medieval fantasy."Kings are dragons: what fun! And the suit of wands has been replaced with black roses: a nice touch. The cards themselves have me feeling I am in a dark and wonderful world. A werewolf makes an appearance. There is a tattooed faery on Temperance. There are lots of skulls. The cards are lustrous and detailed and richly colored, and so is the world where these creatures live.The only downside for me is that I don't read plain pips so well.  If I come across the Six of Cups (three sets of two silver cups filled with what appears to be blood on a reddish backdrop), it is more difficult for me to read that card than if it were illustrated. Some of you will not have that problem.This deck is a beautiful one by Fournier, distributed by Lo Scarabeo. It comes with a LWB and the backs with a skull pattern are non-reversible.If you are into goth, it is a must-have.Even if you aren't, this is a beautifully detailed, rich, dark deck.Highly recommended.

While I found this to be a lovely tarot, with beautiful imagery, when I received mine, I was a bit disappointed with how small the images were.I don't feel that I can use this as a proper reading deck, but if you do not have a problem with reading small images, this deck will be a superb reading deck for you.The card size is 2 3/4" x 4 7/8". However, there is at the bottom of the card a large area in white for the card name with a double border in gold-ish ink.  On the sides there is also a border. Due to the size of the borders, one loses a lot in the size of the actual image.Otherwise the imagery itself is stunning: ethereal, spiritual, almost reminiscent of the Rohrig tarot.If you do not mind small imagery and can read it as such, you will find some wonderful surprises in this deck. Jim Morrison from the Doors is on one of the cards (the Knight of Flames). That it has princesses, such as the Princess of Swords in flight, gives it a sort of Thothy tone.The Minors aren't exactly illustrated. I say it that way, because the Ananda is kind of special. The Eight of Cups show eight cups floating down a river, or rather, suspended above it. But there is a lot of imagery in the card. So it isn't a plain pips card. There is plenty to draw from there in a reading.It is printed by AGMuller, and they are one of my favorite printers. I love their card stock.The card backs are reversible.I recommend this deck if you can read with small images, because it is an exceptional deck.~~"I want to die peacefully in my sleep, like my grandfather. Not screaming like the passengers in his cab." <<

This tarot deck is a feast for the eyes, dripping in gold. The fronts of the cards are heavily foiled in gold. It is a very innovative, unique deck and one that I am glad that I have in my collection. The "idea, technical innovations and graphics" are by Pietro Alligo. The LWB and instructions are by Giordano Berti and Tiberio Gonard.THE DECKThe reversible card backs are in colors of paisley and muted red with images of Jesus Christ in the vein of Orthodox Churches which the Golden Tarot of the Tsar celebrates. They blend beautifully with the deck.Justice is 8. Strength is 11. There are Knaves, Knights, Queens and Kings.The card stock is a nice one, and easily shuffled. My cards slide easily and have a nice finish.Speaking of the box, the box itself is quite lavish. There is gold foil used extensively on all four sides and the top of the box. Given that it is on a backdrop of red and blue, it is quite pleasing to the eye.THE CARDSAll meanings per the LWB (reversed meanings not given):The Fool shows "The possession of Gerasa -- Recovery of psychological faculties. Return to health."The High Priestess shows "Saint Paraskeva -- "The future not yet revealed. Silence. Hidden Knowledge. The mystery of faith."The 4 of Chalices shows "The prophet of Elijah on Mount Horeb -- Invention. Omen. Enlightening. Dream."The 9 of Chalices shows "Joseph welcomed by the Pharoah -- Promotion. Increase in salary. Reward."The 2 of Pentacles shows "David plays the horn -- Lightheartedness. Thoughtlessness. Simplicity."The 3 of Pentacles shows "Saint Luke paints the Virgin -- Work upon request. Glory without gain."The 4 of Wands shows "Miracle of the icon of the Virgin -- Unexpected opportunity. Prosperity."The 8 of Wands shows "Saint Leontius fights for the faith -- Long-distance conflicts. Legal action. Hard struggle."The 2 of Swords shows "Saint Michael judges the souls -- Assessment problems. Conflict of competencies."The 8 of Swords shows "Martyrdom of Saint George -- Inner crisis. Great suffering. Loss of freedom."READINGWhile stunningly beautiful to look at -- and I still think they belong in any collection -- there may be some issues depending on the reader for use as practical reading cards:1. In order to get the most out of this deck, one needs to have a good familiarity with saints and Christian symbols as taught in Orthodox Christianity.2. The scenes in the middle of the card are somewhat small; depending on one's eyesight.OTHER THOUGHTSThe Golden Tarot of the Tsar seeks to celebrate Orthodox religion (especially that of Byzantine Russia) and the teachings therein. The LWB gives a nice explanation, thanks to the succinct but thorough introduction by Giordano Berti.This deck is a beautiful deck to use around the December holiday season, as its red-and-gold colors make it very festive for a table.  It would be a great deck to use for Christian querents.It is also a terrific way to use the enclosed LWB to have a history lesson on the saints or Orthodox Christian events. Since each card depicts a different scene, there is a lot to learn here, or take as a refresher course.This is one of the most beautiful and unusual decks that I own. I do not read with it, but it is a prized possession in my collector's decks because of its beauty, uniqueness and the amount of gold on the cards. I do not have another deck like this one. The card images alone and the way the cards are constructed are one-of-a-kind.

This is the excellent companion book to the Tarot of Prague tarot deck. It adds greatly to one's appreciation of the deck, although one does not have to have the book in order to appreciate the amazing Tarot of Prague.The book, however, is highly sought after, and well it should be, as it is filled with secrets unlocked about these 78 wondrous cards that only those who possess this book will know. Karen Mahony herself (one of the creators of the Tarot of Prague and half of Magic Realist Press) has written this, so it should come as no surprise that the book is excellent: from the print quality of the pages to the very covers.Inside it states, "A tarot based on the Art and Architecture of the 'Magic City'" and indeed, the city of Prague does appear to be magic in the hands of Karen Mahony and Alex Ukolov. Their whimsical, bohemian touches blending the architecture of Prague into a tarot deck have lent this tarot a wonderful glow from within that carries a special magic of its own.Inside this book lies much history about Prague. For example, the Chariot card is discussed in depth, as are all the cards. The sources for the card elements are given in detail for each card. Included is the Royal Route, which is a road in Prague "traditionally taken by Bohemian kings on their way to coronation." There is a lengthy explanation given of the Royal Route, as quite a few cards in the Tarot of Prague include imagery taken from buildings along the Royal Route. In the Ace of Cups, for example, the Lion is from a building on Nerudova Street, which is along the Royal Route. The carved wooden relief in the Ace of Wands is from St. Vitus' Cathedral, which is along the Royal Route.We learn about Queen Elizabeth of Bohemia, about the Charles Bridge, and we learn items of interest along the way such as the myth of the Melusine. There is magic abounding in Prague, which may account for the magic that seems to spring forth in the tarots published by Magic Realist Press!"The Tarot of Prague" is a very enjoyable read which will explain in detail about every card in the deck and have you wanting to plan your next vacation to Prague.Highly recommended.~~"I want to die peacefully in my sleep, like my grandfather. Not screaming like the passengers in his cab." <<

If you pick up this tarot, you will find yourself wanting to know more about Prague. You may well find yourself wanting to travel there. I know I do.This tarot creates a marvelous fantasy world that is half tarot, half history lesson on the beautiful city of Prague. Gleaming statues, magnificent architecture; all are intermixed with the Magicians symbols or the Moon's beautiful backdrop. I ended up housing my Tarot of Prague in a gorgeous Moon bag with the print of that card (the makers of this wonderful tarot), with fringe! But I digress.The card stock is lovely. It is not laminated. The backs are black and white in a reversed pattern.This is a very readable deck: rich in symbolism. It is also a charming deck. It is a taste of Prague wherever you may be. You can pick up this deck and feel light-hearted at your very core.
