Pick any card out of the deck and you will be greeted by an artistic swirl of fantastic figurines on whimsical backgrounds with bits of architectural history thrown in that are centuries old, all in a readable tarot card.The book describes the Moon card as "based on statue of Nox" (Night) at 5 Nerudova Street. It is high up on the house and is partnered with an equally striking figure of the Day." The book goes on to explain that on the Moon card, "The background is the Vltava by moonlight. One of the two towers is the legendary Medieval Old Town Charles Bridge tower. The other ... [ ] stands on Novotnho lvka." Much more detail is gone into in the book.It is fascinating to read about the history in the cards. But even if one does not have the book, one can feel the history emanating from this deck. Most of the deck are themselves statues or paintings from Prague.  It is a quite remarkable deck and I know of none other like it.I hope one day to visit Prague and to take my deck with me and to visit all of the places that I see on it!Don't pass this one up. Grab one while you can.Plus it is done by the incomparable Magic Realist Press's Karen Mahony and Alex Ukolov.Highly recommended.~~"I want to die peacefully in my sleep, like my grandfather. Not screaming like the passengers in his cab." <<

The Circle of Life is one of my favorite reading decks ever produced by Lo Scarabeo. It is an underrated deck that should be looked at by any serious tarot collector or reader, from beginning to advanced. This deck works best with intuitive readers. It is in my top 10 favorite decks and is always on my reading table. It has a wealth of imagery that makes reading with it an amazing experience.  The slightly oversized round cards (about 4 1/4 inches in diameter) are gorgeous and filled with symbolism for interpretation.  I especially love The Fool, but there are so many beautiful cards here.  If you get the Deluxe version, you'll get a blue and gold satin bag for the cards. I have the Deluxe edition with the bag and love it: it is perfect for the cards. The gold satin cloth in the bag matches the gold card backs.  I like the card stock: it is neither too thin, nor too thick.  It feels just right in the hand.To shuffle a deck like this, I like to slide the cards around and shuffle them in a pile.  I find this makes handling this deck easy and a delight.  If you try to shuffle them like a traditional tarot deck, you may find it difficult.  Work with the cards, and enjoy them! It really is easy to find your own method for sliding these cards around; they are easy to work with and to handle as you will soon find out on your own!The imagery of the deck is fanciful forest creatures such as elves and fairies, wizards and creatures: some familiar, some not.  It is like a magical forest, and a celebration of nature and the interplay between the whimsical and the divine, with all of the lightness and darkness that can be found within the "circle of life."Although most people don't read reversals in round decks, you can if you so choose.  In a round deck, it shows the full range of a card.  You do so by reading all of the intervals between upright and reversed: in other words, how far off they are from upright, or reversed.  I like to think of it as reading them like the hands of a clock, or the phases of a moon.  They may be approaching a full upright position, just leaving a full upright position, approaching a reversed position, etc.  Use your imagination!  This deck lacks for nothing in that department.Note: There is no proper "book" that comes with the Deluxe edition. It is called "Deluxe" because of the silk bag that you get along with the cards. You also get a squarish "LWB" (little white book) in several languages: English, Italian, Spanish, French, and Dutch. Of this, not counting the page that lists the languages in the front, only pages 3-7 are in English. A 30-card spread is given and the 30 cards are referenced on page 31 in the LWB.I truly love this deck.  It is a wonderful addition to any collection.

I really like this Arkon Portable Fold-Up Stand for my third generation iPad.It has several useful positions. To me, the most useful one is the basic upright position, which in and of itself can be altered a myriad of ways, as the stand is very flexible: the top portion can fold into a mode that will take the iPad down into a typing position, for example.I use mine on a shelf next to my bed. The shelf is deep enough that the stand fits completely on the shelf. However, if I wanted to, I could bring just the edge of the stand forward, so that I could have the 30-pin connector facing downward and have it freely dangling for a charge. The rubbery grip material extends all the way from the front to the back of the feet of this stand, so it will sit firmly where you put it.There is another choice, if I want to charge my iPad using the Arkon stand on my shelf, and that is to leave this stand sitting back deeper on the shelf but turn the iPad 180 so that the 30-pin connector faces up, and charge it that way. Or, I could charge it in landscape mode -- but on my shelf with some of the other things I have on the shelf, landscape mode is a little tight, given my space requirements on that particular shelf, so I prefer to park it in portrait mode when I am using it on that shelf.Speaking of which, let's talk about how I can use that stand in a typing position to type on the iPad. This works best on a hard, firm surface, such as a desktop or table. Open your iPad, open any Notes or document app, and lean the iPad into a typing mode. The stand is flexible enough to adapt. Now you've got a great position for either the iPad's built-in keyboard or for a wireless keyboard. This is also a nice position to use the iPad for web browsing.Using the iPad in landscape mode in an upright position on this stand is great for looking at slideshows of photos, or movies. It makes a great frame for your pictures.This is a very versatile stand. You can pick it up at a moment's notice and take it somewhere else. It will pack easily and go with you. It folds down into one simple piece that can be cleverly placed into a sleeve or bag.

These shredder lubricant sheets have kept my small Mailmate shredder running smoothly. I believe shredder lubricant sheets are one of the secrets to long life in a shredder.It gives the right amount of oil to each shredder blade simply by running a sheet through the shredder. They work great with all shredders.It literally is as easy as shredding a piece of paper! You run your shredder in reverse after you shred the sheet.I have found that these really do the trick. They work with any type of shredder. For the low amount they cost, they are a high investment in your shredder, and worth every penny.Pick up a pack of these today! Your shredder will thank you.  My trusty MailMate is still going strong and I think largely because I use these.~~"I want to die peacefully in my sleep, like my grandfather. Not screaming like the passengers in his cab." <<

I guess I must be one of the lucky ones, because my MailMate shredder is still going strong after having it for quite a long while.I use it for junk mail. I follow the directions and don't allow it to overheat.I also bought some sheets with oil added to them called "shredder lubricant sheets." I use them as directed. They are to provide "optimal shredder performance."The only downside to a shredder like this is the limited capacity, but I knew that when I purchased this machine.The upside is the machine's great portability and ease of use. I can easily empty the basket when full for reuse.I would recommend this shredder for light use jobs. If you want to stick it somewhere near your front door to stick junk mail into when you come home, it is perfect for that.  But it is not designed to be an everyday shredder to handle all your shredding needs.Recommended, with the above caveats.~~"I want to die peacefully in my sleep, like my grandfather. Not screaming like the passengers in his cab." <<

What stands out to me about this bar are the natural chocolate and coconut flavors. The coconut is natural coconut flakes sprinkled on top. The box states "delicious strands of naturally tasty coconut." The chocolate layer is nice and thick, and really satisfies my craving for chocolate. These Kashi bars contain no high fructose corn syrup. The dark chocolate is made of evaporated cane juice, chocolate liquor, and cocoa.WHO SHOULD GET THESE:* Chocolate lovers.* People looking for a low protein bar.* People looking for a bar with all-natural ingredients.* A bar with no high fructose corn syrup* A bar with dietary fiberThere are other bars that will give you 10 or 20 grams of protein and less or about the same amount of sugar (7 grams). The only downside is that because this bar only contains 4 grams of protein, and 4 grams of dietary fiber, it doesn't leave me feeling satisfied for long.These work for a light snack, when I am in the mood for a bite of chocolate. They are great with a glass of skim milk. At 120 calories, and only 30 grams of fat, I highly recommend them, as long as you are not looking for a protein bar. For the chocolate flavor alone, these bars are a standout.

Works great as long as your motherboard will work with a 20 pin power connector (most lower power motherboards are okay leaving the other 4 pins unconnected but not all of them) and doesn't need too much power. Unlike the 80 watt picoPSU-80, this has a 4 pin 12 volt power connector for those motherboards than need one. It seems very efficient. Compared to a 300 watt 80-Plus Gold supply, and using a fairly inexpensive 60 watt "brick" 12 volt power supply, the brick and the PSU-90 combo used about 10% less power then the 300 watt 80-Plus Gold supply. That's likely because the system I'm running idles around 10 watts and needs less than 18 watts under max load. That's too light of a load for 300+ watt power supply to be very efficient. My system is a fanless Bay Trail Intel J1800 with an SSD.This also runs fairly cool with my system. My infrared thermo reads about 35C with an 18 watt load. I don't know how warm it might get under heavier load.One thing to note. If you're familiar with power factor, most 12 volt "bricks" under 90 watts are NOT power factor corrected. So at light loads some need about twice the VA as watts. For example with my system it run 12 watts and 22 VA with a 60 watt brick. I did try a 90 watt Mean Well brick with power factor correction and it was even more efficient and the VA was barely higher than the watts used.

This board is disappointing on several levels. First, even with a best-case highly efficient power supply the idle power consumption is about double an Intel Bay Trail fanless board (like the J1800). AMD just doesn't seem to understand power management. The difference between idle and full load power consumption is only a few watts.The heat sink is also marginal. Just sitting idle (no CPU load) in open air, the CPU heats up to 60 C. Inside a case without a fan, it hits 75 C. And under load in a case it overheats. What's the point of a fanless motherboard if it needs a fan? Intel Bay Trail boards stay cool without a fan.Biostar is not in the same league as Asus or Asrock. The BIOS has some poor English, there are limited options, the manual is a single folded page, etc.The performance, despite the higher power consumption and quad cores, isn't much better than a dual core Intel Bay Trail. You don't get twice the speed despite it using twice as much power.The only good news are the standard DDR3 SIM sockets (many fanless mini-ITX boards use laptop memory) and the full size PCIe slot (many fanless boards have  only a PCIe X1 slot or an old-school PCI slot). So, for some applications, this board might still be a good fit.

This was free with Prime so its hard to complain too much but I wouldn't pay money for it. Most of it is very basic common sense. It reads like a high-school paper written by someone looking to provide the required number of words while doing the minimum amount of work. The sky is sometimes blue, life is finite, and we all have to make decisions. The author offers up pearls of wisdom over and over such as some decisions are easier than others and it's good to anticipate problems. Really?If you've read any books or even a decent article, about decision making or procrastination, you've read 95% of what's in this book. For someone literally still in Junior High School there might be enough new material to make it worthwhile. For those who already know the usual common-sense advice, this is probably a waste of time. The author doesn't really even provide a new perspective, such as personal anecdotes, to lend a little more value to the tired material.I don't know what's up with Kindle reviews, but they often seem more suspect than the print variety--especially for Kindle books available for free under various programs. If you look up Chref, for example, he/she apparently reads roughly a DOZEN BOOKS A DAY and gives every single one a 5 star review. I know there are many on the Fiverr website offering a dozen "unique" 5 star reviews in exchange for money. So beware.

It's hard to find high output smart USB chargers that are well designed and not potential fire hazards. If you read the critical reviews of verified buyers you'll find many complaints for various no-name brands about overheating, bad smells, and even sparks and melted plastic. Most are offered by sketchy Chinese companies with little or no significant presence in the USA. TechMatte isn't exactly a big name, but at least they have a significant presence in the USA and this unit claims to be designed in the USA.Here are things to consider when shopping for a USB charger and how this one stacks up:- Maximum Output Per Port: Ideally each port should be good for 2.4 amps as the TechMatte is.- Maximum Total Output: Some devices offer 2.4 amps on one or more ports but the total output is limited--i.e. you can't draw 2.4 amps from every port at once. With the TechMatte you're limited to a total of 10 amps but it's very unlikely you'll ever reach that. You can charge 4 devices  at 2.4 amps or 5 devices at up to 2 amps each. Having 5 devices that each need over 2 amps would be very rare. But, if you're simultaneously charging a fleet of tablets, just consider this a 4 port charger. - Build Quality/Safety: A lot of people leave their chargers plugged in 24 hours a day. So you don't want some cheap no-name Chinese plastic wonder bursting into flames when you're not around (yes it happens). Ideally you want a unit with the UL approved seal on it. A FCC seal is also a sign of a well designed product. ETL is another recognized safety agency. CE approval, when it's real, is also worth something but sadly it's often NOT real on Chinese products (when challenged the manufactures argue it stands for "China Export"--Google it). This charger has the CE and FCC seals but not UL or ETL--so I knocked a star off for that. It is, however, in a metal enclosure which makes me feel significantly better if something inside goes wrong. Most chargers are in plastic enclosures. It also runs cool (although I've not managed to push it much past about 25 watts yet). It also doesn't squeal, hiss, or buzz like some of the no-name Chinese designs. It seems both well designed and well made. - Smart vs "Dumb" Charging: Here's where things get interesting. Sadly, USB devices use a variety of different methods to charge at faster rates. Old school USB ports are limited to 0.5 amps of output. So to draw more than 0.5 amps and allow faster charging, some sort of "negotiation" has to go on between the device and the charger. Different companies sadly do this differently. Apple, for example, uses a completely different method than say Samsung. So an Apple tablet won't correctly charge (or charge at all) from a Samsung charger and vice-versa. Google Nexus/LG/Asus products are further different. A proper "smart" charger tries to overcome these incompatibilities by configuring itself in different ways and seeing what generates the highest charging current. This isn't a trivial thing as it's not something the devices being charged were designed for. So it requires both the proper charger hardware design and well though-out firmware in the charger. A lot of the no-name Chinese designs get this at least partly wrong. That's why you'll see a lot of complaints in reviews saying things like "the XYZ Smartcharger charges much slower than the charger that came with my phone." The TechMatte seems to get this part right. It appropriately charges everything I've tried. - Tested With: 1st gen iPad, 2nd gen iPad, iPod Touch 5G, Nexus 7 tablet, Nexus 10 tablet, Lenovo 10" Win8 tablet, Toshiba Win8 tablet, LG G Pad tablet, 3 different Samsung phones, 2 different LG phones, and a Sony phone. It charged all of them at least as well as their factory chargers. This was verified with a Legion USB Meter and, in some cases, also by other means.In practice it's really nice to just have one charger handy and you don't need to worry about what you plug into it, finding the right charger, the right cable, the right port, etc. It just works and fast charges when possible. The TechMatte is one of the only third-party chargers I've found, for example, that will properly fast charge my Nexus 10 tablet (made by Samsung). It loses a star for no UL Approval but that's my only complaint. I'll follow up if I encounter any problems with it.

The Legion is a nice device for a number of reasons. I've verified it's accurate to within a few percent using a high-end Fluke meter and it has a useful mAh (milli-amp hour) function that measures how much energy it delivers over time (something a lot of cheaper meters lack). This lets you estimate the battery capacity of a device. And, unlike the cheapo no-name Chinese designs, this device has very low insertion loss (the voltage drop caused by adding the meter into the USB circuit) which allows many devices to charge faster.Devices designed to charge at more than 0.5 amps, which includes nearly all tablets and most modern smart phones, are very sensitive to voltage drop as that's how they determine their maximum charge current. If adding a power meter causes even a few tenths of a volt drop under load, the charging current can be dramatically reduced. The same happens using cheap or long USB cables with thin gauge wire--something you can easily verify with this meter. The phone or tablet thinks the voltage drop is from the charging source being overloaded so it drops back to a lower charging current and the charging time becomes much longer.I like the fact this was a crowd funded project designed in the USA. It's also supported in the USA should you have a problem. Yeah it costs more than the no-name Chinese versions, but you really do get what you pay for.The Apple and Android modes, and the data on/off switch, provide additional options to help optimize the compatibility and maximum charging rates with various devices. If you already have a good smart charger, this device likely won't make any difference. But if you want to get the most out of a "dumb" charger, the options might help in some cases. And if you're using a PC port, or some sketchy public USB power port, disabling the data is a nice security feature.If you have a bunch of different USB chargers, and are not sure which ones go with what anymore, or which ones work best for a given device, the Legion will help you figure all that out.

This is a really nice charge-only cable and works as advertised. It has a soft rubber (possibly silicone?) covering making it more flexible than most and the red connectors help remind you it's a charge-only cable and won't work for data connections. It's a heavy gauge and charges at a higher current than lesser cables (tested with a high quality USB power monitor). The micro USB connector fits well without being too tight (risking damage to your device) or too loose (risking falling out).

These work as advertised and seem to be decent quality. They are charge-only cables so they allow some devices to charge at higher currents than they would using a regular data USB cable. The micro USB connectors fit well without being too tight (risking damaging your device) or too loose (coming unplugged to easily). I've had no-name USB cables suffer from both of those problems. For the geeks out there, I tested these with a high quality USB power monitor and they do indeed charge at higher currents than even some thinner charge-only cables I have.

This is hit or miss but mostly a miss. I tested it using two different USB power monitors and various cables on a half dozen phones and tablets. It does help non-Apple (and non-smart) chargers work well with Apple devices. My iPad refuses to charge at all with many USB chargers but adding this allowed it to charge at a high rate.With most Android devices, however, it usually didn't make any difference. And, on a few, like my Nexus 7 (1st gen), it reduced the charging current from 0.8 amps down to 0.5 amps making it charge significantly slower. It did nothing to help my Nexus 10 (made by Samsung), or Samsung phone, charge faster. Both charged at 0.5 amps with or without this device while both charge at much higher rates when used with their factory charger or a true smart charger.This doesn't turn a "dumb charger" into a smart charger like you might expect. You're better off spending a bit more and buying a decent smart charger with 2.4 amps.Unless you're specifically looking to charge Apple devices from non-Apple chargers, I wouldn't bother with this and consider trying a charge-only USB cable and/or a smart charger instead.

The product listing states: "Made of heavy duty materials featuring an extra thick ( inches, 6mm) cable, it PROVIDES A FASTER TRANSER RATE than most USB 3.0 data cables"Wrong! A heavier cable does NOT improve the transfer rate. A cable is either USB 3.0 compliant or it is not. The digital ones and zeros either make it to the other end of the cable intact or they don't. Thicker wire won't make those ones and zeros arrive any faster. It will either work, you'll get errors, your USB 3.0 device will disconnect, or it will fall back to USB 2.0 speeds. I wouldn't trust any manufacture making such false claims.

Beware these devices create a voltage drop and most USB devices designed to charge at more than 0.5 amps are VERY sensitive to voltage drops. That's how devices negotiate their max charging current. The "smart" chargers in the device (say a mobile phone or tablet) gradually draw more current from the charging source until the voltage drops below some preset value indicating the power source has reached its limit. They do this so they don't overload the charger or port either causing it to shut down or damaging it.A side effect of the way many devices negotiate their maximum current is any voltage drop from a long or thin cable, or a device like this one, will cause them to charge at a lower current than they otherwise would. To measure current there has to be a voltage drop. How big of drop depends on how well engineered the current meter is.This no-name generic Chinese meter is not especially well engineered. There are other reviews documenting it causes some devices to charge at half the current they do without the meter. That's because it has an excessive voltage drop.There's a YouTube video comparing this to several other similar devices done on a lab test bench. In general this fared relatively poorly both in terms of features and performance. The YZXStudio monitors are more expensive but offer a lot more features and lower voltage drop in their more recent models.So, in summary, a device might be accurate to a few percent in terms of measuring current. But with many USB devices, the voltage drop it creates is causing the device being charged to significantly reduce its charging current. So you end up with an error much greater than a few percent.

This thing seems like a bargain until you try to take real-world pictures with it. The auto flash E-TTL just doesn't work right in many situations. Some pictures are properly exposed and others are horribly over exposed with much of the image blown out. This happens even with the camera in Green mode. I'm guessing the flash is sometimes miscalculating and/or ignoring the distance the camera sends it. It seems to have a serious firmware bug with the E-TTL implementation (at least with my Canon T4i, T1i and 50D--it does the same thing on all 3).The flash is also awkward to even turn on and off. You have to press and hold the power button for several seconds. If you hold the button for a few seconds until the display turns on and let go, the flash turns right back off! You have to press and hold it until the display turns on and then keep holding while the flash does this useless little display routine that someone in China probably thought was cute for it to actually stay on. It's frustrating.Battery life seems fairly poor. The same NiMh batteries that recycle nearly instantly after 50 shots in my Metz or Canon flash are barely usable after 50 shots with this flash (the power on/recycling slows to 5 - 10 seconds). And it only sort of has auto-shut. It takes forever to go to sleep and it leaves an LED on and still seems to have significant battery drain even while "sleeping."The price is very attractive, and the build quality seems decent, but the implementation is half baked. I also had trouble with a Neewer and other Chinese clones. The only flashes I've found that work 100% correctly with E-TTL are Canon and Metz.

This is a decent keyboard. One big plus is it has a thin Li-Ion built-in battery instead of a big bulge on the bottom to hold replaceable batteries. That makes the keyboard much thinner and able to slip inside some tablet sleeves as well as take up less space in a backpack. It's also very light yet the metal back adds a nice solid feel. This is a good alternative to expensive OEM tablet keyboards/docks.The keys feels decent and it paired easily with my devices, It seems to stay connected just fine. It's nice that it's readily switchable from Android to Windows to iOS. You have to get used to waking it back up when it goes to sleep (to save the battery). It takes a second or two to re-pair with your device. I think all Bluetooth keyboards have this issue unless they stay on all the time requiring you to manually turn them off (which would make for much shorter battery life).I do sort of miss not having a laptop-style touchpad mouse. For just basic email, messaging, etc. you can just touch the screen but for doing more serious work it would be nice. You can always use a small bluetooth mouse but beware some of the best ones cost nearly as much as this keyboard and it's yet something else to carry around.I knocked a star off for the cramped layout which slows down typing (but is still vastly faster than any on-screen keyboard). They would have to make the keyboard bigger to fix this issue and that's a trade off. It also sometimes drops keystrokes but not often enough to be a big problem.

I used this to pull the bed bolts on a pickup truck that required using a long cheater bar for extra torque. I was worried I was going to either break the socket bit or even the 3/8" drive post on my breaker bar. But it worked and the bit itself still looks great. It must be seriously hardened tool steel. If you're looking for a T55 bit for a pickup bed, I would suggest a brand name 1/2" drive impact bit and consider using a heavy duty impact wrench. But this one worked for me with some penetrating oil and lots of muscle.

The factory Ford tool is stamped steel with four snug fitting prongs so it can't rock back and forth on top the fuel pump "jar lid" like this one does. This tool is nicely rigid but only has two prongs and the slots are much too wide.No matter how I adjusted this tool, I couldn't apply enough torque to loosen the ring without it slipping off the plastic tabs (with potentially devastating results to your hand on the wrench if you're working in close quarters). After many attempts I finally used a hammer and large flat blade screwdriver to "tap" the ring loose. That turned out to be much easier (just don't break the plastic ring). You can tap it loose far enough to just use your hand to take it off making this tool unnecessary.I tried this tool on a Ford Ranger pickup and it might work better on rings with a different shape and different tabs. The Ford ring is strongly rounded on the sides so there's little vertical surface along the edge of the ring to stabilize this tool.

This pump was less than half the best price I could find on a factory (Ford/Mazda) pump and less than a third of what most shops wanted to charge. It even says "Made In The USA" on the top! It fit fine and, at least so far, seems to work fine. I took 1 star off because Airtex claims they supply new clips for the fuel lines with their pumps, and they're shown in the picture, but mine didn't have any. I took another off as the pump itself was loose in the Airtex box with just some plastic air bubble bags for protection. Amazon just threw that box in bigger box with no packing material at all. My pump arrived with the vapor trap at the top dislodged but I was able to snap it back into place. It's surprising the float sender mechanism wasn't damaged.Time will tell if I have any problems with this pump. But at least it's from a US company that specializes in fuel pumps, is made in the USA, and Airtex claims to be the largest aftermarket supplier. With Amazon's price nearly as cheap as the "no name" Chinese pumps it's likely the best choice. A mechanic told me the more expensive aftermarket pumps, from companies like Delphi and Spectra Premium, are often made by Airtex.EDIT June 11th: Even with the tank completely full the fuel gauge only reads about 95% of full. With the factory pump/sending unit the gauge would be slightly above "F" with a fill-up. Now it's just under the "F" on the gauge. There's at least one other review of Airtex pumps mentioning this issue so it seems their float or sending unit is a little off. It's not that big of deal but it's something to be aware of.For anyone replacing this pump on a Ford Ranger or Mazda pickup, it's usually easiest to remove the bed (or remove the bumper and rear wheels and slide it back) to gain access. You're much more likely to break the fuel line connectors if you try to drop the gas tank without the car on a lift, a transmission jack to hold the tank, and knowing exactly what you're doing as you can't really see the connectors. New fuel lines are hundreds of dollars from the dealer. There's a YouTube video of a guy who broke his trying to drop the tank.The bed is surprisingly light. One person can lift one side of the end of it. The hardest part are the six T55 bolts holding the bed to the frame. You'll need penetrating oil, a strong Torx bit (I bought the OTC 6111 here but a 1/2" drive would be even better), and likely a cheater bar or serious impact wrench and impact bit.I needlessly bought the Great Neck OEM 25156 Fuel Pump Module Spanner Wrench but it didn't work. The only way I could loosen the "jar lid" holding the pump in place was with careful and patient use of a large flat blade screwdriver and a hammer. You don't need any fuel line disconnect tools for this pump. The two vent tubes use clips that you VERY carefully pry out to avoid breaking them. The two high pressure supply and return lines you release by pressing IN on what looks like a "horseshoe" tab that's tempting to pry out.

It's hard to find mats in this size and shape besides those for industrial use and battle ship gray or some other unfriendly color. This ones looks nice, blends in, seems very durable, and is firm but provides a welcome thick cusion. The beveled edges work well to help prevent tripping over the edge. So far, after a few months of use in a kitchen, nothing has harmed it or failed to clean up with a simple wipe of a damp cloth.

Lew Wallick was a well known figure in Boeing's heyday when test pilots were part cowboy. This book tells a fascinating story from the unique perspective of his daughter. It's a worthwhile read for those interested in Boeing and/or the development of modern commercial passenger jets.

Insteon wall switches have a horrible reliability record. I installed over 50 of them and I'd say roughly 10 fail per year. Even some of the replacements have failed. It's a huge hassle to turn off the power, pull all the wires out of a multi-gang switch box, replace the switch, get everything stuffed back into the box (as Insteon switches are rather deep and bulky and leave little room for the wire nuts, etc.), only to have to do it all over again a year or two later. Insteon just doesn't care about quality.It's also worth knowing these things run warm even when the light is turned off. They draw a few watts of power even when "off" which may not sound like much but each watt is about $1 worth of electricity per year. So if you have 50 of these in your house, they're wasting $100+/year in electricity compared to conventional switches/dimmers. It's yet another example of Insteon cutting corners.It also sucks they keep changing things like the color temperature and brightness of their LEDs (or they simply buy whatever LEDs are cheapest that week). So you have 3 Insteon dimmers/switches ganged together, and after two have failed, they all look radically different. One is dim and warm white. One is a super bright bluish white. And the other is a medium bright sickly greenish white. The end result looks pretty sad for $150 and only highly just how cheesy these things really are.

This is a marginally better bulb than the Lemonbest 9W PAR20 but that's not saying much. It's closer to warm white than the Lemonbest, and has a more uniform beam pattern, but it's still more of a spot light than a flood light and it doesn't dim very well. I tried it with 3 different dimmers, including an expensive Lutron dimmer specifically designed for LED lamps, and it flickers badly below about half brightness. If you don't mind a narrow beam pattern, and you don't want to dim it, it's a decent bulb for the price. Otherwise spend more on something better. This is basically a cheap Chinese no-name bulb.

This is a pretty sad generic Chinese no-name bulb. This bulb's a Lemon and there's nothing "best" about it. Not only does it lack any sort of safety certification (like CE, UL, CSA, ETL, etc.) but there's NO PRINTING AT ALL on the bulb--not even a model number! It doesn't match any "warm white" 2700K or even 3000K or 3100K LED bulb I've encountered. It has a rather greenish/blue tint. It also isn't really a "flood" as advertised. It's more of a spotlight and doesn't even have a uniform beam pattern. The 3 non-diffused LEDs cast a rather blotchy beam that sort of looks like 3 cheap LED flashlights sorta pointed in the same direction.Ultimately, with no safety certification at all you have no idea if this thing is going to catch fire and try to burn your house down. And even if you're not worried about that, the color and beam pattern are very inferior to other PAR20 bulbs. So unless price is your only criteria, I'd stay away.

This flashlight doesn't compete with a $30+ Fenix or other similar "tactical" LED flashlights, but for the price, it's a good value. The best part, unlike many similarly priced LED models, it has a simple ON/OFF switch. You don't have to press the button 4+ times to cycle through bright/normal/dim/blink/etc when you just want to turn it on or off. The beam is a good mix of spot and wide. It's also harder to misplace than the little black slender flashlights. If you're not looking for small size, maximum lumens, or to drive over it with your car, you can buy three or more of these for the price of one higher end flashlight. And it's a much better option than the similarly priced Chinese no-name flashlights that fail after only a few uses.

Intuitively one would think the gas valve in a gas dryer would either work or not. But apparently it's relatively common for these coils to somehow become "weak" and they only work some of the time. The result is the dryer gets warm but not as hot as it should and drying times are much longer.These non-OEM replacement coils fit and worked perfectly. They fixed my dryer. I did, however, knock one star off as the vendor (Appliance Parts Stop aka Pricelesssupply) claimed "same day shipping before 3pm" but took an extra day to ship the order.It's easy to confirm if these coils are likely the problem with your dryer. If the ignitor ever glows but there is no flame it's likely there's a problem with the gas delivery. And these coils are the most likely problem that will keep the gas from flowing. If replacing them doesn't fix the problem, and the ignitor is glowing, you likely have a gas supply problem or need to replace the entire gas valve.

The Kaito KA1102 is one of the least expensive shortwave receivers than can receive SSB but its performance is so poor I can't find any SSB stations to receive--even the huge high power ones like W1AW. It has a hard time even receiving any of the WWV time stations which even much cheaper radios can receive. Perhaps I got a lemon as there are many reports of Kaito quality control being poor.The user interface is also far from intuitive. Without the manual you'll have a hard time with this radio as several abbreviations and button functions are neither typical nor obvious. If you use it regularly I'm sure you'll get used to it but for occasional use you may need the manual. Such quirks like SSB only working on "bank 9" and even selecting "bank 9" are not obvious.The build quality is also rather poor. The buttons feel cheap and sometimes require a second push to even work. It looks and feels like a radio that should cost half as much. I wouldn't expect it to be very rugged or long lived with much use.The reception and sensitivity are marginal at best. With the built-in antenna fully extended the radio is mostly deaf from 3 Mhz to 20 Mhz. With the external wire antenna you mostly get more noise rather than more listenable signals. The AM radio band (0.5 - 1.6 Mhz) is decent but the AM/FM Sony ICF38 does better for less than half the price of the Kaito with much longer battery life (but doesn't have shortwave).Ultimately you do get what you pay for. The Tecsun radios are made in the same factory as Kaito and they likely suffer similar issues (at least at this price level). Both are examples of products designed in China to be as cheap to make as possible and it really shows in the KA1102. There are better choices from Sony, C. Crane, Eton, Grundig and Sangean but they cost more if you want SSB.

I read an article about how the founder of GoPro is now a billionaire. Perhaps his obscene wealth reduced his interest in offering quality products and acceptable customer support?I'm on my second GoPro Black Edition and both have suffered many of the same problems well documented here and elsewhere. Most notably it randomly kills its own battery in a very short time sometimes even while powered off. Some of the problems render the camera unusable in the field and are simply inexcusable. A lot of videos one uses a GoPro for are one-of-a-kind opportunities. I've already missed several with my Hero 3 as it didn't work when I needed it.Worse, instead of admiting there are serious problems, GoPro's support walks you through the same things most of us have already done (firmware updates, removing the battery, etc.) claiming they will fix the problem when they don't. They have to KNOW those things won't fix the problem, especially when a customer has tried them already, but they lie to you. How sad is that?It's one thing for a company to rush a product to market half-baked and full of bugs. It's even worse to pretend nothing is wrong when there's overwhelming evidence to the contrary. The Hero 3 debacle will tarnish the GoPro name forever. As many others have done after having their Hero 3 fail, I've given up on GoPro and plan to buy a similar product from another camera manufacture.

Most of the negative reviews of this charger are because people were expecting a fully automatic "smart charger" which is unrealistic at this price. But, the good news is, if you have overnight to charge you batteries, most don't need a smart charger. This is a "trickle" charger and, while it takes longer to charge your batteries, there's little risk of leaving the batteries charging for up to several days at a such low rate (for those who don't believe this, check the battery manufacture datasheets). It also won't cause your batteries to heat up, shortening their life, like a fast charger will.This charger is also UL listed, which is more than you can say for most of the no-name Chinese chargers being sold. Look up "fire" and "battery charger" on Google to see what happens to some no-name chargers that are not UL (or TUV, CSA, ETL, etc.) listed. To me it's not worth the risk of burning the house down. The no-name Chinese brands have little to lose and everything to gain from selling the most cheaply made products possible. While Lenmar has a significant US presence and can be held liable if one of their products causes property damage if it's poorly designed.Finally, this charger is small and doesn't need a power cord or wall transformer like many do. That makes is much easier to travel with. You can't beat it for the price.

First the good news, these drives are really quiet and run relatively cool. They are also one of the least expensive 3 TB drives currently availble certified for use in some NAS models. At least with my shipment, Amazon seems to have (finally!) improved their shipping packaging for hard drives. Mine came double boxed.But the bad news is Western Digital quality control seems to either be nearly non-existant or they simply have cut too many corners with their latest large drives. I purchased four and one failed after only a month. You don't have to search very far on the web to learn many people are having problems with the 3TB Red drives. There are reports of people using these in NAS and other RAID arrays and, while they're waiting for one failed drive to be replaced, another drive fails which means they lose all the data in the entire array. Ouch!There are now only a few companies left making hard drives. It seems with little competition quality is no longer a priority. This is really sad considering how catestrophic data loss can be. I suggest doing lots of research before buying any Red drives. Check the reviews on Newegg for example and look for verfified purchases. WD seems to be rather active in "managing" reviews. It's too bad they don't put a similar effort into making better drives.

For under fifty bucks this thing is a relative bargain. The important thing with a portable TV is the reception. If you can't receive digital TV stations little else matters. The old analog stations are no longer broadcasting in most areas which means portable TVs without an ATSC tuner are nearly useless. This one has an ATSC digital tuner.I live about 5 - 10 miles from most broadcast stations and, with the built-in antenna, this TV did a decent job with most of the stations. The picture and sound are not great but good enough for occasional use. I also like that it has a video input which some of the cheap TVs don't. And the battery pack is removable which should help it stay charged if you don't use the TV for longer periods of time.

The good news is this charger folds up fairly small and is fairly light. It will charge many devices (albeit very slowly) even in overcast conditions. It's the only solar charger of this type I've tried that is at least semi-usable in less than bright sunlight. That's important--especially for emergency or other unplanned use when you can't always count on good weather.The bad news is I can see how some have received DOA chargers or had them fail. They unit uses very cheap looking solar cells and I can see how they may fail either from shipping damage or even just handling. If you put this in a backpack and carried it around for a few days it might not survive. Unlike cells with glass panels and rigid frames, the soft nylon folding case doesn't provide much protection for the cells.Many who have reported measuring the output of this charger, and  other solar chargers, don't seem to know how to measure solar output. You can't just measure the voltage with no load and measure the current into the near short circuit of a DMM as neither is realistic. Instead, you have to measure the voltage and current while it's operating with a realistic load. Measured in this way, this charger does a respectable job for its size and weight.

It's shameful TCP markets these bulbs as they do. It also seems at least some of the InstaBright line has been discontinued. Perhaps their poor performance is why?Like others here, these bulbs initially were brighter when first turned on but they quickly degrade after even 1% of their claimed lifespan. They also have shifted in color temperature to a less pleasant greenish hue. And, perhaps worse of all, I had one of three bulbs work for only a few seconds when it was first turned on and then fail completely. Of course it costs nearly as much as the bulb is worth to send it back for a replacement. I'm saving up TCP bulbs that failed prematurely and already have half a dozen to send back.Of course TCP also sells "fresh" (Ti) bulbs they claim clean the air! Their next bulb will probably claim to cure cancer. Other tests and reviews have shown their CFL bulbs have nowhere near the average life they claim. In short, TCP seems to be 90% marketing hype. Buyer beware.

The Kaito KA1102 is one of the least expensive shortwave receivers than can receive SSB but its performance is so poor I can't find any SSB stations to receive--even the huge high power ones like W1AW. It has a hard time even receiving any of the WWV time stations at 5, 10, or 15 MHZ which even much cheaper radios can receive. Perhaps I got a lemon as there are many reports of Kaito quality control being poor.The user interface is also far from intuitive. Without the manual you'll have a hard time with this radio as several abbreviations and button functions are neither typical nor obvious. If you use it regularly I'm sure you'll get used to it but for occasional use you may need the manual. Such quirks like SSB only working on "bank 9" and even getting to "bank 9" are not obvious.The build quality is also rather poor. The buttons feel cheap and sometimes require a second push to even work. The fit and finish are sloppy. It looks and feels like a radio that should cost half as much. I wouldn't expect it to be very rugged or long lived with much use.The reception and sensitivity are marginal at best. With the built-in antenna fully extended the radio is mostly deaf from 3 Mhz to 20 Mhz. With the external wire antenna you mostly get more noise rather than more listenable signals. The AM radio band (0.5 - 1.6 Mhz) is decent but the AM/FM Sony ICF38 does better for less than half the price of the Kaito with much longer battery life (but doesn't have shortwave).Ultimately you do get what you pay for. In my experience the Sony SW7600GR, and shortwave models from Sangean, C Crane, Grundig and Eton all outperform the Kaito, are easier to use, and have much higher build quality (but do cost more). My Kaito is marginal Chinese designed junk.Tecsun is made in the same factory as Kaito and they likely suffer similar issues (at least at this price level). Both are examples of products designed in China to be as cheap to make as possible and it really shows in the KA1102.

I give 5 stars because it does what it's supposed to. It was too much for me. I felt a 'boost' during the day but then had problems getting to sleep that night.  Perhaps a more active person would not have the sleep problem.I gave them to a friend.It works too well for this old guy.

My Doctor and I have allergies and he takes one of these a day and recommend I do also.  They don't dry me up completely but do seem to help a bit. I suppose it's something that may vary person to person. A very tiny pill with no taste and easy to take.I dump them all in the same bottle for a years worth.I'm happy with these and Members Mark.

I was skeptical about this as I knew very little about it so did some Internet research.I first applied to an annoying 'bump' that was only slightly mildly painful but not inflamed on my hand. I had trouble keeping it on the hand so I used a small band aid for about a week and removed it deciding nothing was going to happen.  In a day or so the 'bump' was no longer mildly sore, dried and was easily scratched off. Been weeks and no return of the 'annoyance'.Only problem with the black gooey stuff is the smell! It is strong, kinda like an automobile tire shop X100. It smells like coal tare.  I'll only use this when I'm not around people for a few weeks.It seems to work great if ya can get past the smell,

I have a 1Gb home network and one of these is 90 feet and works fine to a router extender. They fit under doors and windows which is the attraction for me. I have no Power over Ethernet items so a small works works for me.I use the 5 to 90 foot cables.  One end of some of these end up outdoors.Very happy

I carry a 'Jitterbug Plus' clam shell cell phone in my pocket because it's rugged and I'm, well...  old. I'm always worrying about loosing it so this attached to a 'belt loop' and no more worries. At night Just press the button to remove and plug the phone in the charger. I leave the Lanyard out of the pocket to remind me to get the phone. LOL  Y'all will get old some day. :-)No way would I carry this around my neck (vanity I guess) BUT in the pants pocket is just the thing!Love it...

this is not a 'smart cord' with remote buttons. It's simply a 12 foot power cable and exactly what I wanted to plug into a 12volt AC brick supply for use in the house.Yep 'sometimes' radars are left on in squad cars and it's amazing to hear it squawk when one drives into my cul-de-sac. Put it in the window and forget it.Very happy.

Been using this for about a year twice a day before a meal. It does keep ya very 'regular' almost clock work regular.Taste is fine, clean up any spills before it gets gooey.  I have no way of knowing about other health benefits but I 'feel better' when I'm taking it. I know that sounds strange but it's the truth. I only use half as much as recommended so play with the quantity.Hope this helps ya, I'm quite happy and will always keep it around for daily use.

Been a Swiss Miss fan for decades. I decided to try the advantages of "Dark Chocolate".  The taste is rich and fatalistic.Very happy I purchased this. Now if I could just get some tiny marshmallows before the Indiana Winter....

I really didn't expect this to be as good as old pink Bepto B. but it is and in a small tablet. I don't handle really hot spicy foods late at night but taking one tablet with the meal eliminated my late night acid reflux problem.I still keep a bottle of Pepto Bismo around but these small tablets are so handy, small, no taste or black tongue!I figure if the esophagus is inflamed a liquid Pepto coating may help, otherwise these are a great 'preemptive strike' and put a few in my keyring pill caddy if I'm out and about.Super great product that I will have around 'forever'.

Home was re-roofed and roofers did not cover the grass completely with a tarp. I knew those large head roofing nails would find their way into my car tires. I purchased this magnet and another 'heaver' one that was rated 5 times more powerful.  After the roofers went over and over the yard with their wheel mounted magnet I tried this one with a metal detector. I was so happy and stopped using the detector and just stayed with this magnet. Try do do this when grass is short and soon as possible after re-roofing. I found another 24 nails. You can feel them attach to the magnet (actually 3 magnets) with a satisfying 'click' sometimes 3 nails at a time. I suspect it wouldn't be as good if the nails were imbedded in the dirt but in the grass out sight it worked fine.Very pleased with this product and heck, may even go meteorite hunting now... :-)

10 power and stabilized. Yes, you press and hold a button (top middle) to stabilize the image and release it when not needed. Stabilization is quick and the press to hold button saves battery life.  You can still see fine and use them as regular binoculars with out pressing the stabilization button and I like having a choice. One tip, use the stabilization when you Initially adjust your right and left eye once. It's easier than non-stabilized.Love these things for bird watching!
Stretch it out (if needed) and plug in all those dang wall warts that hog outlet space.Very happy with these and will probably go with a 3rd order!
I like this but had hoped it was less powerful.  I over sprayed the trash can and the entire house reeked of the smell.Yes it works but a small amount goes a long way.Happy with this purchase.

I only needed 2 of these as no skid feet for my laptop but I'm glad I have so many as I'm look for new uses for them.Limited only by your imagination!  Pull off the protective back sheet and post them where ever as bumpers, stoppers, write on them, etc.Very happy.

Unscrew the factory lens (CCW), remove the plastic lens shad on the lens front because you will need it on the 9821W. Once focused, drop in the lens shade over the new lens to prevent the IR lights hitting the lens. I sprayed mine black and used two 'very small' dots of rubber cement to keep it from blowing away. It also reduces the opening for insects. I love it and want more.UPDATE: On my FI9821W it improved edge to edge sharpness. It seems better than the Foscam factory lens. Remember to pull off the lens shade and put/tape/glue it to the camera over the new lens for IR protection.I just ordered more for all my Foscams.

I use this as a backup for my Jitterbug Plus cell phone. I slip the extra battery in the belt loop of the case I have for the phone.  I put it in the phone to charge it and gave it a try first.The picture is of the front and back of one battery. You get one battery not two.I'm happy with this.
Well known tissue in a small soft pack. Ideal for pockets and car change slot or glove box.I put 'em everywhere. If someone asks for a tissue I give them a pack. Hope these are always available.

I liked the reach, I liked the hoop to hang it but wish the sponge was softer and I'm a man but still would like it larger and softer. The sponge is synthetic perhaps that's the problem?HOWEVER...The main complaint on this first day is I have washed it 3 times and it still reeks like a '7 day old dead mouse'. I'm not kidding.  I rubbed a strong soap into it and let it sit for awhile but 'whew'...UPDATE: After soaking in soap for 24 hours the odor is gone. Now I can use this thing.
I use this on my Jitterbug Plus. It's a bit tight but does fit. Nice clip.I'm happy and recommend it.

It works exactly as I need for both boots and shoes. I was having a problem with arthritis and getting on a tight boot but this allows me st stay mostly upright with the 24 inch handle.Good idea and I recommended it.

Bought these because they were camo.They are camo but have a paragraph of text in I assume German and a Nazi swastika. It does have various other military emblems and U.S. Army but no way will I wear this with the that swastika. I did see the word 'holocaust' so I don't know if it's pro or against but doesn't matter with the 'eagle over the swastika emblem'. This is just too much for me. These go in the trash.Would NOT recommend these to anyone.

These come with a nylon? stitch reinforced belt bag that has enough room for other small items such as extra cell phone battery, etc.I wear glasses but prefer to remove them when looking through binocs to get the full field of view. To focus (the first time), close the right eye and focus with the center knob, now close the LEFT eye and adjust the right eye diopter. If you have perfect vision they will be the same. I did use a white marker pin to put a dot for the diopter offset for my right eye so I can quickly return it. I also put white dots on the focus knob and binoc body at 'infinity'.Love the view and as with any binoc you have to get used to finding the best settings and viewing distance for you. When all is adjusted I see only one big circle and can alternately close the left then right eye and all is in focus.There is NOT a threaded tripod hole, which would have been nice to have when I use a monopod stick for field use.Very light weight and very small even when NOT folded up.Some folks were asking about the minimum distance to subject and I can look out my windows and see the birds on my deck but I can't focus on the TV from where I normally watch it.  I got these for outdoor work and I'm happy with them.They have a rubbery feel and while there are NO lens  caps (which I usually end up losing) the lens barrel extends enough to protect the lens.I have every kind of binocs from giant astronomical to one eye 'slip in your shirt pocket' models.I'm very happy with this.

A little pricy but I love it! I found I could get about an inch of separation from the magnet and still work. I use Velcro tabs (from Amazon) for the main unit. You can just leave it mounted and pry open the cover to change the single AA battery but I'd rather just remove it first.  Right now it's linked to an LED Insteon light.  The unit does have an external sensor terminal. Exterior of case has a 'set button' which can also toggle the mounted unit on and off regardless of magnet position. A status led blinks on opens and closures then goes out. Only one AA battery powers the unit.Using Houselinc program you just drag and drop to link to devices and not need the computer (once linked) or use the computer program and make Insteon 'Actions'.If they were a little cheaper I'd buy a truckload.Happy with item.
Very nice classy container. Good for showing or protecting a item on the shelf and could be easily sealed if needed.

This may be a fine device if you have an 'X10 system' but not for me. I use a simple X10 hand controller, with 16 buttons to turn stuff on and off, socket rocket for bulbs and lamp modules and appliance modules, etc.I expected this to work the same way but it doesn't.  You can't press an 'on button' and have this go off. Instructions say to press 'on' then 'off' then 'on' again and keep doing this as long as you want the sound. Not something you want to do when you need an alarm.As far as the sound, it's not very loud, not to me anyway and I tested it sitting next to it. It's pretty high pitched and might drive a dog nuts but nothing like my Stadium 105dB air horn.  The unit would lock up and not turn on again even with the required commands requiring me to unplug the device and reinsert it for one more single toot then stop working again.I don't know if it's important but the word "PRO" is not on the module as it is with some other modules. It does say it on the box.No happy with this purchase.

These work to remove interference from going back into the power line.  I had a fan that would cause Insteon problems but this knocked out the electrical noise. Also have them on my UPS and computers.
I love these! Just peal and apply to anything. I put them on a security outdoor cam and made it hard to see.Kinda feel like the cloth bandades.

This is a very good Insteon 'only' controller. It can be programmed manually or even better by HouseLinc software (free).6 buttons depending how it is programmed. Makes a nice 'click' and a light flash when a button is pressed. I have the (top) of the first button to turn on my light dimmer and a quick click of the (bottom) down arrow to kill the light and 'HOLD' the bottom down arrow to dim. Nifty.I've had no problem with range. I takes 4 AAA batteries. Has a rubbery feel and non skid feet.  'NO' template is included so you can write you button names.  You use a piece of paper which is a kludge. It's not small but I like that making it easy to find. About hand size or slightly smaller.Outside of no templates the only thing I dislike is it will not send X10 signals so you may still need to keep your X10 controller.I like it and will get another on for the second story.

I replaced the porch light switch which was in a duplex plastic wall box. Kill the power and check by flipping the existing light switch and if you have a volt meter 'use it' to verify the voltage is off.  AC voltage in the home can give you a nasty shock and depending on your health and which wires you get across (and how) it 'could' kill ya so make SURE there is no power to those bare wires.Ok, I hope you've done something like this before.  The wires extend from the switch and must be twisted around the proper box wire and a 'wire nut' screwed in to each wire bundle to hold everything together. Make sure there are no power wires that are showing bare copper. Some of those wires can kill you and some of are totally safe. Know what you're doing.The only reason I purchased the non-dimming switch is because it's a relay and I learned the hard way in my old X10 system that when a bulb burned out it often took out the dimmer but not an 'off and on appliance relay'.  This is not a dual-band device(if you're wondering) but they still work nice.It was pretty tight in the box when I started screwing it together and was glad my switch box was plastic and not metal. Again don't leave copper wire exposed on the hot leads or they may short when you try to push it into place.  It took two tries because the wire nut came loose but once in place it's beautiful and works perfectly. I'm gonna try the dimmer switch next.If you're uneasy about doing this get or hire or beg a knowledgeable person to help, you don't want a shock or fire hazard.You can link direct to a hand held controller or in my case a Passive Infrared Motion detector.  This is the Toggle Linc Relay wall switch and has a max rating of 480 Watts.  The Toggle actually stays in the center and if manually switched you just tap the toggle up or down and it returns to center.  The main points are, this is a relay and is non-dimmable. There are 4 wires coming from the module that need connected to the correct box wires.I hope this helps...

After reading the reviews I decided to try this....Gag......Not funny, not exciting, graphics not that great little to no plot, what's the point?  I guess it's for the teeny boppers which I'm not. Give me Alien, Terminator, etc. etc and I'm happy. I've seen good animated Sci-Fi but this is just dumb.Oh, this was a 'free download' and I still feel it wasted part of my life.Ok, got it, stay away from the Red Vs. Blue so called chronicles.

I now have 4 of these. I love them.I have a mixed X10 and Insteon system in my home. These come with a mounting 'swiveling stand off' that I feel helps with the Radio Signal by giving some space between the unit and the mounting surface, especially if mounting on a metal surface. The internal antenna is not up against your metal siding as the old X10 units were.There is a variety of jumpers that set various things and all can be externally programmed by a computer EXCEPT the sensitivity setting. Default is high and you can lower it 33% if it triggers too much. One of mine is set to actually trigger at body movement 'across the street' while another is above the door and looking down to turn on light. At night it turns on a light if there is movement around my car.  As with all products go to Smarthome website (or just search) and download the PDF file that has a full set of instructions. You get a single 'quick start' sheet in the box but I like all the details. Remember to save those PDFs somewhere you can find later 'on your computer'.I use the HouseLinc (now free) program to set what it links to but once that's done you don't need the computer unless you really want to do some fancy programming with complex settings.  The battery operated PIRs are RF and not power line operated. They send all their signals to and from the PIR over the air and not the power line so they need to be in range of an access point. It is true that the more Insteon devices (the power line devices) you have the better because they retransmit the signals.  I can't encourage people enough to use one of the free computer programs to program and monitor your units, it makes life so much easier than going to each device and you don't have to dismount the device.They are easy to paint to make them stand out or hide them. I put a strip of electrical tape around the seams and stick in a small bag of 'silica gel' in a open apace under the battery, but that's just me doing over kill again.I am so very pleased with all the Insteon products. I can't wait to see how the handle the Winter.

Very happy with this. I plugged it into a GFI and programed it using HouseLinc software and have had zero problems. It's linked to a PIR. I'll wait and see how it manages in the Winter. It's under a shelf and out of direct rain, snow, ice...It's also "Dual-Band" which should help extend the range of my outdoor Insteon items.

I didn't really want all the bells and whistles this has, all I wanted was to plug it into my Ethernet pull up its interface page and give it the IPs of my camera and get composite video out to send to a DVR because it says "Support composite (RCA) video output to TV" . Nope, nada, it looks like it's not gonna happen.  I downloaded the required 'search' application and it found only the GXV3500 so I figured there must be 'somewhere' I can drop the IP (I know the IPs) of my camera into the interface. Nope.  Double clicking on the search result pulls up IE and displays a blue page of camera controls but nowhere to add a new camera.  My cameras are Foscam IP cams. The advertisement did NOT say Grandstream cameras only and that's very misleading.I reread all 9 pages of the simple instructions but still no where to put info about my Foscam cams.This probably works with Grandstream cameras but not Foscam.I'll give it about another day of bashing my head and searching the web and forums and will change my rating if something magical happens but I don't think it's gonna happen.Oh, so unhappy...

I'm quite happy with this, ESPECIALLY the rotating power plug. The power plug makes it possible to fit almost anywhere and provide another 2 outlets (3 total). The 1 Amp USB charging ports top it off and are located right where I need them. I also see they now have a newer version of this that charges at 2 Amps for those that need it.Good deal, good quality.

This has beautiful light (1100 Lumens!) and it looks better to me than a 100 watt Incandescent bulb.The only problem I have with it and it's a deal breaker (for me) is it knocks out my X10 and Insteon networks which are part of my home automation.  I tried it in two locations neither using X10 or Insteon modules just a lamp I plug into the wall socket, and when I turn it on the two mentioned networks no longer respond for the other lights, fans, etc. Only thing I can figure is that it must be generating so much garbage on the power line it over powers the remote control power line signals.I tried it in a typical lamp socket and when turned on there is no more control by the X10 or Insteon for ANY modules.  Turn the LED off and all is well and things works normal.Next, I plugged the lamp containing the LED bulb into an 'Insteon power Line Filter'. The Filter is designed to remove power line noise that would interfere with Insteon operation and that is exactly what happened.Using an Insteon noise filter on the lamp allowed the X10 and Insteon networks to function while the LED was on (or off). Remove the filter and when on it kills all the signals.It's a deal breaker for me because expensive Insteon devices are all over my home and the places I would use this (directional light) is in ceiling fixtures pointing down and I can't install filters without rewiring which I can't do because I rent.It was NOT on a dimmer Nor was it controlled by any type of X10 or Insteon  device.Too bad, I wanted it to work. This one bulb illuminated the entire kitchen perfectly. I don't know if the interference is a characteristic of all LED bulbs but I do have one LED Bulb made By Insteon that works fine but was not as bright as I needed.  I have a CREE 60W LED that I may try but it's also dimmer than I wanted but is more omnidirectional.This bulb is non-dimmable which is fine for me and has a whopping 40,000 hours life. The light is somewhat directional.I think this is a good light. Lots of beautiful light for very little power and if you don't have X10 or Insteon it may suit you very well. It is the brightest I could find.Update and change of rating after verbal abuse from company:Well Stevie, I tried it again and again it produced so much line noise it killed both my Insteon and X10 networks so I wouldn't exactly say that it "Easily replaces 100W Conventional bulbs in real life conditions" it dosen't. I tried it in a real life situation and it failed to works as a conventional bulb so get over it.  You really need to work on your people skills fella. You whine so much about a perfectly good 3 star rating (which means 'ok') It's 'ok' get it? It's not great, just ok but the company policy of harassing purchasers deserves a 1 star because I really dislike your attitude. Therefore I must change my rating and recommend everyone to stay away from you and this product.The bulb is going into the garbage bin as I have nowhere I can u

This is for a USB 3.0 hub but I'm actually using it in a USB 2.0 slot on the computer because there is another 3.0 hub using the only 3.0 port on the computer. (My computer has 1 USB 3.0 and 3 USB 2.0 ports, go figure.)That's fine as I have about twice as many items that are 2.0 than are 3.0 (Today anyway).  The cord is perhaps a foot and a half (i didn't measure it) but it's too short for my needs so I purchased on Amazon "Cable Matters SuperSpeed USB 3.0 Type A to B Cable in Blue 6 Feet". Note that one end is a 3.0 type A and the other is a 3.0 type B.I had a cheap 10 port 2.0 hub before with a tiny power supply and upgraded to this figuring future items will be USB 3.0 (and I'll have more 3.0 ports). There are 9 ports as stated and one 'Power only' port for 2.1A device recharging. I would rather have 10 ports available but I know some folks will have a use for the heavy duty recharging port.My only recharging is my Logitech headphone and it's recharging from one of 9 regular USB port.So, right now I have the stock 3.0 cable going into a female 2.0 jumper that goes to a 2.0 port on my computer.  This cable mess will be replaced by the above single cable.It has blue lights but at least they don't link.  The hub is now full with 9 USB 2.0 items and all seems to be working better than before.  I tried plugging it into my existing 3.0 hub but somethings didn't work properly (Headphones). The power supply is a big honk'n brick! 12 Volts and '5 Amps'!This was sold by AnkerDirect Via Amazon.I don't understand this statement: "For maximum performance devices connected to the 9 ports should not exceed 8 Amps (total)! Unless it's getting some current from the host computer I don't understand where the other 3 Amps are coming from unless the power supply is actually rated higher than stated. (I wouldn't count on it.  Most of my 2.0 stuff is off most of the time and are connected just for convenience for when they're needed. Of course the rating was '12 Volts' (not the usual 5.0 volts) at 5 Amps and that would be 60 Watts total, perhaps that's where the extra current is coming from as a result of the voltage step down? It could just be magic. They did say 8 AMPS Max! Wow!Anyway,I arrived a day early, worked exactly as stated, not even hot but does have a short (for me anyway) connecting cable. The connecting cable from the hub to your computer HAS TO BE USB 3.0 and a 2.0 cable is not going to mate at the hub (mine didn't).Built in surge protection.Happy and would recommend this and hope the review helps with your decision as it is a bit pricy.  If it goes West (dies) I'll update this review.

150 Watts of raw power! 2,440 Lumens, that a LOT of light. Lights up my barn!The way things are going I'll stick back a few of these for outside lights because I figure they will be banned in the US eventually.  It's hard but not impossible to get a 100 Watt Incandescent bulb now.

Works fine and holds well and for the most part waterproof or at least water resistant.Only 'cons' are, the bottle is stiff and hard to press the glue out the tube.  I noticed some glue sticking 'inside' the bottle that 'might' eventually have to be removed if it starts blocking flow.  Nifty cap just kinds clicks in place and the entire two piece cap has a 'reverse thread' if you really need to get inside.My only other question is, now that I've used it a few times and sucked air back into the bottle how long will it remain good.I still remember those tiny metal tubes of "Super Glue" that you used and a month later the remainder was dried out.Only time will tell and it's still good after a few weeks of light use.I'm happy and hope this helps you in decision making.UPDATE a few weeks later:Still happy with this product but continue to have difficulty squeezing the bottle. Someone with stronger hands probably would have no problem. I just unscrew the tip and stick a screwdriver in to get a bit and use the screwdriver to actually apply to glue exactly where I want it. The glue just wipes of the screwdriver with no problem. I kinda like it that way.Some will shake their heads with my latest use. My laptop has a USB port that goes to a 7 port hub and external USB drives among other things. The connector and socket on the laptop would lose connection from time to time as I moved the laptop on my lap (It's a laptop) thus causing all kinds of serious issues with the external drives. You probably know where I'm going with this. :)  I cleaned the connections, plugged in the USB cable and put a bead of this glue around the plug much as one does 'caulking' in the bathroom and let it set overnight.  It solved my problem and has a slightly soft feel when pressed with a fingernail so I figure a bit of solvent and a screwdriver will pry it out again if I ever need to remove it. DON'T get glue 'inside' the plug or jack just the outside.  Remembering the days of serial ports and monitor connections where real screws or wire clips held the plugs in place I wonder why 'something' similar wasn't used with USB.  Oh well, sounds crazy but solved my disconnections and Windows sounding warnings and going bonkers.  As said before this stuff goes sets up clear and is slightly 'springy' not brittle.Yeah, he glued his USB connection to his laptop, must be crazy. :-) Out of the box thinking.

I was having battery problems with the battery status not showing and assuming it was LOW. I replaced the battery and had the same problem. I discovered on my ASUS when I used a USB '2.0' hub everything worked fine including all the headphone buttons such as volume, next song, etc,' When On a USB '3.0' hub the phones 'audio' worked both wired and wireless but NOT the battery indicator or the volume roller or next song.I never tried it on a USB 3.0 jack on the computer as everything I have is run through two hubs, one a USB 2.0 connected to USB 2.0 on the computer and the other a USB 3.0 connected to a USB 3.0 port on the computer.  The erratic behavior was me for various switching the headphones USB hubs. Now that is running on a USB 2.0 hub everything works including all the buttons switches, charging and battery status.  Would it work on 3.o on the computer? I don't know but moving back to the 2.0 fixed my problems.Too bad I threw away the original battery as it was dated this year and just wasn't registering properly. I can't take credit, I read that keyboards, headsets, mouse, pointers, etc 'MAY NOT' work on a USB hub if they were were designed for 2.0.Live and learn.Been using this for several Months now. I still love the headset as it provides a deep richness to music and videos and the voice changer is cute on Skype. Now I have all my buttons back.I highly recommend it but if it only 'partially' works on USB 3.0 switch over to USB 2.0. As I said I did NOT try USB 3.0 directly on the computer (no hub), it may work tat way for you.Bottom line works fine on a USB 2.0 hub.Only the sound works on a USB 3.0 hubLive and learn. So much for backward compatibility.Hope you find my 'adventure' of help.

Arrived quickly and well packaged.  I use the houselinc program and it was instantly found and incorporated into my Insteon network. NOTE: The Insteon number is on the TOP of the bulb xx.xx.xxI purchased this mostly to play with as my aging eyes have little use for a regular 60 Watt incandescent bulb let alone something shaped like an ice cream cone.I tried it in the lamp next to where I read and as expected, the light was more toward the ceiling with a shadow under the lamp. The light is very directional so remember that. It would be better suited in a ceiling fixture or to replace a low powered flood light. I liked the color temperature and colors seemed fine but the slightly less than 600 lumans is a deal breaker for me. The houselinc program allowed it to easily link to a motion sensor and with a little experimenting I was able to have it on at 10% brightness and when motion was sensed go to 100% brightness then back to the 10% level after I left the room.I would have liked to used this in my porch fixture again running only 10% which is just enough to see the door address and then switch to full brightness when someone walked up.  It will do exactly that but it needs to be brighter, perhaps equivalent to a 100 Watt bulb and OMNIDIRECTIONAL. Don expect much light to be cast toward the threaded end.If I use it indoors it will have to be in a fixture where the top is pointing down.The base of the unit does get too hot to be comfortable when I touch it but that temperature quickly subsides when off (it's only 8 Watts!).All of this is pretty much as I expected and it's fun to play with but rather than purchase several of these for an array I'm waiting for a couple of non-dimming non-Insteon LED lights to arrive, one is a 100 Watt equivalent but again it has the 'ice cream cone' shape the other (CREE) has the correct spherical shape but only equivalent to a 60 Watt.Ok, time to put my CFL bulb back in my reading lamp and find some use for this as it's too expensive to not use.Oh, these are DUAL BAND (RF and Power line signaling) devices which are really nice if you want to place them some distance from the house.So, com'on Insteon make a 75-100 Watt equivalent omnidirectional LED bulb.I wish it was a lot brighter.UPDATE (out of box application): My house (I rent) has a dual head Motion detector. It was a pain trying to get the right wattage for each light. I needed different light levels for each lamp. I noticed I heard a 'RELAY click' when it detected movement so I put these Insteon LED bulbs in and it works! I can now change the level of each bulb. The bulbs 'remember' their last brightness level when turned off. When they turn on it's at that level but I can also change it with the Houselinc program for say when there is snow on the ground Vs green grass or adjust for best security camera light level while watching the camera!
