Tiki torches are for effect - not for light - and the effect of these solar tiki's is quite good.  I get up pretty early for work and I can STILL see the Tiki's flickering at 6 in the morning - not bad for something that runs off the previous day's sunlight.Now the bad - the torches are perched inside of a brittle/flimsy plastic and this same plastic is used to make the 3 piece poles.  I say flimsy and brittle because it looks and feels flimsy and brittle up close - from just a little distance it looks like bamboo.  In reality this "flimsy and brittle" plastic hasn't broken so I'm talking myself out of saying they're brittle and flimsy - but up close they just don't feel sturdy.Now the really bad: they come with black plastic stakes intended to insert into the ground - these things are USELESS.  Out of the 12, 3 immediately broke with the meager physical effort of inserting into the ground.  The solution: (a good solution, but with extra cost) Tiki makes tiki torch stakes made of sturdy metal.  We pounded these into the ground with a mallet and now our solar tiki torches stand nice and straight.  If not for the flimsy/useless plastic "stakes" I'd rate this with 5 stars.

Missile Commander was one of my favorite quarter arcade games 30 years ago. I've tried it on every platform since hoping to recreate the magic but a PC and phone can't replicate the roller ball and three button firing interface. This game gets it right. The graphics are updated and a tablet is the perfect touch and fire platform for me to defend my cities.

Amazon has scolded me for not reviewing this product within 30 days, but since one of the pre-eminent claims of these guitar strings is that they are "long-lasting" I felt justified waiting longer to see if they're as advertised.The good news: they are.Hardly any guitar strings don't sound good the day after they're put on.  And hardly any guitar players have the time or money (or free strings) to change strings a couple of times a week.  (If you're breaking guitar strings frequently - I recommend you check your technique for putting the strings on, or winding them or your playing technique.)So what do I look for in strings?First - the sound.  Almost all strings sound too bright and twangy when first applied.  Then they turn into... what?  Good strings mellow quickly into a wonderful, warm sound - what Eddie Van Halen called the "brown sound."  I think he said it was like the difference in the sound between hitting a block of wood and hitting an anvil.  Anyway - these strings sound good.Second - how long do they sound good?  As I said - most strings sound ok day 2.  But if you're not breaking strings often (and again - I can't emphasize enough that you SHOULDN'T be...) it would be awesome if your strings still sounded good months later.  I've had MANY name-brand sets sound just DEAD a week or two later.  The best strings still sound warm and powerful after many months.  These strings are two months old - haven't broken, and still sound excellent.  Recommended.

Amazon has gotten on me because I had not yet reviewed this product which they sent but - since the purpose of the product is to prevent weeds it would be (in my humble opinion) pretty difficult to determine whether or not this product actually does what it's supposed to do in less than the time-limit of 30 days.The good news:I treated half my lawn with Concern Weed Prevention and half with a standard commercial product.  We live in an area that would acquire a collection of dandelions and milkweed over an untreated summer.Both sides look good - and since the "plus" on Concern 97181 is that it is "natural" and non-toxic and made from corn gluten that is safe for people and pets - I can recommend this product if natural and safe are part of your concerns in weed prevention.

You wouldn't be here if you didn't like your auto to look its best, and Griot's Carnauba Paste Wax makes the shiniest gloss I've ever seen.  My FAVORITE part of car waxing is seeing water bead up and run off of it with the next rain storm and Griot's is AMAZING.  I have no idea what ingredients make this more hydrophobic than the other waxes I've seen or used - but with Griot's it's almost like there is a "force field" around the finish that not only repels water but keeps it from even touching the car in the first place.  You kind of have to see it to believe it.  Recommended!

I haven't been able to talk NASA into sending me into space so that I can test Pilot's claim that this pen writes under "all conditions".  They claim also that the pen can be dropped into water and it will float - I tested this and, indeed, it did float - and wrote afterwards.But I haven't yet been to space and I don't recall any time in my 50 years that I needed to write something over water.  I would imagine that if you were a fisher-person.... with a slow or stationary boat - and you wanted a pen that you could retrieve when you had one of those "darn it!" moments and dropped your pen overboard.But for every day writing - I like a pen with a little "heft" to it.  I want a pen that feels like there is something in my hand and then writes with a dark, fluid line.The same properties that allow this pen to float make it feel like a thin piece of plastic in your hand.  For the cost of one of these babies I can buy a 3-pack of much more substantial and comfortable writers.It does what it claims - but is that what you need?

Truth in advertising: I'm 50 years old and my brother and I grew up with prized Tonka trucks and construction toys.  The Toystate Caterpillar Dump Truck hasn't broken - but there is no way it is as durable as the good old Tonkas.BUT - for the bells and whistles generation that is our grandson's, this excellent toy has some features far outdistancing old Tonka.There are two key features for a toy dumptruck - it must roll, and it must dump.  This machine does both at the touch of a button.  (How cool is THAT?) Push a button - the dump bed lifts.  Another lowers it back.  One button starts the truck rolling forward, another puts it in reverse.  Sounds and lights enhance the effect.  The up-down-forward-reverse buttons are all on easy to read arrows.For children of the "toy dump truck" age - this truck and a backyard are all that are needed for hours of play.Enjoy!

I grew up as a reader in an era in which biographies were written in a way that grabbed my young brain and pulled me into the story.  This is not to say that Neal Thompson's book is not even-handed and well-researched or that it plays as fast and loose with "the facts" as did Ripley himself, along with some of his contemporaries such as Hearst or P.T. Barnum.  No, this gripping and ripping tale made me turn the pages until there were none left to turn.  Robert Ripley, in effect, never grew up, and he became an extreme proponent and made his fortune with a little old fashioned entrepreneurial spirit mixed with equal parts "reporting" and "pandering".  He traveled the globe looking at the "believe it or not" amazements of the world - and of history.  Initially he transmitted them to us in his wonderfully imaginative drawings, but over the years he had collected enough real-life oddities that he had to display them in his "Believe It or Not" Museums.Remember pulling into rest stops, hotel lobbies and restaurants along your way to vacations and seeing the display stocked with colorful leaflets begging you to go to THIS or THAT attraction?  SEE ROCK CITY!  VISIT CAPE CANAVERAL!  SEE THE GRAND CANYON!  The young version of me would pick up a dozen of the most interesting to read on the trip.  I never failed to pick up one for Ripley's museums.  (It seemed the cover always featured a "shrunken head" or some person with what seemed an obscene number of piercings on their face.)This is the book that tells about the man that sparked the imaginations of everyone who ever cared about that which was not commonplace.  And in a way - isn't that all of us?

The Mrs. and I now have four different feeders of different types scattered around our yard.  So far - this is my favorite and here's why.  We put up bird feeders so that we may see the little critters up close partaking.  This feeder is not only the most attractive of our four, but it is perfectly symmetrical, meaning that the square shape allows four symmetric feeding stations attached to U-shaped perches.  (The manufacturer states this U shape is preferred by birds, but I didn't ask any to confirm...) Our other "main" feeder is asymmetrical.  It's free to turn in the wind on it's hanger, and if it's not turned at exactly the correct angle, when birds come to feed, your view is obstructed.  What good is that?  The antique copper finish on this feeder looks attractive and the "all in one" design doesn't give me the chance to lose screws or bolts when cleaning the refilling the feeder.  A cable runs through the center of the feeder and through the antiqued copper lid/roof.  The roof simply lifts off the feeder - allowing you to access the inside easily - then the roof slides back down the cable to sit squarely on the feeder again.  Simply stated - it couldn't be easier to use.  At under 20 bucks I don't think you can find a better-looking and easier to use bird feeder.  Cheers.

This Jabra speakerphone does all of the things it wants to do - to some degree - but at one of its three most important tasks, it's noticeably worse than just using the microphone on the iphone.I was using it with an iPhone 4, and the audio I RECEIVED was excellent.  The device is also wonderfully compact - it comes with a padded case about the size of the palm of your hand, and the USB powering cable has a built-in wrap-around storage groove.  The Jabra is a nice, sleek, modern black, with LED lights to indicate battery charging, mute, volume control, blue-tooth connection, plus the simple green phone icon for making a call and the red one for hanging up.If the speakers on your laptop aren't particularly good, plugging the Jabra into a USB port improves the sound.  I was going to give two stars until I tried this function so I'm giving an additional star based on that alone.The problem is this: modern iphones and androids are so spectacularly versatile and useful that even my phone - two generations behind "cutting edge" had a microphone that worked much better than the mic on the Jabra.  In other words - having the Jabra set up in the center of a group gathered around a table may offer better sound for the people listening around the table - but the person RECEIVING your call will have noticeably worse audio than simply setting your cell on speakerphone and putting it in the center of the table instead.The Jabra LOOKS more modern and impressive... but the audio sent should be at LEAST as good as the phone by itself, shouldn't it?

I still remember Yahtzee games from forty years ago and the excited yell of anyone who rolled the coveted "Yahtzee" - five dice with the same number.Twenty years ago I bought a Yahtzee game for my own family - and it was just like I remembered it.  Which would have been fine for circa 1970, but in the video game era is frankly a little slow.  You wait YOUR turn while all the other players in the game take their three (or less) rolls of the dice.  There is a bit of strategy to it, but the degree to which blind luck determines a game was hammered home to me recently when I downloaded an electronic version of the game for a handheld device - not as fun as the game I remembered from my childhood.This new Yahtzee game adds action and excitement to the relatively stale concept: all players roll at once and an electronic button in the center of the playing board allows players to jump in and claim needed dice combinations.  This game keeps the best parts of old Yahtzee and adds needed excitement.  Good for old Yahtzee fans and anyone looking for an exciting dice game.

This Oster Electric Wine Opener has less "show" appeal than any opener I've seen - so if you like making a production showing off your skill with a corkscrew this kind of defeats the purpose.But that's not me so I'm glad for this opener.  For about ten years we've used a nifty device Vinotemp Cork Mate Wine Bottle Opener - VT-CORKSCREW that uniformly and easily removes the cork - but then you're left with the cork impaled on the screw and it's sometimes difficult to remove the cork.This device works slick as a whistle.  First of all - it comes with a seal-cutter to leave a nice even edge on the foil top to the bottle.  Then you just insert the top of the bottle into the opening on the bottom of this opener and press the bottom.  It whirrs and after a few seconds you can tell by the sound and feel that the cork is free.  This part only makes it as good as our previous opener - but THEN you push the button in the other direction, the opener whirrs and the cork is extruded back out the opening.Opening a wine bottle has never been easier.  Also costs substantially less than our admittedly still working fine Cork Mate - and don't know whether durability will become an issue.  I suspect the Cork Mate will still be working fine (nothing electric) long after the rechargeable battery on this Oster has given up the ghost.

This brush has several features that make it a full cut above any other Windshield Ice-Scraper/Snow Brush I know of:1. The sturdy and comfortable rubberized handle extends - not flimsily, but into an extended "locked" position.  This allows you to more easily reach the hard to reach places.2. The sturdy but soft bristles are attached to a head that swivels: you can use it like a "standard" snow brush, but you can also turn it 90 degrees and use it more like a snow "push broom".Ideal for auto users in snowy climates.

We received a bottle of this lotion as part of Amazon's Vine Voice program and the Mrs. and I both found it fine - the lotion is not greasy and creates a moist, smooth texture to our skin when rubbed in.  The smell is pleasant and mild.  We have our "favorite" lotions - there are several we like well enough that if they are available at a better price than competitors we will choose.  This "Pure Oat Extract Vaseline Total Moisture" goes onto our list.

First things first: I don't know whether this review will ever be (or stay) posted: at present the book is only available from 3rd party sellers at close to $100.  That's crazy.  (Amazon review reviewer - before you decide to delete this review, consider whether or not you want your company a party to blatant price-gauging.)  Hopefully the publisher will decide to offer the book directly on Amazon for a reasonable price.  I just got mine directly from [...] and paid only $34.99 for an autographed copy. ($24.99 without the signature)Now to the book:I must admit I was jealous when I first heard someone was undertaking the "definitive" biography of Tony Rice.  After trying (and failing, like everyone else) to PLAY like Tony, I began to consider myself something of a writer and was thinking about undertaking a project such as this myself.Thankfully, Tim Stafford and Caroline Wright beat me to it.  With unprecedented access and mandate from the man himself to tell it all - warts and all - the picture of one of the most gifted, imitated and mysterious figures of American music emerges.Presumably you know something of Tony Rice or you wouldn't be reading this.  He partnered with pretty much everyone in American string music from about 1970 to present, along the way acting as a central figure in the greatest Bluegrass Band in history (actually - in at least TWO of them)J.D. Crowe & The New South, Bluegrass Album as well as in two different string jazz bands. The David Grisman Quintet (US Release), Backwaters  His style was so ubiquitous for three decades that EVERY flatpicker copied him - then had to go to great pains to NOT copy him if they were forging the next frontier of acoustic guitar (such as Bryan Sutton).  Tony has maintained such an aura that if he is in a room of the biggest names of his business: Ricky Skaggs, Alison Krauss, Mark O'Connor, Chris Thile, Jerry Douglas - it is understood that Tony is the coolest cat in the room.  (Part of that aura is that while he was establishing himself as undisputed king of lead guitar he was also the undisputed lead vocalist of the era: in bands that included Skaggs, Krauss, Sam Bush, etc - Tony was always, without question, the lead vocalist.Krauss writes that when she received her platinum record for "Baby, Now That I've Found You" (the first platinum recording, I believe, in the history of Bluegrass) she sent the record to Tony and struggled over a typewriter trying to find the words to express her gratitude over his role in her development as a musician.  She wrote that tears flowed and when Tony received the letter he must have thought "what is this film doing on here...?"Simultaneously perhaps the most musically inspiring and least "knowable" figure of Americana, Rice comes alive in these pages, through his words and those of his contemporaries including all of the above, plus other seminal figures such as Bela Fleck and Emmylou Harris and Linda Ronstadt.The book closes with a comprehensive catalogue of Rice on over 200 recordings, plus a special section on Tony's famous guitar - the 1934 Martin D-28 - perhaps the most valuable acoustic guitar in existence.I'm no longer jealous - just happy and thankful that this book was made.  Thanks to Stafford, Wright, Tony and 40 years of musical memories.

Guitarists love and hate capos.  They let you adjust pitch so that you can play in weird keys without having to use weird chord shapes and fingerings, but it is incredibly difficult to get a good balance between "easy to use" and "holds the strings properly - without buzzing."  (Not to mention guitarists HATE it when pianists or non-capo users call the device a "cheater".  Hey - the best barre chords don't really give you as good of an E-flat as a good capo. But I digress.) The Planet Waves Capo does both - and well.  Previously marketed capos either held the strings tightly - such as the Shubb - I love my Shubb - inobtrusive and holds the strings securely right where I want it.) But the mechanism of the Shubb made it impossible to work single-handed (very important if you want to change position mid-song.) OR the easy to maneuver capo kept a weak grip on the strings - inviting buzz - and were usually large monstrosities that required awkward hand positions for some fingerings.  This capo goes to #1 in the rotation - it not only holds the strings well and is easy to reposition with one hand - it is easily adjustable so it will grip a narrow neck like my strat and a wider, rounder neck like on a classical guitar.  Steel string acoustics are perfectly held by the Planet Waves.  It's made of sturdy components and I expect it to last decades. Highest possible recommendation.

I am very pleased with this cable the quality is far better than some I have tried in the past. Some just aren't living up to quality standards. I knew when opening this one however I should be good because it came with a lifetime guarantee. I initially was  impressed what the overall durability,and overall quality of the charger you can tell they put effort into making it last.  The connection nice tight, secure connection when plugged in , I hate when charges fit loosely. I was very pleased to find this charges not just our iPhones and iPods but our iPads as well not all chargers will be supported but this one did. The cording seems better than most chargers I have tried I feel like it will hold up way longer than even the chargers that came with our devices originally. I was given the opportunity to test this charger to and give an honest review on, I wouldn't hesitate to buy another in the future, its high quality and backed by a guarantee.

My nieces love these metallic tattoos I was made aware by them that these are all the rage now that we have tried several packs and they are so fun. This pack by zip are a bit different then some others I have used with the girls the designs are very unique.  They feature  brilliant color that looks great on skin. The colors really look good when the light or sun hit them. These are so easy to use and all you need a little bit of water. These aren't your old school temporary tattoos, they are so much more unique. They ca make any outfit pop and feature chains and charms that you put together and create jewelry with. For such a great price you can afford to accessorize. Even better is they last a log time once applied. I was happy to try out this colorful pack of tattoos in exchange for my honest review, you cant go wrong with these.

I got this case along with a few others from Verus for niece to go with the new s6 she got for her birthday when it came. She is like the average teenage girl and loves to accessorize, she however goes as far as matching her phone cases to her outfits. When I knew she was getting the s6 I knew I had to go ahead and get her some cute cases to go along with it. Upon receiving the case I immediately noticed how high quality it looked and felt.I like how the case provides a little lip between both the screen and the camera lens to prevent scratching when placed down. It does great at protect against slips and drops. The slot are perfect size and it leaves plenty of room for the charger.Overall this is a great case and goes great paired with a screen protector. It is thin so it will slide into a pocket without adding to much bulk to the phone. I am grateful to have received the case at a discounted price in exchange for my honest evaluation this is a great case she loved it.

If you have ever like me find yourself out and about with a low battery, you can agree your phone dies at the most inopportune times. This case works wonders at preventing you from bring left with out a phone. It is two pieces that snap together to enclose your phone, at the bottom is the charging cable piece that connects into the charging port of your phone. The case itself is lightweight and high quality. It charges quickly and is ready to thrown on your phone and go. iIt is easy to use all you do is  press the  power button and charges your phone from zero in about an hour can't be beat . Overall this is a great case and you will be happy you have it. The only downfall is that it doesn't do anything to protect your screen, nor does it claim to but just a heads up I recommend buying a tempered glass screen to place on your phone for protection. I love that it has a kickstand it makes it great for setting on your desk and watching videos.I recieved this case at a discount to test and evaluate for review purposes, I am so glad I did!

These are the boys favorite they are the perfect combination of cheesy and spicy. They love the classic crunch of doritos combined with that punch of heat. They are spice but nothing drastic. These Spicy Nacho Doritos are a staple in the house.

This mp4 player is a great starter player who a younger kid who wants to be just like the big kids. Most kids these days know how to work all the latest technology but the younger ones aren't quite ready for the high price tag well known models. This is nice in the fact that it can play games and videos like the expensive versions, it also has a radio feature that has surprisingly great reception. I didn't realize it but my youngest discovered it even records ...pretty neat. It was very easy to load music to I made a file of kid friendly songs and then just drag and drop them onto the drive while the player is connected, doesn't get much easier. It also has a nice price tag, you can't beat the price for all it does. While I found this to be a great player there are a few small things that can be improved. The first is sound quality of the earbuds isn't the greatest and you will need to get a new pair. second the button functionality takes a it of getting used to. While both of these things were downfalls they are minor since the player itself functions great, it charges quickly and holds a charge rather well. I also found it to be quite a bit more durable for what I was expecting. Overall I am happy with the quality it was provided to me free for evaluation purposes, I am happy with it and would purchase again for a younger child.

This mp4 player is a great starter player who a younger kid who wants to be just like the big kids. Most kids these days know how to work all the latest technology but the younger ones aren't quite ready for the high price tag well known models. This is nice in the fact that it can play games and videos like the expensive versions, it also has a radio feature that has surprisingly great reception. I didn't realize it but my youngest discovered it even records ...pretty neat. It was very easy to load music to I made a file of kid friendly songs and then just drag and drop them onto the drive while the player is connected, doesn't get much easier. It also has a nice price tag, you can't beat the price for all it does. While I found this to be a great player there are a few small things that can be improved. The first is sound quality of the earbuds isn't the greatest and you will need to get a new pair. second the button functionality takes a it of getting used to. While both of these things were downfalls they are minor since the player itself functions great, it charges quickly and holds a charge rather well. I also found it to be quite a bit more durable for what I was expecting. Overall I am happy with the quality it was provided to me free for evaluation purposes, I am happy with it and would purchase again for a younger child.

Ive been told numerous times about how different wine smells and tastes when its been aerated; about how many reds, especially, benefit from a good decanting.  Being the only person in my household who drinks wine, a decanting an entire bottle wasnt a great option.  This small, portable aerator was the perfect solution.  And now I understand what a difference it really makes.The device is easy to use.  Simply hold the decanter over your glass, and pour the wine through.  Do make sure you position the bottle so that the wine hits the little umbrella within; thats pretty important to the way the wine filters down through the system.  Youll hear the aerator working as the liquid is forced through the tiny holes.  But more importantly, youll smell it working.  The fragrance of the wine is really brought out during the process, and you wont fail to notice it.  In fact, youll probably pick up on things you hadnt before (even in your favorite wines).As for the taste  I can only describe it as opening up the wine.  Nuances Id never tasted before are suddenly at the forefront. Its almost like a whole new experience. Ive used the aerator with cabernet, a red blend, a ros, and a sauvignon blanc so far.  Each wine has been one Ive enjoyed before, but I have made sure to taste the wine both before and after, and each time the difference has been remarkable.This particular device is small and portable, easy to clean and to store (with its own stand), and travel friendly (a carrying bag is included).  It is also reasonably priced on Amazon at $19.99.  I cant recommend it enough.  You dont have to be a sommelier or connoisseur to appreciate it!

Fish, Fish, Squish! is a board game for young children. It is designed for two to four players and those players should probably be very young children. The game box says "5+," but I would recommend 5-10 as the core age group. My wife, after having played a few rounds of Fish, Fish, Squish! declared it the stupidest board game she has ever played. She liked it even less than. the old 80s Garfield board game or Miskatonic School For Girls. She's more of a DC Heroes Deck Building Game kind of woman.  Again though, she's not the target audience for this release. I however thought the game was flawed but cute and that very young children could have a lot of fun with this in short doses.Fish, Fish, Squish! doesn't take much time to play. The box says 15-30 minutes but in truth it is about 5-10 minutes only. In fact, set-up time (especially for four people) probably takes longer than it does to play the game. Now, this isn't something like Ikusa or Cthulhu Wars where you have lots of pieces to set up. Fish, Fish, Squish! is actually pretty simple in this regard. Some of the time is spent shuffling the 54 card deck and then creating a 6x6 grid out of them. Yes, you will set some of the cards aside in case the game reaches its conclusion without a winner. The real block of time is spent molding your fish to squish! Fish, Fish, Squish! comes with four bags of extremely high quality clay. It's fantastic molding clay and honestly, it's probably worth the purchase price of the game. The game also comes with four resealable bags so once you open the clay from their original airtight packaging, it won't dry out as quickly. I should note that because clay does eventually go bad, this does mean Fish, Fish!, Squish! has a limited life-span. The good news is that it will take a long time for the clay to dry out (We're talking months/years) and by that time your kids will probably no longer care about the game.The game comes with four fish molds, all of which are exactly the same, but you get one for each player to shorten the setup time. You make five fish of your chosen color by putting the clay into the mold and then removing it. Without fingernails, it can be hard to get the clay fish out of their molds and trimming the lines off the figures once released can take time and be tricky  especially if you have anal-retentive children who want their fish to be perfect. So again, setup takes long than the time to play the game.Actually playing Fish, Fish, Squish! is short and simple. Each player goes (from youngest to oldest) and on their turn, they flip a single card from the 6x6 grid over. This continues until someone makes a three-of-a-kind. This does not mean that they have three of the same fish revealed, but rather a line of three different fish (yellow, red and purple). This line can be horizontal, vertical or diagonal. Once a player has made a line, they can squish one of the other players' fish. Lose all of your fish and you are out of the game. The winner is whoever still has a fish left at the end of the game. Pretty simple, right?Well, there are a few problems. The first is that with more than two players, you will almost always run out of cards in the 6x6 grid. Even with a two player game, that nearly happened every time. The game does have sudden death rules of "add another line of six cards to the board" but that doesn't mean even this will be successful.  You can end up having two or three sudden death lines (which uses all the cards) and have no declared winner. This is because of the randomization. Bad shuffling can end up with the cards not equally scattered across the grid, but with a massive clump of one color in a contained area. We saw it happen more than once. The randomness of the game not only increases the replay value of the game, but also can cause the game to be unbeatable  so to speak. This is a notable problem but one that can't essentially be solved because it really is just bad dumb luck when this situation occurs. Kids won't mind though, unless their fish squishing is down to a bare minimum. Perhaps it would be easier to make the game work as a Memory clone but with fish mashing. It wouldn't certainly remove the sudden death aspect that is often needed.Another issue is that some little kids won't process all the possible lines once the majority of the cards are revealed. Heck, some adults will have this problem. You will have three of a kind but a young kid might only be looking vertically or horizontally and forget diagonally. The good news is that the rules of the game note this and remind parents to help view all the possible outcomes that occur when a card is flipped. For adults that miss a three way that they have just made, well there's no excuse.Adults probably won't find Fish, Fish, Squish! very fun. It's a little too simple and shallow for them. The squishing of a clay fish is always satisfying, no matter your age group though. Young children (once they hit double digits, the fun factor in this probably decreases sharply) though, should have a blast with this. The game helps teach spatial recognition, pattern recognition, probability outcomes and lets you mangle something made of gooshy clay. I can't see this being a game kids will want to play for than two or three times in a row without getting board, or even once a day for weeks on end, but it is something that will be enjoyable in short bursts and something a parent can do with their child. With a price tag of under $15, you WILL get your money's worth with Fish, Fish, Squish. I'm just not sure for how long.

Generally the only treats we can get all three of our cats to like are Greenies. Until now that is. All three of our cats really enjoyed these salmon and cranberry Kittles.Case Study #1: Shelly is a 14-15 year old Maine Coon mix. She eats anything and everything. She is not in the slightest bit picky. Each time we have offered her some of these treats she devours them. We think she might even be swallowing them whole. Now since Shelly is pretty much a garbage disposal, a glowing recommendation from her is not that impressive, but she does love these and ask for more when her treat allotment is done.Case Study #2: Malice is a two year old kitten. Her mother dies in childbirth and her sibling died soon after. She was the runt of her litter and ended up being fostered by my hare. So our tiny kitten who grew up to be a giant cat the size of my torso partially thinks she is a rabbit. As such she does not like meat. Or we assume this is why she doesn't like meat. She will eat some fish (swordfish and tuna for the curious) and chicken if it is rotisserie cooked, but that's it. She does not like wet food and strongly prefers kibble. She went gonzo for these treats. Which is a great sign. Like Shelly she wanted more and wanted them NOW.Case Study #3: Angel of Music is our almost one year old kitten. She is extremely picky. She loves her Royal Canin kibble and is willing to go on a hunger strike rather than eat wet food or even other brands. She doesn't like any meat except tuna and pretty much hates everything food-wise. With these treats, she stared at them for a while, then she licked them for a while and after a few minutes she ate them. This has been her pattern all three times we have offered her Kittles. The fact she deigns to eat them at all is a "MIKEY LIKES IT!" kind of moment and shows that across the board, our pets love these treats.Health-wise the treats are fantastic as well. they are two calories each and the first five ingredients are salmon, peas, potatoes, chick peas and chicken meal, so they are quite good for the kitties. There is a lot of protein to be had in these treats too, which is excellent. The price tag is a bit high on these treats (especially the Tuna & Cranberry variety), but since all our cats love them AND we have something all three will willingly eat, it's more than worth the cost.

"A Naturalist Goes Fishing" takes a look at eight different parts of the world with an eye on a specific fish for each region. In Manitoba, the focus is on the Lake Trout. In the Gulf of Mexico, Yellowfin Tuna is the catch of the day. France has Anchovies, the toothfish gets its fifteen minutes during the chapter on Antarctica. So on and so forth. In each chapter, the current conditions of each region and how changes to them have affected the fish population of the chapter are discussed and debated. It's a stark look at what humanity has done to the world around them. This just doesn't cover climate change, but pollution, deforestation, overfishing and more.Don't think that this book is a dry clinical read. Yes, it takes a stark look at regional developments and their fish population, but this reads more like a travelogue than a ichthyology manual. It is sometimes sage, sometimes funny, sometimes sad but always a captivating read. I don't even like fishing, but I really enjoyed this book in a manner similar to "A Walk in the Woods" by Bill Bryson. I will never attempt to walk the Appalachian Trail in its entirety, but I loved that book. Same too with "A Naturalist Goes Fishing." I have no interest in fishing, but the book and its narrative tone really made me interested in the author's enjoyment of the hobby and for fish in general. I also appreciated how much the author put into treating the fish with respect rather than as trophies. After all, they are living things and a source of food. It's not like they're a Heisman.Even if the thought of fishing makes you roll your eyes and you can think of nothing more boredom-inducing, "A Naturalist Goes Fishing" is still a very enjoyable read. I learned a lot and I had fun doing so.

This is a fantastic pizza wheel. It cleaves through the pizza with ease, yet it's not sharp enough that you would not fear a serial killer wielding this against you. It's very sturdy and glides through the pizza. It is very large though so those will small hands might find this unwieldy. At the same time though, the size of this thick and the strength of the wheel means this is the perfect pizza cutter for thicker pizzas like those done in the Chicago style. As well, I would recommend handwashing it as the size of the wheel  generally leaves the wheel spotty with water stains if you clean it in the dishwasher. Still, this is a great pizza cutter and it should last you a very long time

We just purchased a breakfast nook for our dining room and decided to get this tabletcloth for it. It's a very beautiful dark green and the damask pattern really adds something to it. It's very stain resistant and you can wash it without worrying about it losing any color or being damaged in the wash. The tablecloth is quite slick so you might want to keep an eye on glassware or pets.You get a very well made and striking tablecloth for an extremely low MSRP (Amazon sells it for half that, which makes this all the more of a bargain). We're quite happy with this tabletcloth and will use it a lot, especially in the winter around holiday time.

Nory isn't your typical kid  but how many books are about typical kids?  They always have magical powers or secret identities or destinies or quests, some secret power that will be revealed and they will save the day.  And they generally come from tragic pasts, too. Their parents have died and they've been raised in a horrid orphanage or by a mean aunt and uncle.  Well, Nory isn't your typical story book character, either.Well, she does have magical powers.  They don't work right, though.  Her past isn't  that  tragic though; her mother isn't living, but her father is alive and well and has a great job as a the headmaster of a very prestigious magic school.  Too bad he pushes her away. Maybe it's because he's still grieving, or maybe it's because she's different and weird. She has two siblings, who seem to love her a lot  but they aren't quite sure what to do with her, beyond trying to help her be "normal."Did I mention she is mixed race?  Yeah, the book kind of mentions that too, in passing.  Not many story book characters are mixed race.As the story begins, Nory's only "mission" is to get into Sage Academy, the prestigious magic school where her father is Headmaster.  Not only because it's the best school there is, but if she doesn't get in, it's kind of embarrassing.  And also she didn't apply anywhere else.But Nory instead finds herself living with her mother's sister and attending a "regular" magic school, in a class full of students just like her  students with "upside down magic"  that's what you call it when your powers work, just maybe not like they're supposed to or as you think they should.  Will Nory learn the value of her (and her new friends') powers? Or will she keep trying to "learn" to be normal?Oh, to have been given Upside Down Magic when I was a child!  This book was a simply delightful read from beginning to end.  I urge every parent, cool aunt/uncle, grandparent, guardian, or anyone with a child in their life to buy this book as soon as it comes out!  And there are probably some adults who should read it, too!

I picked up this camera for my father to use and basically wrote this review around his time with it and his observations. He loves photography but he refuses to learn or accept digital cameras so when I have purchased him them, I end up having to return them or find them unused years later. This however is right up his alley. My father used to love Polaroid cameras when I was a kid and he had so much fun with the instant film. Of course, we all know what happened to Polaroid's instant cameras and film. That's a subject for another time. Me? I use my iPhone for cat pictures and that's about it.This camera came with a two pack of film and I had my father use the camera on his next trip to DC to visit us. The film went by quickly. Although the pictures are not going to be professional magazine level quality, they came out very well and my dad really enjoyed this camera. It's also reasonably priced, which made us love it all the more.The package contains the camera, a shoulder strap, AA batteries, a close up lens and the usual bells and whistles for a budget cameras. You have a viewfinder, extended lens, a tripod socket, manual flash, automatic focus, close up lens, and so on. It's a really nice camera that gives you "widescreen" style photographs. The camera does not usually come with film (this was for review purposes only).Like an old Polaroid, the film is pricey compared to digital prints and the resolutions isn't as good as some high end digital cameras. That's not the point though. The point is that the camera is an update of an old classic and it brought a smile to my dad's face. So this camera did everything I needed it to and more. Looks like the film will be an easy standby gift for him when various holidays roll around.

I love cooking. My kitchen is full of all sorts of wacky gadgets from a gelato maker to mini pie makers. I actually find cooking relaxing. So when I was offered a chance to review this cast iron grill, I jumped at it. I love KitchenAid. I have their blender, their soft serve ice cream maker and many other items. I have to admit, I fell in love with this skillet as soon as the box arrived and I felt the massive heft of it. This thing is much heavier than you might expect. The weight on the Amazon page says only 6 lbs, but it actually weighs more than double that. So expect that.This grill is fantastic. I can't express it any other way. It works wonderfully and I love using it. The Panini/sandwich press topper is just a bonus. You CAN season this grill like a cast iron skillet or pot, but it has a porcelain enamel coating, so you don't really need to. The instructions say this the grill is dishwater safe, but they also say you're much better off handwashing this. Trust the instructions. Your grill will last much longer if you wash it in the sink instead of the dishwasher.Cast iron kitchen pieces can get extremely expensive. You get what you pay for. That's why I was surprised that this grill is so affordable. The MSRP is $199, which is indeed pricey, but Amazon sells it for much less, meaning you can get a high quality piece for your kitchen for a fraction of the usual asking price. I'd definitely take them up on that. This piece is very versatile, as you can use it in the oven, on the grill or on a stovetop. It's easy to clean (remember to dry it thoroughly) and it is a wonderful addition to your kitchen collection.

I already have cleanser and moisturizing regimen that works.  But no matter how careful you are with your skin care, an unexpected zit will pop up from time to timeusually just in time for a big event or date. When that happens, I want something that will not just clear it up, but will do it quickly.  Preferably with as little irritation as possible.  I hadnt tried any of the Proactive products before, but I had heard good things about the products themselves (though I have been warned to never buy direct from Proactive) so I thought it was definitely worth a try.I know that benzoyl peroxide is my best bet for getting (and keeping) my skin clear and this product is a strong dose (5%).  I used it for several days in a row on a couple of tiny spots.  They cleared up really quickly (within a couple of days at the most), but I was left with dry, peeling skin.  This isnt actually unusual; many acne treatment products cause this, so it wasnt unexpected and I have ways of dealing with it.However, I found that the product just didnt work as well on the big monster blemishes (which I conveniently developed just in time to use this product on  lucky me).  You know the ones: the painful, hard, obnoxious ones you get once in a while (especially during hormonal changes).  Even in concert with my benzoyl peroxide cleanser, it still took almost a week before that one cleared up sufficiently.A two pack is $45.95 on Amazon right now  a two pack of really small tubes (.33 of an ounce each).  Is it worth that price?  I dont think so.  It does work, but its not a miracle product.  It doesnt work quickly enough on the real problem blemishes to warrant spending that kind of money on it. Thats why its only getting three stars from me.

These baskets are excellent for storing things like clothes, blankets, towels and other soft/fabric based items. They are lightweight and flexible, but they are not sturdy or thick. This means you shouldn't use them for heavy, fragile or sharp items. Sweaters - yes. Power Tools - no. They are excellent for maximizing space in you closet and for holding items that only get seasonal use. The "sweater size" baskets hold half a dozen sweaters give or take. Obviously a XXXL person will fit less clothing in one of these than someone who wears a S or M.The price for these bins is incredible as you get them for about six dollars a pop. So you can certainly get a lot of these without breaking the bank. Our cats love to play in these too.

We love Nature's Miracle. I've had an incontinent cat and a Rabbit who would sometimes spray outside of her litter box and for both, Nature's Miracle urine remover has been fantastic. It removes smells, stains and even non-urine issues like poo, juice and chocolate. So my wife and I were more than happy to take a review copy of their new product.Now it might surprise you to hear that we got this not for either of us, but our two year old kitty, Malice. Malice loves to smell everything, but she has some severe allergies to dust mites and trees. So she is on allergy shots once a week for life. We got this to see if it could help in conjunction with the shots, and I'm happy to report it really helped. It's not a long term solution, but the Allergen Blocker works just as well as getting allergens besides pet dander. We can squirt this in hard to reach places or in cracks like under the stove or fridge where we can't really clean, but the cat can still stick her nose under to sniff. Her sneezing is now almost nonexistent. She's much happier and so are we.This works quite well for people too. My mother is very allergic to cats and we have three so even when we come visiting, she ends up having a flare-up. Spraying this before a visit seemed to prevent the usual issues. So overall, we have some very positive experiences with this product.

This is an algebra practice workbook, for children in grades six through eight.  Each section starts out with a pre-test, so you can see what areas the child should practice in.  The concepts for that section are very briefly reviewed, then it continues on with pages of exercises. Each section also ends with a post-test, to check that the child is picking up the concepts.  Areas covered include Algebra Basics, Fractions, Equations and Inequalities, and even some graphing. Answers are included at the back of the book.This book is not a complete algebra course. It should not take the place of tutoring or a remedial class for a child who is really struggling with the concepts.  Each section contains only a few paragraphs to review the concepts presented.  It does not go into in-depth explanations and in most cases only one example is given. If your child is really struggling with the subject, or is failing algebra, this book by itself is not going to fix the problem.If, however, you are looking for a way to keep the concepts fresh in your childs mind over the summer months, or if he or she just needs a little extra practice to get the concepts, this might be a good investment. Alternatively, if you have a gifted child who is interested in math beyond his or her grade level, this might be an interesting introduction.

When I get a product that calls itself juice, I kind of expect it to be well, juice. So I was surprised when this review product arrived to see that this was actually ONLY 20% juice. This statement is blasted against the back of the package, which makes it more akin to Minute Maid fruit punch then actual 100% juice products. Generally this is done to cut costs, calories and/or sugar, but Purity Organic actually has as much sugar and calories as a 100% orange or orange/mango juice per serving. It also costs a lot more. Now you might think this is because the drink is organic, kosher and non-GMO. Unfortunately, this too doesn't hold up under scrutiny. I go to my local Co-Op or grocer like My Organic Market and get 100% organic juice products for less. So Purity Organic is needlessly expensive compared to contemporaries and is less of a juice product.This gets three stars because it tastes good and it tries to be socially and environmentally content, but for the most part, this is a product trying to pull the wool over people's eyes and from the other reviews here on Amazon, it definitely seems to be working.

You rarely say to yourself, "Boy, I sure feel like making nachos on the grill." In fact, I had never said that before in my life. However, don't let the name fool you. Cuisinart's non-stick grilling platter is exceptionally versatile and one of the easiest to clean pieces of cookware that I own.The 13" platter can be used for a wide array of dishes, both in terms of serving and cooking. The non-stick coating is the best I've ever seen. Not only does gunk slide right off when you clean it, but it doesn't slowly but surely ship away like so many other products with a coating of this nature. Even if you don't cook with the platter, it makes for a fine serving tray as it is both light and durable.Note that the platter is HAND WASH ONLY. It's so easy to clean that this shouldn't be a problem. Besides, the size and shape makes it hard to fit properly in a dishwasher anyway.

I picked this stapler up for my wife to use at her office. She fell in love with it at first site and I'm happy to report it works just as well as it looks. It's a Swingline though and the tend to make fantastic staplers (insert your own Office Space joke here I guess). It doesn't what it needs to. It staples, doesn't appear to jam, and it makes a nice conversation piece for one's desk.You do have to use Swingline's staples though rather than generic ones, which knocks this down a peg, but it looks good and its functional and that's what matters.

We've used this curry paste several times and had great results with it. You do have get the measurements right or it will be bland and runny or thick and extremely spicy, but once you get the actual ratio (not what is suggested on the package) right, this makes a fantastic curry base. My wife is a big fan and although I usually make my curries from scratch, this is a lot easier and faster...and almost as good.Now it is far from authentic and it's a little high in oil for my liking, but everyone's tastes are different. It's not the healthiest choice for a curry base, but it is similar to a lot of pastes I looked at after receiving my review copy, at least in terms of things like sodium, fat and ingredients. I'm happy with it, but with all things, tastes vary and although we enjoyed the flavor, you might not.

On paper, this cats food seems like a great idea. It's well made. It's grain, potato and wheat free. The first ingredient is chicken and not chicken meal and it's got a lot of protein and fiber. It has everything a cat should need and want.The problem is we have three cats and none of them will eat it. They will go out of their way to avoid this cat food and if it is the only one we offer, they will just engage in a battle of wills with us until we give them the dry cat food they actually want (Royal Canin). We were really excited to try this. Unfortunately our cats just don't feel the same.

The Mai Couture Like a Diamond Trio is highlighter and blush on thin paper slips together in one packet, designed for quick easy use on the go.  In theory (or, on paper if you will  ha!) it sounds like such a neat idea.  Unfortunately in practice its anything but.The first thing I noticed was that the dust goes everywhere.  This is not something Id want to carry around in one of my nice handbags, because I can imagine the product staining the lining.My second issue was that I found the papers to be hard to handle.  Its actually a bigger problem with the highlighter sheets, since when applying blush youre generally trying to get the color in a larger area. I had a hard time getting the highlighter where I wanted it.  I had to fold and bend the sheets in an attempt to get the look I was going for, and wound up with more product on my fingers than on my face. With both the highlighter and the blush, I still had to blend the product with a brush anyway because of the harsh lines I ended up with  which I thought defeated the point of the papers?I did like the highlighter color very much.  Im very fair and it looked quite nice on my skin.  The rosier blush was lovely, as well.  I dont wear blush on a daily basis, but it also looked nice with my coloring.  The other blush was a bit too orangey for my taste.This is not a product I would get again, especially for $24.00 for a packet.  Thats a bit more than I want to pay for a product when more is going to end up on my fingers, dressing table, and floor than on my face.

So the boxes aren't very good. I have to state that right out. The tube is too small for our cat or either of our kittens. They can't maybe get their head in. These are so small I'm not sure how the makers thought these would be appropriate sizes for cats when they are too small for kittens. Maybe bunnies or guinea pigs.The boxes are too small as well. Our cat can't fit in either, and if you have cats you know how good they are at contorting themselves to fit small boxes. That speaks volumes about these. One of our kittens likes to lie in it, but they are so small, whenever she gets in, she knocks out a side panel or the bottom because they are so flimsy. Don't even get me started with how dangerous these can be if your cat gets on top of one. Like the sides, the top is removable and thus pops out/caves in from the slightest amount of pressure, say a cat or kitten walking or just laying on it. These things can be death traps to the less agile, clumsy or any cat over five pounds.My advice would to never, ever ick these up. The materials are shoddy, the boxes are too small for cats to actually use and the tunnel is simply unusable. Save your money and just give your cats the next box your Amazon order comes on. It's free and it will last longer. These are terrible.

Look, I love Grimlock. I still have my original one, my blue G2 one, my Beast Wars version and several other variants. I especially love my Masterpiece Transformer version, who is certainly the best version of Grimlock to come out. So I when I was offered a chance to review a new version of, him, Grimlock, I definitely jumped at the chance.When the Voyager class version of Grimlock arrived, I looked at him in the box and was unimpressed. He did, after all, look nothing like *MY* Grimlock. Now I have the Alternators Grimlock and Pretenders Classic Grimlock, so I don't need him to be a classic T-Rex by any means. This was just weird looking to me. When my wife, who is pretty uniformed about Transformers saw him though her reaction was, "OOOH PRETTY!." She kind of fell in love with AoE Grimlock at first site and went from being nonplussed about our free tickets to the film to being excited because she wanted to see Grimlock on the big screen. Her Grimlock, mind you. Her initial impression to this toy (which she loves) and how different it was from mind made me realize I was condemning this toy for not being the classic "Me Grimlock King!" from the cartoon or the Budinsky/Furman Grimlock from the comics. That was unfair of me and the more time I spent viewing the toy on its own merits and flaws, the more I realized, this was a pretty good figure on its own. It's not perfect, but it's by far the second best of the AoE figures to me.The Voyager Class Grimlock is easy to transform, although I advise you not to use the instructions. Grimlock comes packaged in Dino form and the instructions are from robot to T-Rex. Whoops. Grimlock transformers pretty easily ATLHOUGH he has a couple pieces like his shoulder section in T-Rex form  (which becomes part of his back in robot form) that feels like you are moving it the wrong way and/or that it will break if you move it into the correct spot. it won't, but man will it seem like it is going to. I also like that this version of Grimlock has a moving jaw action but I do wish there was a way to permanently close his jaw instead of it always hanging open. He's not perfect, but he does look like a weird alien version of a  angry T-Rex.Robot Mode is fine. I'm not a fan of his feet, but that's personal opinion. He stands up fine and that's all that matters in the end.Overall, I'm pretty happy with Voyager Grimlock. He's no Masterpiece Grimlock, but he's also only twenty bucks rather than five to ten times that ala my Japanese import, so it evens out in the end. There is a "Leader Class" Grimlock that is prettier and contains both more chrome and colour to him that this voyager version...but he also costs twice as much. I'd personally stick with the Voyager. When my TFs start hitting the $40+ mark, I start to consider the third party market or Masterpiece figures - especially over a Bey-verse guy. All that said, Voyager Grimlock is pretty good for his price point and I'm happy to have him in my Grimlock collection. He'll never be my favorite Grimlock, or even in my top five, but he's one of the better, if not the best AoE transformers, so that's a big plus in his favor.

I was a big fan of the Dinobots as a young child growing up in the 80s. My favorites were Grimlock and Snarl, but Slag was the first one I owned and he still has a special place in my heart because of this. Well, the Bey-verse Slug is NOT my Slag. This Transformer is much smaller and is brightly decked out in purple and red colours instead of silver, gold and gray. As much as some older TF fans like myself may want to compare AoE Slug to classic Slag, it really is apples and oranges. That said, if you WANT a Dinobot closer to your childhood memories, do a google search for FanToys Scoria. This third party Slag looks like the original but has the articulation and poseability of a modern Transformer. It'll also set you back two hundred bucks, so this $9.99 Slug may sound better and better after that revelationSlug (SLAG!) is a pretty easy transformer to well, transform. His modes are pretty easy and obvious to shift from one to the other. The Dinosaur (triceratops) looks fine if a bit garish. My wife likes how colourful he is and once you get past the G1 Dinobot paint scheme that is more than likely embedded into your head, you'll be okay with it. Paradigm shift people!Robot mode is where Slag falls apart. Part of it is indeed my own preconceived notions. it's weird having the triceratops head as shoulder pads instead of a helmet for example. Other parts are just bad design. Slug's robot head is just kind of a blob amdhis front dino legs are just hanging out on his side in robot mode, making Slug look more like Shiva than a Dinobot.So all in all, the price point is nice and when you get past the G1 expectations in your head, the dino mode of Slug is pretty decent for a Bey-verse figure but the robot mode is really lacking. We'll call it a thumbs in the middle here.

Do you like old school Konan, Kull the Conqueror, Appendix N style authors and the like? Then you may just enjoy Barbarian Lord, a new graphic novel collection which continues the saga of well, Barbarian Lord. Yes, that is his name.I wasn't sure if this was a prequel or sequel to the other Barbarian Lord releases out there, but to be honest, they all can work as stand-alones more or less.Barbarian Lord's main character may rub some readers the wrong way. He is definitely a Marty Stu in that he is great at everything and defeats any obstacle in his path with little effort or challenge.  He's also rather unlikeable as a person. He kills a person at the drop of the hate for any slight, imagined, over-exaggerated or real. Good naturedly rib Barbarian Lord? He will murder you. Try to take his land? He will murder you. So on and so forth. He also looks kind of like Dick Briefer's Frankenstein. I'm not sure if that is coincidence or purposeful homage. Barbarian Lord is not a good person, nor does he have many redeeming qualities, so if you go into this expecting a "lawful good" sort of protagonist, you will be in for a shock. I have to admit. *I* don't even like the character, but it is the writing and world of Barbarian Lord that makes it enjoyable for me.This particular graphic novel isn't very gory, even if it is violent. There are beheading and impalements, but there is gratuitous depictions of such like in a Geoff Johns comic. Instead blood and gore is left more to the imagination. The most violent thing shown is an eyeball flying out of a caved in skull and that is at the very beginning.The story of this particular graphic novel is a bunch of people who don't like Barbarian Lord are manipulated by a certain skullheaded antagonist into declaring Barbarian Lord an outlaw and casting him out of their village. From there Barbarian Lord encounters a few challenges and some new allies as he seek both revenge and to retake his rightful lands. The story is deeper than that quick description as you will see from reading it, but that's the book in a nutshell.The writing is where Barbarian Lord really triumphs. The book reads like a classic prose novel, with characters speaking in ways you would never see someone do in real life, but this manner makes the book all the more enjoyable. The odd turns of phrase, unique sentence structure, and even a poet vs poet battle make the comic as much fun to read as it is to look at. The cast of supporting characters (especially the birds and wolves) are fantastic too.I enjoyed Barbarian Lord for what it is, but it definitely isn't for everyone. Younger readers should probably stay away, and those looking for more likeable characters will probably be disappointed too. If you are a man of Howard and other similar authors, you will probably enjoy this for what it is.

I really like the semi-recent trend of the "pick your own size" paper towels, as it cuts down on waste and allows you the size paper towel you actually want/need for a spill, cleaning or napkin alternative. We tend to buy the Brava brand in our home because they are really absorbent and you can get a lot for a good price. We were offered this bulk purchase of similar style Bounty paper towels to review and found ourselves equally impressed with what we got.The paper towel rolls are enormous. In fact, they are so thick they don't fit on our towel dispenser. We have to whittle the roll down a bit and then put them on. That's not a bad thing, but something you should keep in mind. As well, because you are getting a dozen two packs, you will need a place to store these. Great for a big family that goes through a lot of paper towels, but if you live in an efficiency apartment or the like, you might want to rethink this purchase. The rolls even out to about $1.25 per roll, which is an excellent price.The towels do what they need to, which is suck up spills, help you clean, and give you something to wipe your hands on. I mean, it's not rocket science. For the most part a paper towel is a paper towel is a paper towel. Thickness and absorbency are the two real areas to judge these by and the Bounty towels do a great job. We're very happy with them and their results.

Sweet Chili Garlic chips seem to be the hardest Kettle Chip variant to find. In fact, although I've looked for them in stores, I've never seen them. This was my first experience with them and I have to admit, they were as addicting as they were tasty. I tend to be a very light snacker but I would find myself eating half a bag if I wasn't careful! It's spicy enough to be tasty but not so spicy that would offend a more sensitive palate. Even my friends found these extremely delicious and would ask if they could take a bag from me since this particular flavor appears to be nowhere in the DC metro area.Terrific chips, and buy purchasing them in bulk, they are quite cheap and will last you a very long time. The only downside is trying to store the giant box of them. It really is massive.

I generally enjoy historical novels.They dont even have to be 100% historically accurate - Im a firm believer in artistic license, as long as the author doesnt claim otherwise, of course.  However, I just couldnt get interested in this.  The reason for that was that I simply hated the protagonist.Tom Hawkins is a man in debt, given a second chance (through the love of a good friend and  a healthy dose of luck).  But does he take his money home, blessing his good fortune and pledging to make better decisions?  Of course not!  He decides to stay out half the night drinking and carousing, and manages to get robbed on the way home. It didnt take long for me to start feeling like Hawkins was an idiot who deserved what he got.  I couldnt relate to him at all and had no sympathy for him.The writing was fine, and I feel that the author did a good job of trying to depict the harsh reality of life in a debtors prison in the 1700s.  Unfortunately, I can't give this a positive review, simply because my hatred of the main character and his constant copious amounts of stupidity kept me from finishing.

This is supposed to be a mystery novel about master sleuth Sam Levitt.  Unfortunately, theres not really any mystery here and Sam Levitt hardly strikes me as a master of anything  unless its a master partier.  Thats all they seem to do in this novel  eat and drink good wine.From the very first chapter, we know whos after Francis Reboul.  Theres no mystery to solve, really  another rich guy wants his house, a rich guy with a history of violence and a string of dead business partners.  They talk about the danger Reboul is in throughout the novel, but the bad guy only makes the one attempt at the end of the novel; an attempt thats so easily thwarted you sort of have to question the intelligence of he and his conspirators.The only thing I really enjoyed about the novel were the descriptions of the locales.  Thats about all it had going for it, and it was the only reason I finished it. Theres no mystery, no suspense,  little action, and even less adventure.  Not a series I will pursue.

Although I was never a big fan of Andre the Giant in the ring, I found his life and the stories told by his fellow wrestlers to be fascinating. So I happily picked up this graphic novel. While the book does take liberties with Andre's story (and the book admits to doing this) and portrays him in a far more positive light than long time fans might expect (cruder stories such as his Asian women fetish and habit of pooping in bathtubs are left out despite being some of the most famous stories), the book does do a good job at showing you key moments in Andre's life, whether it's the usual WMIII rigmarole or a fight he had with Bad News Brown/Allen (A black Canadian wrestler) over his use of the N word .At nearly 250 pages, this is a pretty long original graphical novel and wrestling fans should really enjoy the stories and nostalgia it provides the reader. Even people who are too young to remember Andre will still enjoy the graphic novel on some level, but int his case, the older you are, the more you will get out of this piece.I will say I didn't care for the art style, but that's really subjective. What matters is that out of all the books on Andre so far, this was the most fun to read, even if it wasn't the most accurate or informative. Still, it's a comic so it's not like you're going into this thing expecting the author/illustrator to have vetted everyone who even tangentially knew the man.

Glad makes top notch storage bags and these are no exception. These are sturdy, they can hold a lot of wait, and they are clear so you  can see exactly how your food is doing, which helps prevent freezer burn and other potential issues. You can double check via the colour combing seal to ensure there isn't any air getting in. So on and so forth. These work great storing dry food, food in the fridge and even as freezer bags. I'm very happy with them.

So, my family grabbed this litter box because it looked neat and the ability to get a urine sample seemed like a good idea as we've had to do that before with our elderly cat and it was a pain.The Purr Fect Potty is easy to put together and well made. It's a finely crafted litter box and it looks great. However, our pets refuse to consider it a litter box. They simply don't know what to make of this thing.We have three other cat litter boxes in the house, one is a hooded box like this but much bigger and with steps for our elderly cat to get in and out of. One is the Merry Pet Cat Washroom / Night Stand Pet House which looks and works great. The other is a regular litter box with a high back to prevent spraying. So you would think the Purr Fect Potty would be something easy to adjust to. Well it isn't the refuse to go to the bathroom in it. The kitten plays with the pine pellets like a little human child plays in a ballroom. The elderly cat uses it as a bed. Not once have they gone to the bathroom in it.We suspect it is because the pine litter looks like rabbit pellets. We have an eight year old hare that is definitely the boss of the two cats. She's territorial and very aggressive if either cat tries to use her litter boxes. So either the cats think that because it smells and looks like rabbit food, they are not using it or they simply don't like the thing as it was intended.Checking other reviews on the site, no cat seems to actually be using the Purr Fect Potty, so I guess it must be displeasing to cats in some way we mere humans can't understand. Well, at least the cats are sleeping and playing with it instead of actively avoiding it. That's...something I guess.

First things first - the Neato Botvac 80 is NOT a replacement for regular vacuuming. If you buy it for this reason, you will be disappointed. That said, as a maintenance helper to keep the dust and pet hair picked up regularly, the botvac is fantastic. Sometimes it's just fun to watch it learn the house and interact with your pets. We have one cat that has a love/hate relationship with it as it runs from and chases the Botvac around the house.Pro:A large dustbin compared to other robot vacuums. It needed to be emptied after each room thoughCon:The dust bin is easy to remove from the bot, but to pry the lid off of it takes a surprising amount of force, which as you may imagine, causes dust to fly out and back onto your nice clean floor.Pro: The vacuum is pretty good at navigating your room. It quickly learns the layout of a location and you'll be able to figure out its cleaning pattern of a location after a few trips in that room.Con: There are a few quirks where the vacuum will insist it can fit under something it can't or will think there is something blocking it when there is only empty space and not go forward. In our study, the Neato always gets stuck under the couch and will cry out for help (which is kind of neat) and will do only half the room three times in a row, repeating itself and refusing to move beyond a certain point until it has circled the other half of the room three times. Only then will it make a single sweep around that other half.Pro: The vacuum can mostly be left on its own after it learns the layout of your home.Con: You do have to baby-sit the vacuum the first few times it does a room to make sure it doesn't get stuck. This isn't so bad except it takes three times longer to clean a room than a regular vacuum, so make sure you have a book or handheld gaming system while you wait.Pro: It's VERY quiet.Pro: it's always able to find it's charging base and doing so doesn't take long at all.Pro: It works on carpet, tile and hardwoodPro: It's usually gentle with furnitureCon: Except out extremely old Amish rocking chair heirloom which it repeatedly tries to climb. It looks like it's trying to mate with the poor chair.Overall, this thing is a great little maintenance machine. You can program to vacuum at certain times every day or every few days and our kitten (the one who has the love hate relationship with it) has even learned to turn it on to try and play with it. It's very cute.Although expensive, the Neato Botvac 80 is better in nearly everyway to the Roomba's. It's a wonderful cleaning tool and it makes your regular vacuuming sessions a snap. Just remember the small dustbin and slow length of time it takes to clean means this is an accessory or supplement to cleaning rather than your primary means of getting pet hair, gunk and dust off your floors.

Ill be honest here - I dont have a lot of dark spots or freckles to speak of on my face.  Outside of a few sunburns when I was very, very young and dependent upon someone else to keep me sunsafe, Ive tried to stay out of the sun and use sunscreen when that wasnt possible.With that said, I didnt think this product would make much of a difference in the way my skin looked.  I was wrong.First of all, its a fantastic moisturizer.  Most stuff just sits on my very oily skin and doesnt want to absorb - not so this. My skin drinks it right up.  It feels very light on with no greasiness at all.  It lends an almost matte look to my skin that lasts a couple of hours - and with my super oily skin, thats saying something.  Also, it smells great.Second, while I dont have a lot of discoloration to fade, I did notice that it made my skin almost glow.  I dont know if this is a lasting effect or something in the product that deflects light (normally these products use mica, but since mica tends to really irritate my skin, I dont think thats the case here).  The Amazon listing says that it will Reveal your most pearlescent beautiful skin, and thats the effect Im seeing.  The product doesnt add any color at all (trust me, Id be able to tell) but my skin has a lovely pearly sheen afterward.The only downside is that it doesnt contain any sunscreen.  Im fairly certain that a sunscreen would make it heavy and greasy feeling, though.  So Ive been using it at night and could see myself using it as a day cream under a foundation with at least SPF 15.For the price ($23.94 with Amazon Prime) I will certainly use it again.

Ive been an Olay user since my teens.  Ive tried other products, but I always come back to Olay because I can trust my skin to their products and theyre reasonably priced.  Sure, Ive liked some products better than others, but Ive never had an Olay product damage or irritate my skin.  I cant say that about other brands.Id heard that gel moisturizers are better for oily skin, and skin is scarily oily!  So I was really excited to try this gel from Olays new Fresh Effects line.  I certainly wasnt disappointed!Most moisturizers leave my skin looking shiny (yes, even my beloved Total Effects 7).  Its rare that I come across a product that doesnt.  Dew Over is one of the few!  My skin feels refreshed after application - like its had a cool drink of water - but it looks soft and velvety matte.  It has a light, airy texture that goes on smooth and feels wonderful on the skin.  Whats more, I dont notice a thick sheen of oil hours later.I love the scent of the product, as well.  It smells so fresh and clean.The product does not contain a sunscreen. As nice as it would be to have that in there, it would probably change the texture and feel of the product way too much.  The products in the Fresh Effects line are made to be layered, so I do know that there is a sunscreen designed to be used with it.The Fresh Effects line is marketed toward younger women - those in their late teens and early to mid-twenties.  Im a bit outside that range, but I love what Ive seen from the line so far. Im extremely happy with Dew Over and will definitely buy it again...and try other products in the line.

I started using Olay Total Effects 7 as soon as it came out.  I loved that I could use one product for basically everything - in my twenties, I didnt need a separate night or eye cream as long as I used this.  It was available in several varieties, and Ive tried most of them.  That it was available with SPF (15) or without was a plus, because sometimes the foundation I used didnt have any. It was lightweight, never greasy, didnt irritate my skin or cause breakouts, and it smelled great. Ive tried many other products over the years but I always came back to Olay Total Effects 7.My lifestyle has changed significantly over the years, though.  Im a lot more apt to do outdoorsy things than I was in my twenties.  So I was really excited to see Total Effects 7 with SPF 30. Unfortunately, I was a bit disappointed with the results.The texture is radically different.  This new Total Effects is a lot heavier than any of the other versions.  Its noticeable from the first pump.  It feels completely different going on.  It felt more like a thick, drug store brand sunscreen than it did a moisturizer.  Fifteen minutes after application, my skin was really shiny and greasy, as if the product didnt absorb.  I have really oily skin to begin with, so this was a huge turn off.  I also noticed some tiny bumps on my skin after a couple of days of use.I still love Olay products, and Ive learned by now (I hope) to stick with them.  But I think next time Ill get the old SPF 15 version and just make sure I use other sun protection measures.

Although this is a very fictitious version of "The War of the Roses," the acting, costuming and cinematography on The White Queen was fantastic. I can't say I enjoyed this as much as The Tudors or The Borgias and other docu-drama series, but as a mini-series this was entertaining for what it was. I'm not sure why this is being sold as "The White Queen: Season 1" when the packaging states it was a mini-series and I can't imagine what they'd do for a second season, but just know if you HAVEN'T watched this - The White Queen is not getting a second season. It was designed as a ten episode mini-series for the Starz network and that's exactly what you are getting here.The first three episodes were pretty good and we watched them in a row.
