After a couple of weeks of taking the hair growth vitamin, my husband has not experienced any additional thickness in his hair, which has been thinning over the past year. However, he has noticed that all the hair on his body has been growing at a faster rate. In time he is hoping this will result in thicker hair, but don't expect immediate results. [I received a free sample of this product for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

I have been taking probiotics for years, ever since I had pneumonia and the antibiotics I had to take left me with some serious digestive system issues. The probiotics worked and after a few weeks restored the good bacteria to my body. In my search for a good brand of probiotics I found a wide variation in quality and effectiveness. The common drugstore type with 1 billion CFUs probably won't do much.The more good organisms the capsule contains, the better it is. Many are destroyed while navigating the digestive tract, so the more organisms the each pill contains, the greater the odds enough will make through the stomach and into the lower intestine.The Viva Labs Probiotics contain 25 billion CFU per capsule, more than most brands I have encountered, and contain six strains of good bacteria. The capsules are medium-sized and are easy to swallow. There is no aftertaste and I did not experience any side effects. A quality product, made in the USA in GMP-certified facilities.

I regularly take fish oil capsules for slightly elevated cholesterol and for relief of joint pain. It works well and helps relieve both of these conditions.I've tried many brands, and while they all work, they do not all contain the same amounts of Omega-3 or the amounts of EPA and DPA in the Omega-3. I want those two fatty acids to make up the bulk of my fish oil. (EPA has anti-inflammatory effects, DHA is for brain health.) Lower amounts means I have to take more capsules. The packaging states these pills provide 880mg EPA and 660mg DHA; however, a serving size is 2 capsules, meaning each capsule only contains 440 EPA and 330 DHA.The capsules are large, similar to most other brands of fish oil. They are ok to swallow as long as I take them one at a time. They are supposed to have a lemon flavor to prevent fish burps, but I do not taste any lemon nor is there a lemon scent. Unfortunately, the only sure way I can prevent fish burps is to take the capsules with a meal. I tried taking these without food and yes, fish burps; with food, no problem, no aftertaste.Zenwise Fish Oil is made in an FDA registered facility, GMP certified, and made in the USA. While a little more expensive than the generic drug store brands, I feel better knowing I am taking a supplement that is guaranteed high quality.[I received a free sample of this product for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

This coffee table style book is a gorgeous volume filled with beautiful full-color photography and text. While primarily aimed at those with an interest in nature and science, this is also a resource that can be enjoyed by anyone, from nature expert to novice.The book begins with a general introduction to butterflies as a species, with further chapters going into more detail on individual butterfly families and their life cycles. Covered are topics such as life history; wing shape, color, and patterns; what butterflies eat; butterfly environments; and effects of climate change to name a few.The text is informative and interesting, but what really shines are the accompanying photos on each page. The text is white on black glossy paper, enhancing the presentation of the photos. This is as much a photography book as a text on butterflies.I am familiar with only the common butterflies such as Swallowtails, Monarchs, and Skippers, and found the wealth of detail presented fascinating. The format used makes it easy to absorb new information. Many of us are visual learners; I know I am. Seeing the photo along with the text reinforces the information I have just read.Butterfiles is a treasure trove of information and a handy reference guide to be consulted again and again.

This is a wonderful little mouse. It's fast and responsive and has a flat, comfortable design that fits well in my medium-sized hands.The bluetooth connects quickly and stays connected. There are no drop-outs, and when I restart the laptop, it reconnects with no problems. It is more convenient to use than a USB mouse since I don't have to worry about losing the receiver.I'm using the mouse with a Dell XPS and Win 8.1. Note that your laptop must have bluetooth ability and it must be enabled, otherwise the mouse will need an adapter. The mouse runs on two AAA batteries which are not included in the package.[I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

This is a rich, heavy, odorless cream that worked quickly to soften dry, hard, callused skin on my heels and feet. I use it twice a day - after my shower and before bed.I don't often wear closed shoes in the summer, resulting in a lot of rough, dry skin. Within a few days of use, there was a noticable difference in texture. I also noticed that when using my foot file in the shower, I was able to slough off more dead skin than usual since it was much softer.As much as I love the results of the cream on my feet, I don't like the way it feels on my hands. It dries thoroughly in a few minutes, but it does leave a residue - not exactly sticky, but definitely a tacky feeling for about 10 to 15 minutes. During the day, I rinse off my hands, but at night I leave it on for some extra hand moisturizing around my dry cuticles.This is not a whole body lotion, but perfect for problem areas that will not respond to a daily moisturizer.

I began taking probiotics years ago after a bout with pneumonia; several courses of antibiotics left me with some serious digestive issues. The probiotics worked, and after a few weeks restored the good bacteria to my body. However, not all brands of probiotics are same, or as effective. The common drugstore type with 1 billion CFUs probably won't do much.The more good organisms the probiotic contains, the better it is. Many are destroyed while navigating the digestive tract, so the more organisms the each pill contains, the greater the odds enough will make through the stomach and into the lower intestine.The Viva Labs Probiotics contain 25 billion CFU per capsule, more than most brands I have encountered and contain six strains of good bacteria. These are medium-sized capsules and easy to swallow. There is no aftertaste and I did not experience any side effects. A quality product, made in the USA in GMP-certified facilities.[I received a free sample for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

Years ago I was advised to take probiotics to help restore the good bacteria in my digestive tract. It worked. It worked so well that probiotics became my go-to remedy for digestive issues and general digestive health.LoveBug Probiotics are a little different than the capsules I had been taking. While my old brand did have 8 strains of good bacteria, each capsule contained only 4 billion organisms. One LoveBug pill contains 10 billion organisms which use a slow release system into the body.The pills are easy to swallow and there is no aftertaste. No side effects whatsoever. They are packaged in a distinctive blue bottle making them easy to spot in my refrigerator. But more important than the pretty color is that they are in a glass bottle - so much better than plastic - and the tablets contain live cultures, which is the most effective way to take probiotics. And they are made in the USA, non GMO, with no chemicals or preservatives added.[I received this product at a promotional discount for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

Nice, thick, quilted oven mitts that do a great job protecting my hands when removing hot pans and trays from the oven or grill.They fit well on my medium-sized hands and the extra length, as compared to my old pair of mitts, is nice to have and good protection for my wrists. They are well-made with adequate thickness that I can hold a pan for more than a few seconds without feeling the heat.A nice addition to my kitchen.

I like the way this cream leaves my hands feeling soft and smooth. It has a nice creamy texture that at first feels greasy but is quickly absorbed. The only thing I don't like is the strong floral scent when the lotion first leaves the tube. However, it does fade after a few minutes and becomes tolerable.

I've tried many brands of dark circle correctors and had given up finding one that would work. Most left a filmy or tacky look that was worse than the dark circles.The La Roche-Posay system is different. It combines a quality concealer with gentle eye massage to move the fluid and puffiness away from under the eyes.The concealer blends cleanly, absorbs quickly, and didn't leave a trace. It noticeably brightened my skin. It's fragrance-free and non-irritating. I wear contact lenses and this did not bother my eyes at all, even when I got a little too close and some got in my eye.Using the metal applicator to apply the cream worked well, but I found it a little awkward for the massage and ended up using my fingers to gently massage out from the inside of my eye.After using the cream and eye massage twice a day, morning and evening, I definitely see a reduction in the dark circles under my eyes.

Previously we've owned gas powered chainsaws. My husband has never been happy with the lack of power from an electric model. Now that we no longer have large trees, I was looking for something easier to handle for use on small trees and large shrubs. As the gardener (and female) in the family, I wanted something that we could both use and that was easy to maintain.The Black & Decker 16-inch electric chainsaw is compact but still powerful. It's a little heavier than I expected, but the weight is balanced, and it's still light enough for me to handle. I prefer the electric because there is no gas to mix and no cord to pull to start it. Plus, on this model the chain tensioning is automatic so I don't have to learn to do that.Like most things we buy today, the saw needed to be assembled. Happily it only took a few minutes and no tools were needed. Just mount the bar and chain, and add oil (oil is not included in the box). There are a few plastic parts but they feel sturdy enough. Time will tell. A chain bar cover is included - I like that as my garage is a bit crowded and I won't have to worry about anything getting snagged on the chain.How well does it cut? Very well, and much better than we were expecting. It's a little slower than our old gas chainsaw, but still easily cut through six inch logs and smaller branches. It's perfect for our needs. For the average homeowner with a few small trees and shrubs, this model would be a good choice.

These reusable pods work well with my Keurig 2.0 K250 Brewer. This is a larger size pod than the single-cup version and only fits the machines that work with a carafe. When the carafe is not attached, he pod opens up the extended menu with additional brewing choices: carafe 2-5 cups, travel mug 12 or 14oz, single 8oz cup, and froth.These pods are well-constructed and solid, made of heavy plastic and have a sturdy mesh filter. Using a mesh rather than paper filter does allow some oil and sludge to pass through, but I don't usually mind this unless I'm brewing a very bold blend. Then I will add my own paper filter. It will remove most of the sludge and also makes cleaning easier. I cut down the cheap filters for regular brewers to make them fit.The pods are easy to clean. After emptying the grounds and rinsing, I wash them on the top rack of the dishwasher and they come out sparkling clean.I've been using these pods for a month now and they work almost flawlessly. The only issue I've had is an occasional "oops error", Keurig's way of telling you this is the wrong pod. I just reinsert the pod or wiggle it around a little and the error disappears and the pod works fine.The convenience of using my own ground coffee at a much lower price, and having a pod that I can use again and again rather than creating more landfill, makes the time spent washing and refilling the pod a small inconvenience.[I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

I have used sunless tanning products on my body for years but this is the first time I've tried one on my face. My skin can be sensitive and I was worried that it might look orange or fake, but after trying the XEN-TAN Dark Lotion on my legs and obtaining excellent results, I decided to give this a try.I applied the tanner in the morning after my shower. Although I have a tanning mitt, I chose to use my fingers instead so I would have more control over the application. (Just be sure to wash right after). The lotion has a creamy feeling, a nice scent, and was easy to apply. It dried quickly and left no greasy feeling. Within a few hours I could see a subtle difference in color.I was being very cautious around my eyes, and once the color developed, I could see where I missed a few spots. Other than that, the tan was even, and lasted a few days before fading. I have fair skin and am looking for a little added glow, not building a dark tan, so every few days works well for me.

This is a very nice, medium strength coffee. Although I generally prefer a darker roast with more complex tastes like Starbucks Cafe Verona or Espresso Roast, I found this very tasty and pleasant.The K-Cups are compatible with my 2.0 model brewer. They worked well on the 8oz setting brewing a robust, smooth cup of coffee. The taste of this brand reminds me of the excellent coffee we were served while on vacation in the Carribbean.

I have been using the retinol cream daily for the past month along with the InstaNatural Vitamin C Serum  and I am pleased with the results. The effect is subtle but the overall tone of my skin has a smoother, cleaner, and tighter look to it. It is gentle, yet effective.I have sensitive, older skin and did experience a little bit of itching and slight flaking for the first week or two as the dead skin cells began to turnover faster and were replaced with younger-looking, fresh skin. When my face feels too itchy, I use the retinol every other day for a few days - usually this is because I have been in the sun. For the most part, this combination of products is gentler than the ones I had been using, but produces the same good results.Unlike other anti-aging products I have tried, InstaNaturals Retinol Moisturizer is unscented. It's produced and packaged in the USA in FDA-certified facilities, which makes me feel confident about the quality of the product I am using.[I received a free sample of this product for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

I have used Miracle-Gro soil mixes for my indoor and outdoor potted plants with great results. The soil holds moisture, drains well, and provides the plants with an extra boost of nutrients. Now that the outdoor growing season is ending I am re-potting my herbs for the indoors where they will live in the garden window.The Organic Choice potting mix has a soft, lightweight texture  a blend of sphagnum peat moss and composted bark  and a rich, loamy smell.  The bag was easy to open and has perforation line that tore cleanly making scissors unnecessary. It was easy to pour from with little to no mess and the bag has a resealable zipper inside for easy closure. In addition, the mix contains two months of plant food which is perfect for starting or transplanting new herbs.This is an ideal choice for small indoor pots and, since it's organic, for plants like herbs that will be used for food.

This works ok, but it doesn't shave close enough. It requires going over the same spot a few times. It's good for small areas or quick trims. On the plus side, it's waterproof so it can be used in the shower. It's lightweight, compact, and uses standard AA batteries, making it good for travel.

This is a basic and really cute shape-sorter that's a fun and educational toy. It's appropriate for both boys and girls, is made of brightly colored plastic with four shapes that sort into a collapsible kitty carrier. It has a solid, sturdy feel and will hold up well through many hours of playtime by toddlers.The best part is that the kity carrier folds flat with the shapes inside, making this an easy toy to take along in the car, on outings, or to grandma's house.

This is a cute metal shelf narrow enough to fit inside a standard locker and it has potential for use other uses. I'm using mine to stack books under my desk and to free up floor space. When not in use or when being transported, the legs pop off and the shelf can be stored flat.The metal is thin, and the shelf is a little wobbly, but with care it should easily last the school year. Don't accidentally lean on like I did because it will start to bend out of shape.

This is replacing a rotary triple blade shaver for the man in the house.It took him about a week to get used to the way the Panasonic razor shaves, but once he did, he was very happy with the results. It requires several passes to get a close shave. The old rotary shaver is quicker, but it doesn't produce the smooth, clean feeling that this razor does. This is a man with sensitive skin, and any changes cause a little redness, but after the first few days, there was no more irritated skin.He doesn't like using it wet, but this is a personal preference and probably not the fault of the razor. The sideburn trimmer is excellent and gives a close, straight cut. The shaver itself is lightweight and easy to hold.He doesn't think the cleaning system is necessary, plus it takes up too much precious space on the counter in the bathroom. The shaver charges quickly (about an hour) using the cord and it easily rinses clean with water.Overall, a nice razor that gives a good, clean shave.

With many power-hungry devices and a limited amount of outlets, a USB charging station was the answer for my home for charging our phones, tablets, mp3 players, bluetooth speakers, headsets, and other devices that needs frequent charging.The Sentey Charging Station is an excellent choice. It is small, compact, and lightweight enough to be carried in a briefcase or carry-on for travel and can be easily moved from room to room. The power cord is detachable from the unit making it easy to store in the included travel pouch.Only one electrical outlet is needed, and six devices can be charging at the same time. Each USB port provides up to 2.4 amps of power. The hub has Auto Detect technology and will charge at the fastest possible speed (up to 2.4amps) allowed by the device and the cable.The charger is designed to stand on its side, and gives it a very  small, compact footprint on my already busy desk. I have been using it daily for the past month and find it charges all devices just as well as with their dedicated chargers. And best of all, I have been able to reduce the clutter of individual charging units and the mystery of where I last left one of them when I need to find it to charge a device.[I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased feedback.]

Now that I have numerous wireless devices in my home, some that run on N or AC band, it was time to replace my reliable but aging Linksys wiresless 54G. I wanted the speed and versatility of a multi-band router and greater wireless range.Setup of the new TP-Link was straightforward. Other than accidentally pressing the restart button while I was hooking up the equipment, it went flawlessly. Since I already had a router hooked up to my cable modem, I just unhooked the cables and transferred them to the TP-Link. After waiting a few minutes for the connection to complete, all the blue lights on the front went on, and I was able to configure the router through my web browser.The web interface is clean and simple to understand for even a new user. There is a quick set-up, a basic, and an advanced mode. All but power users should be happy with these choices. [On my previous router I was able to use the excellent, feature-rich DDWRT replacement software. This router does not support that option.]To make things easy, I used the same login/password and wireless security key as with my old router. I was pleased that most of my devices (phones, TV, tablet, laptops) connected to the 2.4G without needing to re-enter the password; I only had to configure the 5G bands for each of them. Something that I find handy is to put a shortcut link to the router interface on your bookmark bar making it easy to access months from now when you need to change something.The router has excellent range. I have a solid connection anywhere in the house, through walls and floors, and all the way to the back of my yard (100+ feet), even in the garden shed.Speed is fantastic and all my devices are connecting at high speeds and I'm consistently getting full internet download speeds.I am using the USB Ports for shared files on a hard drive and media streaming to my TV. Using the 5G band I get a clear, stable picture.Additional features are a guest network; parental, bandwidth, and security controls; and some basic diagnostic tools and statistic reports.Overall, I am happy with the performance of the TP-Link AC3200. It has delivered beyond my expectations.

My aging skin now has occasional breakouts, something I never had in my younger years. My dermatologist prescribed Tretinoin (Retin-A) which worked well to both stop the breakouts and made my skin younger. Currently I using over-the-counter products containing retinol to control breakouts and reduce fine lines.Proactiv+ Clarifying Night Cream contains retinol for aging plus salicylic acid for breakouts. It would be more convenient for me to use a two in one product, so I was eager to try it out, but I was a little concerned that these two ingredients might be too harsh when used together. I tested a small area on my face for two nights. I had no bad reaction so I proceeded to apply the cream to my entire face for the next week.After washing with a gentle, moisturizing cleanser, I applied a thin layer of the Proactive+ cream. It has a light texture, a pleasant scent, and absorbed quickly into my skin. After a few days I did indeed have a small amount of flaking skin, mostly around my nose. After a few more days, the flaking stopped and the overall texture and tone of my skin now has a smoother, cleaner look to it. This is similar to the effect I got when using the Tretinoin.I do like the product and for me it performs well. Depending on your skin type and what products you are accustomed to using, this could be quite drying and cause some initial peeling. I have fair, combination skin and it works well for me - however, my skin is used to these types of products. Also, I apply it only in the oily areas and some nights skip the dry skin - I let my skin be my guide.

These are medium size capsules containing cynarine, which is derived from the artichoke plant. They are easy to swallow and there is no aftertaste.I have been adding natural supplements to my diet that have antioxidant and cholesterol lowering properties, such as artichoke. It's difficult to evaluate after only a few weeks whether or not the capsules are having an effect on lowering LDL cholesterol, but I can say they have not caused any side effects.I am taking these capsules as part of an overall strategy along with a healthy diet plus other vitamins and herbal supplements. When I do choose a product I want it to be from a company I have had previous good experience with, and Nature's Bounty is a company I trust and buy from.

These dark chocolate bars are delicious. They are fresh, tasty, and chewy. They are a little on the sweet side although not overpoweringly so, but I've been noticing that with many of the snack bars on the market now.Each bar contains lots of fruits and nuts with a layer of dark chocolate on the bottom. The predominant fruit flavor is blueberry.While this mostly a healthy snack, it does have a  fair amount of fat at 9 grams and contains high fructose corn syrup, an ingredient I try to limit or avoid - although it's not that easy to do. However, the healthy fruit and nuts, 3 g of fiber, and great taste, does outweigh the negative, and I will be adding these to my snack drawer.

The Oceanique Bath Rug is soft and plush and feels great beneath our feet after stepping out of the shower. It's very absorbent and quickly soaks up any dripping water. And it dried faster than I expected considering the amount of water it absorbed.I have the gray mat in the 17x24 inch size. The color is true to what is shown on the product page and matches my bathroom decor. However, I find this size is a little too small. It works, but the larger size (21x34) would provide better coverage outside the shower door. (This is not the fault of the mat but mine for guessing on size and not pulling out the tape measure!)As much as I like the mat, the quality could be a little better. There were a lot of hanging and broken threads and missed loops in the weave. These look like flaws, not like they are part of a pattern, and, while not noticeable when the mat is on the floor, they will in time cause the rug to wear out faster than it should.

I am a routine flosser; my husband is not. He finds floss of any kind difficult to use and has given up despite being told it really is necessary for healthy gums. So I jumped at the chance to try the Sonicare Airflosser for him.This is a nice idea that is working ok, but not as well as I had hoped. It is simple enough to use, but the actual implementation is a bit clunky. It takes a little patience but overall he likes the unit.It has a small, compact size so he can conveniently leave it out on the vanity shelf. Unfortunately, because of the small size, it doesn't hold a lot of mouthwash and sometimes runs out of liquid before finishing, especially on the triple pulse setting. One problem he is having is the tip doesn't fit well between teeth  it's just a little too large. Also, the tip is not flexible, which makes it more difficult to maneuver.Perhaps using an airflosser is an acquired skill and takes some time to get better at. On a positive note, he is using it, which means his teeth are getting cleaner; a much better alternative than not flossing at all. Definitely worth trying for those who can't use string floss.

It's difficult to say if these pills are having any effect on cardiovascular health. My husband has high blood pressure and has added this to his diet with the hope that it might lower his numbers. After a month, there has been no significant change, so at this point I am neutral on its effectiveness. However, he will continue taking them a little while longer as positive effects often take a few months to show up.What I can report is that these capsules did not cause any negative effects.  The capsules are normal size, easy to swallow, and have no aftertaste. Each capsule contains 75mg Arjuna Extract. They contain all natural, non-GMO ingredients, are vegetarian, and gluten-free.

From outward appearances, nothing about Mike Erikson stands out as unusual. Hes a regular guy teaching at a small town high school, so it seemed odd when he was recruited to investigate the mysterious happenings at a DARPA lab. But Mike has some special abilities; ones that make him uniquely suited to the task, as the scientists at the lab soon discover. His mission: find out what secrets the team is hiding and why the project is taking so long to complete.The story started out strong. It had all the elements I love about a good science fiction novel. The characters were well-developed and geeky  ie the cranky genius, the trekkie; stereotypical but fun. The plot unfolded at a quick but even pace. The scientific device  a teleportation machine  was made easy to understand and, even though fiction, was one of those devices we would all like to have. That and a time machine!About two-thirds of the way through the plot makes an abrupt switch to a horror story. Until that point, this was a resounding 5-star read. I have no objection to horror stories; Stephen King is one of my favorite authors. But this turn of events had a silly B-movie feel to it. I was disappointed, but the first half more than made up for it. And the ending left an opening for a sequel.Even those who don't normally seek out science fiction would enjoy this book  it's more action-packed thriller than scifi.Audio production:I read this in audio and print. The audio was performed by Ray Porter who did a fantastic job with the characters and the segues back and forth as the narrator. At first I thought this might be an ensemble production, it was that good. The pacing was quick and he kept the story moving. It was easy to follow and its not overly scientific. I recommend the audio to listeners of all levels for its engaging qualities.

I often use the video feature on my phone but always handheld. I had no idea this little gadget existed until I was offered a sample to test.This is actually a set of two adapters. They have rubber grips on the inside to hold the phone safely and securely. One is a spring loaded grip, and the other has a small knob that screws the grip open and closed. Both adapters fit my Samsung Galaxy S4 phone and my tripod. I liked the one with the screw-on grip a little better because it allowed me to easily see what I was videoing through the opening in the back. The one with the spring grip was easier to attach to the phone, but blocked a little more of the screen. Both worked fine and held the phone securely in place.These adapters are clever and easy to use. And best of all, let me take video with my phone that is not shaky.[Sample product received for review purposes.]

I have been using sunless tanning products for years, and this is one of the best ones I've tried. My skin tends toward a pasty color which looks awful with skirts and no hose. Most of my experience is with tanning my legs.My experience with XEN-TAN . . .Positives:  - Good color - My legs look tan, not orange  - Easy to apply  - Thick, creamy lotion that began tanning instantly  - No awful chemical smell - In fact, very little scent at all  - No greasy feeling or residue  - Lasts a week and fades like a natural tan.Negatives:  - Pricey - At the higher end of the cost scale of those I've tried.Correct application of a sunless tanner is a little more complicated than the directions on the tube would make it appear. "Apply to dry skin and blend in" is a little vague and may not produce the desired results. Here's what worked for me. . .Exfoliate and shave just before applying the lotion. This is important for an even looking tan. Lightly dry skin - a little moisture remaining helps to spread the lotion evenly as it is quite thick. I used the XEN-TAN Deluxe Tanning Mittand applied using a circular motion. It did a nice job keeping my hands clean and was easy to rinse out. Be extra careful on rough areas like knees and ankles at the heel and use sparingly. I did get a bit of orange on one of my heels which I was able to exfoliate off.I used the XEN-TAN Dark Lotion even though I have fair skin. I have found the lighter shades don't provide as much color.

These chewy caramels just melted in my mouth. They are individually wrapped so they don't stick together, and didn't stick to the wrapper either. Soft, creamy, and delicious, I could easily eat the whole bag in one sitting, but I saved some for later.

I bought a large Mueller Fitted Wrist Brace because my left thumb suffers from tendonitis. This brace is well-made, attractive and breathes, which is important since I live in Houston. I appreciate the kinda sporty appearance, though I wish the lime green protective cloth under the Velcro straps was a bit wider and black.I've been wearing it constantly during the day, including when I drive, type or work around the house. I only take it off when I need to shower, etc. This brace feels quite comfortable and my thumb feels a bit better. Not sure what else you could ask for.Five stars!

I discovered wool dryer balls though a Facebook post--I'd never heard of such a thing! I chose the Smart Sheep 6-Pack XL Premium because of the thousands of positive reviews. It sounded like a good way to cut back on chemicals in my environment and save a couple of bucks in the long run.First, these little critters work perfectly. About the size and weight of fat, wool-stuffed tennis ball, you just toss these bad boys into the dryer with your clothes and rock and roll. No lint or wool fibers, no muss or fuss. I know people rave about "fluffy" clothes, but my clothes came out about the same as with dryer sheets, which was fine. I could tell no difference in drying time. Maybe a little more static, but I live in Houston where static is rarely an issue.Minor downsides:These balls kinda bounce around in the dryer and make a soft "thunking" sound. Not loud, but just a bit more noise than dryer sheets. Also, I always used the old dryer sheet to clean the lint trap, now I use my hand or a paper towel. No biggie, just a heads up. You also need a way to store these things so they don't fall on the floor or get dirty; I just leave them sitting in the dryer for next time.Anyway, five stars. The Smart Sheep 6-Pack XL Premium do what they advertise.

I bought the TEKTON 5941 Digital Tire Gauge after I misplaced my beloved old Brookstone dial pressure gauge. This is a real step up.Using this little critter is a joy. The brightly-illuminated dial and nozzle are clearly visible at day, night or in a dim garage. I only lose a whisper of air when pressing it onto a tire valve stem. The readout remains on the screen for 30 seconds; my old dial gauge lost the reading the instant it slipped from the valve stem.Other positives: they delivered it in two days with Amazon Prime. The price is more than reasonable. This gauge has a mufti-function readout some will appreciate (PSI, BAR, KPA, Kg/cm squared). And the jazzy red plastic casing makes it easy to find in a cluttered glove box.Negatives? Just some minor quibbles. You have to unscrew the case to access the batteries, though reviewers say it has a very long battery life. I would like a setting lock so it only displayed PSI. I wouldn't mind a heavier plastic or metal construction, though this looks pretty rugged.At the price, the TEKTON 5941 Digital Tire Gauge is a solid five stars.

The fragile USB port cover on my Galaxy S5 broke off and this is an identical replacement part. These things break all the time, so if you plan to use your Galaxy S5 for awhile, go ahead and buy two or three of these critters and keep 'em in a drawer. It took less than five minutes to open my phone, unscrew the tab, and replace the cover. I followed these You Tube instructions:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ZEBtx2O0FcThe only tricky part was keeping the black sticky tape under the tab in place to maximize the waterproofing. Five stars!

The UltraFire 7W 200LM may well be the biggest little bargain on Amazon. Made from aircraft aluminum and powered by a single AA battery, this tough little focusing flashlight is a jewel. It uses a white LED that is seven TIMES brighter than a standard flashlight bulb and waterproof in case of emergencies. The focusing mechanism is an unusual push/pull design instead of the standard twist design.At the price, get several and give them as gifts.

The Metro Vacuum ED500 DataVac is awesome! It is smaller and lighter than I expected--about the size and weight of a can of compressed air.  I use it to blast clean my computer, keyboard, monitor vents, and Roomba, but I also find it useful to dust fiddly, difficult-to-clean areas like my CD/DVD collections, books, behind and under furniture and bookshelves, light fixtures and refrigerator coils.I use it like an indoor leaf blower, herding all the dust bunnies into a handy corner, then dust mopping after it settles. I seriously suggest putting on a dust mask first! (O.K., so sue me; I'm not the best housekeeper.)They placed the convenient on/off switch right by the handle, which is handy because the powerful DataVac airstream produces a definite "kick" when you turn it on. The blowing power matches or exceeds compressed canned air, but without the danger of running out or spitting propellent onto delicate parts. For storage, I loop the generous 11-foot (not 12-foot as stated in the literature) cord and tuck it into the grip.Cons:One design flaw is that the air intake filter on the bottom is a sponge-like material that looks like it will get damaged pretty easily, and there is no easy way to replace or even clean this critter. And the DataVac is pretty loud; although in all honesty my vacuum cleaner is noisier. Finally, only one of the attachments "click" properly onto the nozzle's raised safety button--I had to drill holes in a couple of the other attachments to use this button. But I still call this a solid 4-1/2 star product.

This is my first self defense tactical pen and overall I'm pretty pleased. The dimensions are about the same as a standard pen but just a bit wider with a diamond crosshatch grip. The pen itself writes smoothly with black ink and opens (a little stiffly) by twisting the front. I was a bit disappointed to find that it does NOT write upside down.It isn't as heavy as I expected, but the tough aircraft aluminum still has a nice heft and terrific grip. I haven't broken any glass with the end or stabbed anyone, but I sure as heck wouldn't want to be on the receiving end of this thing! The tight clip and rough barrel might shred a dress shirt over time unless you use care. But this is a really good deal at the price.UPDATE: I managed to break the fragile plastic ink cartridge the first time I disassembled it. Largely my fault, but the cheap plastic cartridge didn't help. I replaced it with the superior metal Parker Ballpoint Pen Refill, Fine Point, 0.7 mm, Black, product ID 183145 from OfficeMax/Office Depot. Much better!

I just received the CyberTech 4400mAh Lithium battery replacement for my Roomba 770, so I can't address its longevity. Instead I'll just say that it takes about 60 seconds to swap out the original Roomba battery with this terrific upgrade. All you do is:1. turn off your Roomba (big button on top) and flip it over2. remove two little Phillips screws and open door3. pull out the old battery with the plastic side tabs4. drop in the new lithium battery5. close it up, power it up6. re-enter the day/time information. (All the programming data disappears when you pull the battery--no biggie.)I've used my Roomba 770 almost daily for a year and the original battery was getting a bit anemic, though still useable. But this lithium replacement is far better than Roomba's original Ni-Cd battery. Not a design flaw--it's just that the pricey lithium batteries are inherently superior to Ni-Cd batteries. And the build quality of the new lithium battery is, if anything, even better than the original.I like the extra little side brush CyberTech threw in, so I swapped it out at the same time. If your Roomba is getting a bit feeble and you have a few extra bucks, this is a worthwhile upgrade.

Eneloops are simply the best. This is my second order for 16 AA Eneloop batteries. Why so many? First, AA batteries power just about every mouse, remote control, flashlight, toy or doodad in the universe. Second, I found no-name D-cell adapters that take three AA batteries in parallel:http://www.amazon.com/Parallel-Connection-Battery-Holder-White/dp/B00K86RXQU/ref=cm_cr-mr-titleAfter Hurricane Ike, I stockpiled several dozen D cells to power lanterns and fans. After a year, easily 25% of my expensive alkaline D cells leaked corrosive crud all over the place! During the second year, another 25% failed. It got so bad that I individually wrap each D cell in a baggie before storing.So! I bought a bunch of AA Eneloops and a couple of dozen D cell adapters and couldn't be happier! As my old alkaline AA and D cells fail or run out of juice, I toss them and replace them with Eneloops. A permanent solution since Eneloops hold a charge for years, don't leak, and I can recharge them when they get low. Five stars!

I recently bought Canon's stunning 11-24 f/4L lens. Canon only supplies a ridiculous leather pouch with this $3000 lens, though, so the first thing I did was go shopping for a practical way to carry and store this bad boy.Acting upon a recommendation from another photographer, I bought the Tamrac MX5341. The Canon 11-24 f/4L lens fits like a glove! The padded rip-stop nylon pouch has a zipper top and the snap+Velcro-style belt loop works perfectly.It might be nice if there was another little pocket for memory cards or a loop for a pen or if it was a two-zipper design, but I'm really not complaining. A solid five stars.

I'm an unabashed fanboy of John Conroe's Demon Accords, but they've gotten a bit dark and disjointed recently. This latest book is a breath of fresh air--mixed with a hint of napalm. All the unusual kids who appear in the earlier books, including "Black Frost," are thrown into a university environment that makes Hogwarts seem like a school for wussy underachievers. You think you had problems with beer-guzzling frat boys? Try an aggressive werewolf or pushy witches circle!Lots of fun and action with more character development. Just about everyone from previous books makes a camio. And just when we figured we'd whipped the demons and elves and black op agencies, a whole new threat appears on the horizon. One that isn't a bit mystical and may be all too real.And the Barbie hunt? You'll see. Enough spoilers--buy this book. Buy it now!

This fun move varies a bit from the book, but the changes help smooth the story flow and makes the kidnapping less grim. A whimsical story that combines true love with a loose nuke and an enemy toad. And, of course, the penultimate "Florida Man."

I'm an editorial photographer and recently bought Canon's 11-24 f/4L lens. First, let me state that this unique ultra wide angle lens is not for everybody. It is expensive, but a bargain considering the nature of the lens. It is heavy, but relatively compact. This is NOT a lens that casual photographers should seriously consider. Instead, let me recommend Canon's marvelous 16-35 f/4L IS for general architectural, landscape and environmental portraits.But if you want the finest rectilinear ultra wide angle lens in the world, the Canon 11-24 f/4L is hands-down your best bet. Even wide open it displays virtually no distortion, flare or vignetting and is blazing sharp right to the edges. So far my biggest surprise is just how easily it handles. Unless something is near the edge of the frame there is no way to tell that you aren't using a standard wide angle.This precision 2.6 pound/1180 gram lens is built like a tank. It makes your camera front-heavy (I'm using 5D III bodies with grips), even when hanging from the strap. Not as bad as a 70-200 f/2.8, but you notice the weight. Canon made the built-in lens hood from heavy, high impact polycarbonate. The unusual lens cap wraps around the whole front of the lens hood to protect that massive bulbous front element.Since this lens cannot take a normal or drop-in filter, Canon placed a small 3 cm X 3 cm gel filter slot on the rear. While I dislike fragile gel filters, this appears our only ND filter option. The rear of the lens also sports a rubber weather sealing ring as seen on other high-end Canon "L" lenses. But the huge front element moves freely inside the front of the lens barrel when zooming, so I'd avoid situations where water or sand can impact the front.I've covered a fair number of editorial assignments with this lens in a television studio, low light "Good Friday" shots, working in crowds, rail car welding and some architectural photography. The Canon 11-24 f/4 handled surprisingly well; I genuinely felt no difficulties working fast, handheld, in tight conditions. Images were blazing sharp right to the edges with little or no flare even when shooting wide open against studio spotlights or daylight blazing though windows or an arc welder. This groundbreaking lens earns a solid five stars.NOTE: Canon only supplies a ridiculous leather carry pouch with this lens. I bought the Tamrac MX5341 M.A.S. Pro 50 Lens Case to carry and store this lens. A perfect fit.Unboxing video just for fun: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRC0op9b5VA&feature=youtu.be

I'm a photojournalist and own all kinds of fancy video gear, but sometimes ya just want to shoot a quick video with your smartphone. I went to my local Fry's and tried out a variety of phone mounts, but only the XL Joby GripTight Smartphone Tripod Mount securely supported my Galaxy S5 without forcing me to remove the protective case. The compact folding design is a nice perk. It folds flat to slip comfortably in your pocket or camera bag, but flipping the Joby GripTight open and attaching it to a tripod produces rock-solid support for professional-looking videos.It's a bit pricey for a phone mount, but the unique design makes this a winner.

Twangy country western music makes me want to hurl, but I'm a huge Archer fan. I bought "Cherlene" just for fun and am surprised how much I enjoy the music. Extremely well produced with excellent vocals and instrumentals with sly, almost subliminal, references to Archer episodes. Just a heck of good album; I found my foot tapping to the music as I wrote this.

Any writer who can call forth the avatars of Albert Einstein, Zathras, Sun Tzu and Al Bundy is a guy worth reading! A well-written book and I'm looking forward to more from this author. I am, however, deeply disturbed that I recognize almost every Sci-Fi nerd quote. Man, I gotta get a life!"Can not run out of time, there is infinite time. You are finite, Zathras is finite. This is wrong tool."

I'm a photojournalist and I bought the YOPO 180 Universal 3 in 1 just for fun. First, don't freak out when you get the package and find only two lenses and one clip. The macro and fisheye lenses attach to one another.These lenses should work on just about any device. I use mine on a Galaxy S5 and a Galaxy Tab 3 8 tablet. The lenses themselves are surprisingly well-machined and the glass appears coated, though ghost reflections appear if you are shooting against a light source or a high-contrast scene.All three lenses are satisfactory for the price. The 180 degree fisheye is a fun lens, though fisheye effects can get real old, real fast. The "Super Wide 0.4X" should be the most useful lens, but disappoints since it displays severe barrel distortion. The real jewel in this kit is the macro lens. You can just about fill the frame with a pencil tip and the optics are good enough that I would be fine using it for my editorial work.This is a bargain and a lot of fun!

I bought the SentrySafe H4100CG at a local brick and mortar store. Note that this isn't much of a "safe" per se. I suspect that anyone with a hammer could easily break the lock or simply carry it away; I just leave the key in the lock. I bought it to store personal and financial documents and a backup hard drive of zero value to burglars. I want to be able to freely access the material yet provide some protection from fire and flood.I'm even considering spray painting the SentrySafe fluorescent orange and stenciling "Personal Documents" for ease in location by myself or relatives after a hypothetical disaster. But that's a project for another time and I'm not sure I could tolerate a bright orange box!I particularly appreciate that this safe stores full-sized 8-1/2 x 11" documents and supports hanging file folders. Very practical and organized. Note that it is pretty hefty (duh!), though any healthy person can carry it. At the price, this is a solid five star product.

I use this with my Galaxy S5 and find it a terrific value for the money. Here are my impressions after several months:Pros:1. The Pebble has a solid vibration function that alerts you to incoming email, SMS and phone calls. I've found this quite useful in noisy or hectic environments. You can also set it to stop vibrating at night so it doesn't scare the bejabbers out of you.2. It's seriously waterproof!!! I had no idea. I bought it just for fun, but this thing can double as a dive watch.3. It quickly charges though any USB port and lasts almost a week! HUGE drawback for other smart watches. It also charges in minutes, not hours.4. Screen lights up for 1.5-2 seconds by pressing a button or shaking your wrist. It is quite legible in direct sunlight or night.5. I can control my phone's MP3 player right though the watch. I leave the phone in my pocket and control volume, skip or repeat songs, etc.6. It doesn't interfere with my car's Bluetooth phone setup.7. Lots of health tracking apps available. Not my cup of tea, but a big plus for health conscious folks.Cons:1. The e-Paper display is nowhere near as pretty as the glowing display on other smart watches. This is the tradeoff for that spectacular battery life.2. It's a bit awkward to navigate many of the apps with the stiff buttons.3.. Minimal instructions make it difficult to tell what apps are worth loading. Many (most?) of the apps are pretty marginal or difficult to read on the low-rez gray and black e-Paper screen.4.. Plastic appearance. Personally, I like my nerd watch to look nerdy, but some folks object. Option: the Pebble Steel or a fancy metal watchband.  I wish the burnt orange watch was one of the standard colors!5. Oddball magnetic/USB charger connector falls off easily. Needs careful placement and no jostling.Anyway, I'm quite pleased with my new toy and wear it constantly. At the price, this watch is a winner!

I'm a big guy, 6-foot, 250 pounds, so I had concerns about buying a plastic toilet seat. But the Bemis 200SLOWT000 barely deforms or moves when I sit. The heavy plastic seat has a solid hinge and four supports. The hinges utilize clever catches that let you twist and remove the seat for thorough cleaning in seconds, but it is rock-solid when locked in position.Though I don't much care about it, both the seat and lid s-l-o-w-l-y close when dropped. The appearance is relatively sleek (I mean, it IS a toilet seat--shrug) because the lid sorta wraps around the seat when closed to look like a single unified piece.Installation took about five minutes total. After I removed my old toilet seat, all I did was press this new seat into position, finger-tighten the plastic nuts, then tighten the ends. Bemis has a very clever way of avoiding over-tightening and damaging the toilet--the end of the plastic nut sheers off when it is tight. The only tricky part is that you need to verify if your toilet is elongated (18-1/2") or round (16-1/2"). I goofed the first time and got the wrong size.I'm not a Bemis fanboy, tho. The paint on my last three Bemis painted wood toilet seats wore and chipped off after a few years, looking horrible. I mean, how hard is it to paint a toilet seat so your butt doesn't destroy it--huh?But this one looks like a winner. I just bought a second Bemis 200SLOWT000 for a small bathroom. If I ever have a problem, I'll update this review immediately.

I replaced my laptop HD with a Crucial SSD a couple of years ago and it was a great upgrade, but when it came time to replace my desktop HD with a SSD, the specs on the 1TB Samsung 850 EVO looked just a bit better.Not only is the 1TB Samsung 850 EVO blazing fast, but my computer runs cooler, quieter and draws less power. I'm a photojournalist using Win 7 Pro, so I work with some pretty hefty visual software. Note that the SSD does NOT speed up Photoshop itself, but opening, closing and the user experience was infinitely better. Here's a few before and afters for ya:  HD vs. SSDboot to musical tone:  110 sec. vs. 27 sec.open Photoshop:  13.4 sec vs. 4 sec.Adobe Bridge:  9 sec. vs. 2 sec.Photo Mechanic:  19 sec. vs. 8 sec.NOTE: I suggest buying the Corsair USB 3.0 Cloning kit as opposed to using Samsung's software, however. I never got the Samsung cloning software to work properly, though the included "Samsung Magician" software worked perfectly and offers some useful tweaks for the SSD.Definitely a five star product!

I'm a PC guy and I used the earlier USB 2.0 version of this product to clone and replace a laptop's HD with a Crucial SSD. When it came time to replace my desktop's HD with a Samsung 850 EVO SSD, I bought this Corsair USB 3.0 cloning software. Good thing--I didn't have much luck with the Samsung cloning software, but this Corsair kit was dead easy.All you do is put in the disk (or download the software), attach the SSD to a 3.0 or 2.0 USB port with the included cord, and do a couple of clicks. One hour later, swap out the HD with the SSD and you are good to go. Everything was there and operated perfectly: Windows, hidden files, full-on Photoshop CS6, Photo Mechanic, etc. And, man--that SSD rocks!This might also be a simple solution for truly bulletproof backups. I put my old HD in a safe in case anything horrible ever happens to my computer.This is a great five star product!

I'm rating one star to get your attention, so don't go nuts on me.This is a wonderful, funny movie that I watched several times in theaters when it first came out. But my DVD locked up 2/3rds the way though and would not proceed. I'm using an top-notch Sony Blu-ray player with the latest firmware. I got a bad DVD. Not worth the hassle of returning.Just a heads up.

I bought the Grace Digital WiFi Music Player to stream internet radio though my stereo system instead of mucking around on my computer or cellphone. Setup was easy and connected through my U-verse WiFi with no problem. Display and presets are clear, bright and easy to navigate. It sounds quite nice through a real sound system, so I put my mp3s on a thumb drive and plugged it into the rear USB port (because sometimes ten thousand internet stations just aren't enough!)It helps if you have at least a nodding familiarity with internet radio. I've messed around a bit, but it is easy to get swamped by the thousands of goodies out there. Also, pay attention to the kps of the streaming music--more is better.Note that Grace has a handy free app for navigating the stations and radio from your cellphone or tablet. Some (O.K., a lot of) folks hate this app, but I like the visual information offered more than the standard remote control.The Grace music player itself has a built-in mono speaker and a big internal space for a battery if you want a standalone setup or bedside clock/radio. Personally, I kinda wish I had bought a smaller unit without the space for the battery or speaker, but after several months I'm quite happy with my purchase.

I sooooo wanted to love this stuff. I've got a porcelain tub, circa 1960, that is always a pain to clean. Nothing special, just hard water calcium, soap residue, a bit of rust and the dirt/grease that builds up on white porcelain from hands.I scrubbed the entire tub with Bar Keepers Friend using as instructed and it really didn't do much of anything. I get as good or better results using Comet cleanser with bleach. Most of the cleaning results came from scrubbing like mad with a green 3M scrubber.Maybe this stuff will work on pots and pans or other surfaces, but it was pretty useless on porcelain.Disappointed.

If you've never attempted a plumbing upgrade, let me first warn you that this is one of the most unpleasant household chores out there. I had to laugh at Pfister's "how-to" video with its pristine, perfectly-fitting hardware and roomy, well-lit conditions.In my case, I first had to remove my old faucet and drain. It was a study in slime, rust and corroded parts while almost standing on my head to wrestle with awkward stuck fittings. And the horror that slimed out of the P-trap could give a buzzard the dry heaves! In addition to the tools suggested by the instructions, may I suggest a single-edge razor blade, green 3M or copper scrubbing pad, flashlight, dishpan, several rag towels, aspirin and lots of patience. Suggestion to Pfister: it would be nice to include a dab of plumber's putty for the base seal.The finished project looks truly sleek and elegant, but the water flow is much slower than my previous "el-cheapo" aerator faucet. I measured by filling a glass and it took four times longer with the new Pfister Jaida faucet. Still, it is a totally functional and gorgeous upgrade!

My beloved Logitech K740 keyboard finally started failing after 3-1/2 years. After soliciting advice and checking reviews, I choose the CM Storm QuickFire TK with Cherry MX Brown switches. Quite a radical change!BAD/UGLY:Not as sleek and low-profile as the Logitech K740, the tops of the QuickFire keys are pretty high--roughly 1-1/2 inches above the desktop. The overall appearance is square, rugged and looks like they made it from repurposed Soviet tank treads.The arrow keys and navigation keys are incorporated into the number keypad. This saves desk space, but sometimes makes things a bit awkward.GOOD:Bright white keys are sharp and easy to read. All keys and spaces between are illuminated. I keep the key illumination on its lowest setting to avoid dazzling my eyes while editing photos.Clicky! MAN, I've missed using a keyboard with mechanical key action! I bought the model with the Cherry MX Brown switches whose action feels "just right." A bit noisy compared to standard keyboards, but it's a joy to use.Reliable. This bad boy is rated for tens of millions of keystrokes! I'm sick of keyboards going bad after a year or two. The solid construction can really take a pounding.Removable USB cord. Not sure if this should be a "pro" or "con" feature. I've accidentally unplugged the keyboard a couple of times. This keyboard uses a standard USB to connect to the computer, of course, but it also uses a micro-USB that plugs into the keyboard itself for ease of storage and transport. The braided cord attaches to a slot underneath and feeds out a left or right or rear channel.I'm still getting used to this new keyboard, but it earns a solid 4-1/2 stars. If I ever have a problem, I'll update this review immediately.

I'm a photojournalist and used an incident light meter to compare the standard 2AA Mini Maglite bulb against the TerraLUX TLE-5EX MiniStar2 Extreme LED. The TerraLUX LED measured roughly seven TIMES brighter than the original krypton bulb! I'm still seeing spots before my eyes.The LED produces a pure white light and the replacement reflector smooths the beam spread better than the original reflector. Factoring in the longer battery life, this is a major upgrade for this little workhorse flashlight.Don't hesitate--this is a solid five star upgrade.

I bought a couple of these Phillips 10.5-watt LED bulbs to replace two deck lights. The color closely resembles the standard warm white light of incandescent bulbs or warm CFL bulbs. The unique flattened doughnut shape is made of tough plastic and screws into a standard light socket. Heat output is minimal. Even after burning for hours, it feels warm, not hot.I haven't tested the dimming ability of these bulbs, so I'll just skip that feature. But I think the manufacturer might be a bit optimistic about the light output. I would judge it--maybe--as bright as an old fashioned 40 watt incandescent bulb. Still, this was exactly what I wanted for my back porch, so I'm a happy five star camper!

After over 20 years of reliable use, my old Maglite AA Mini Flashlight was ruined when both AA alkaline batteries leaked, jammed and badly corroded the inside. Well, this gave me an opportunity to replace my standard black Maglite with a jazzy red model. The red color makes it a bit easier to spot in junk drawers and glove compartments. The flashlight projects a powerful, focusing beam. Removing the reflector allows it to act as an electric "candle."Maglites are manufactured of tough aircraft aluminum and sealed with rubber "O" rings making them ideal for foul weather emergencies. The included rip stop nylon holster grips the handle snugly.  These things last just about forever and I replaced the bulb once in 20+ years. They even include a spare bulb in the end cap!Although I'm using the included alkaline AA batteries, I'm going to replace them with AA Eneloop batteries. The Eneloops work just fine and do not pose the danger of ruining my new flashlight.Update: I replaced the standard krypton bulb with the TerraLUX TLE-5EX MiniStar2 Extreme LED Upgrade for Mini Maglite 2AA Flashlight. The light is 7X brighter (seriously--I measured it!) and a clean white color. Good upgrade!

I'm a career photojournalist and bought the 16 GB Eye-Fi Mobi to use in my Canon 5D III. In theory, I would love to capture RAW files on the CF card while transmitting lower-rez jpeg images to breathless clients when working in the field. Unfortunately, Eye-Fi Mobi's flawed app and intermittent connectivity issues make it unreliable for professional work.The setup was easy and I successfully transmitted photos 30-40 feet to an Android smart phone and Android tablet in another room. Unfortunately, the app's clunky user interface on the phone/tablet only occasionally feeds and displays properly. I kept having to exit and restart the app to get the current image to display. This is a software issue and could be solved IF the Eye-Fi folks bother to tweak their free app.A more serious issue was that my camera kept losing the connection with the smart phone/tablet if I stopped shooting for a minute--even while the camera remained powered up. Then I had to shut everything down on the camera AND Android device and start them all over again from scratch.This device has tremendous potential for professionals, but right now it is just too darn unreliable. Professionals need a bulletproof, reliable connection that works full time. But it is a pretty neat option for people on vacation who just want to email or post a couple of photos to Facebook using their "real" camera.

I just bought a bunch of Eneloop batteries and wanted a top-notch charger. The Titanium Smart Fast 16 Bay Charger fits the bill. Key points:1. You can charge 1, 5, 9, 16 or ANY combination of AA or AAA rechargeable batteries. This charger acts like 16 individual chargers; you DON'T have to fill individual bays.2. I'm not a fan of LCD display panels, but the cool blue LED lights do a great job illuminating these displays. And every--single--battery has its own individual readout!3. The 16 Eneloops I bought needed a bit of charging, so I filled all the bays in the charger. The batteries got fairly warm, but once they completed charging, they cooled back down as the Titanium switched to a maintenance trickle charge. I had no misgivings about leaving them charging overnight.4. You also have the option of discharging/recharging batteries simultaneously. You can put batteries you want to discharge/recharge in one bay, while doing standard recharging in the next bay.5. This charger has two USB charger outlets and a car charger plug for emergencies and road warriors. Nice touch!Very minor downsides: I wish they put screw holes in this charger so I could mount it on the wall. Also, it stinks! Pretty strong burnt plastic/chemical smell that I hope will disappear with time.A solid five star product!

I've used these Mysterious Purr Padd Cat Cushions for over a decade when they were named something else. I just bought four more to replace my old shredded cushions. I put one in a cat carrier, another in a "cat house" built over my kitchen wall, and a couple more on shelves. Cats just love these things! They are warm and scratchy and soft and cats take to them instantly.But DON'T leave them outside if your neighborhood has squirrels! Seriously. Squirrels just attack these things to use as nesting material. The polyester is so light and fluffy it ends up dropping all over the yard, then the dumb squirrels gather it up again and it scatters even further. And the squirrels do it again, and again, until non-biodegradable fluff shreds are everywhere. One day I actually stopped a squirrel that was going up a tree hauling an entire 20X20" mat! I finally learned my lesson--indoor use only.

I'm a career photojournalist and use identical Manfrotto hexagonal quick release plates on all my gear, with matching connect adapter plates on my tripod, monopod and Manfrotto Super Clamps. I bought these critters over 20 years ago when they were still named Bogen and use them to this day. They look and operate like they were new.I keep quick release plates attached permanently to my 300 f/2.8 and the collar of my 70-200 f/2.8, with a couple of extras loose for camera bodies. I've used them for remote cameras at Space Shuttle launches, attached to the wing of an airplane, architecture assignments, sporting and spot news assignments, fireworks, and a building demolition. Solid as a rock.Note that these plates come in a couple of versions. One version uses a flush-mounted screw that attaches to the camera or lens collar with a screwdriver or quarter-sized coin. This model is nearly identical and uses a standard tripod-type double screw that you hand-tighten.--One downside--Note that some of these plates use a cork face to grip against the camera or lens collar. Over the years, the cork gets chewed up and starts falling apart. I eventually replaced the cork on a couple of plates with tough rubber gasket material attached with contact cement. Problem solved.

I use identical Manfrotto hexagonal quick release plates on all my stuff, with matching connect adapter plates on my tripod, monopod and Manfrotto Super Clamps. I bought these critters over 20 years ago when they were still named Bogen and use them to this day. They look and operate like they were new.I keep quick release plates attached permanently to my 300 f/2.8 and the collar of my 70-200 f/2.8, with a couple of extras loose for camera bodies. I've used them for remote cameras at Space Shuttle launches, attached to the wing of an airplane, architecture assignments, sporting and spot news assignments, fireworks, and building demolition. Solid as a rock.Note that these plates come in a couple of versions. This one uses a flush-mounted screw that attaches to the camera or lens collar with a screwdriver or quarter-sized coin. There is a nearly identical version that uses a standard tripod-type double screw that you hand-tighten.

I'm a photojournalist and used these Wasabi LP-E6 batteries in Canon 5D II bodies with no problem, so I bought two more more when I upgraded to the 5D III. I'm using the latest firmware (1.2.3) and the batteries register and communicate with the cameras perfectly in the camera's body or when using a battery grip. From prior experience, I don't think the Wasabi batteries last quite as long as the Canon's, but the difference is negligible.I do wish they had included two chargers with the two batteries, but my Canon chargers work fine on the Wasabi batteries. For the price, this is a solid five star product.

Okay, you've heard plenty about this excellent camera already. But if you are getting ready to pull the trigger on the 5D III, keep reading.I'm a photojournalist and missed the recent Black Friday deals and rebates (grump!) Suddenly my work changed and I simply HAD to replace my current 5D II bodies with two 5D III bodies. I saved about $600 by checking out the "used" deals. I bought two completely NEW, UNUSED cameras that simply had the 24-105 kit lens removed from the box. Everything else was in there, unopened, and the cameras untouched with the original warranty.I've shot hundreds of assignments with the 5D III cameras and am loving the heck out of them! Compared to the 5D II, the 5D III offers far superior focusing, better low light sensitivity and six frames per second. The "quiet" shooting mode works great at concerts, churches and other venues where you need to remain inconspicuous. The single drawback is that Canon crippled the SD card slot rendering SD almost useless for action photography. With that one exception, it is what the 5D II should have been.Update: after a year of professional shooting, I'm more pleased than ever with my two 5D III bodies. Low light sensitivity appears to be a solid two stops better than the 5D II, and the little-discussed "quiet" mode for shooting is a wonderful addition for working during plays, concerts, churches, etc.

I'm a big fan of John Conroe's "Demon Accords" universe, and "Executable" does not disappoint. This time Conroe introduces us to a young warlock and a young "something" on the run. You think vampires, werewolves and government plots are bad? Try surviving the horrors of high school!Conroe shows us the flip side of the usually treacherous witches with his usual flair. I was a little concerned we wouldn't see Chris and Tanya this time, but halfway through he meshes this story nicely into previous books. Well done, John; looking forward to the next one!

I'm a career photojournalist and bought two of the Vello BG-C9 battery grips for my Canon 5D III bodies. I'm impressed with the build quality and the exterior finish matches the camera's perfectly. The Vello fits flush against the 5D III with no annoying gap or wiggle, and you stash the camera's battery door safely inside the grip if you want to switch back.I recommend this grip to any serious photographer. Reminiscent of the old-style motor drives, this grip has a vertical shutter release button (plus other controls) that let you securely handle the 5D Mark III even with a big 70-200 f/2.8 or 300 f/2.8 attached. It also helps counterbalance the camera when using a speedlight.The Vello BG-C9 grip adds a second LP-E6 battery slot and gives you the option of shooting with six AA batteries in an emergency, guaranteeing power even on all-day assignments. The 5D MK III battery info display lets you track individual charges, health and shutter counts on both LP-E6 batteries.DOWNSIDES:This sizable grip makes the 5D III quite a bit heavier and bulkier, and I spoke to an aerial photographer who wasn't happy with the extra weight. It helps if you have big hands. Plus I wish Vello had placed a rubber gasket where the battery drawer slides into the grip. But I recently shot an assignment in the blowing rain where I got soggy as a flounder. Although one of my cameras quit twice, the battery grip wasn't a factor; the water leaked into the camera though the lens and top panel.All in all, at the price, this is a solid five star product. If I ever have an issue, I will update this review immediately.------------UPDATE. O.K., I promised to update if any problems arose. After a year of hard service, one of my Vello BG-C9 grips developed a weird problem. It still powers the camera, but the camera's LCD display does not show?! If I use the other grip or just power it with the standard camera battery slot, the LCD shows up fine. Just ordered a replacement Canon OM grip, darn it.

I'm a photojournalist and used these Wasabi LP-E6 batteries in Canon 5D II bodies with absolutely no problem. I recently upgraded to Canon 5D III cameras with 1.2.3 firmware and they work fine there, too.When I first insert the Wasabi battery in a Canon 5D III, I get a message "Communication with Canon LP-E6 battery is irregular. Continue to use this battery?" I simply hit "O.K." and everything works fine. No chip or communication problems.Though I haven't done a rigorous test, these batteries might not last quite as long as Canon's OM battery, but they are still fine for an all-day photo shoot. At the price, these Wasabi batteries earn a solid five stars.

The short summary is:PROS:*best picture quality of any TV ever made*deepest blacks possible*most amazing 3D I've seen (and you can use the "passive" glasses from a movie theater instead of battery powered ones)!*4K/UHD*plays HDR content!*thinner than some phones, and bezel-less so all you see is the amazing picture!*cool Wii-like remoteCONS:*very high defect rate (see below)*expensive*very little 4K, HDR content currently available*some gamers didn't like the input delay (I don't notice it)*400 nits of brightness is good, but is one area where future OLEDs may improveFull review:SOME EF9500s are about the most perfect picture you're ever going to see. It's literally the darkest black levels possible (no light output  at all), surpassing even the best plasmas and LED local-dimming sets. At the same time it's as bright as any LED/LCD set, so you get the best picture pop you've ever seen, even at off angles!Unfortunately, the near perfection of the set is marred by a high defect rate on the 65" (almost all 55" models are fine) with problems ranging from not turning on, to bad ghosting with 3D imagery, to yellow or pink banding evident in all-white scenes, to reduced brightness near the edges of the screen.If you're lucky enough to get one of the good sets, you won't be disappointed! If, on the other hand, you paid over five grand for set with problems, you might be.However, if you're willing to put up with an exchange or two and you're the type of person willing to pay a mint for the best TV ever made to date, this is your set.This is my second uber-expensive TV set I bought in the past few years (the other was a Sharp Elite), and while I had to go through one exchange to fix a problem, I'm blown away by how much better the picture quality is than even the set I paid five grand for only a few years ago!It's simply amazing!

I have a three-year old Frozen-loving girl who loved smoothing Play Doh around the figurines and a 6 and 8-year old who loved playing with the molds.Everyone had fun with it, and it's probably my kids' favorite Play Doh play set (which is saying something).If your little ones like Play Doh and Frozen, then this is likely to be a hit!

As a wireless speaker, this thing is pretty great for the price; excellent bass, decent clarity. It's high-quality audio with a wireless, rechargible battery.The problems I faced were that there is a rhythmic pulsing whenever playing audio while the unit is plugged in.Furthermore, I tried to contact support about the issue only to discover that email inquiries go unanswered, while calls go to a robotic-voiced automated system where you can only leave an unanswered voicemail during limited business hours.As such, I really can't recommend the speaker and would suggest going with a more well-established company with better quality assurance and support.

I've had cheapo Revgear gloves, cheapo Titles, a couple pair of Venums and now these, my first pair of real-leather gloves.My impression? The leather is great, construction is great, they certainly feel more breathable and supple than the polyurethane gloves I've been using (the breathability is especially nice, because I sweat like a pig).I have average-sized hands and thought the hand compartment was perfect, and the foam in the gloves is exceptional compared to what I'm used to! The gloves actually feel thinner than my 16-ounce Venums, and the foam feels like it distributes impact a little better around your hand, despite the thinness.However, the other thing I noticed (beyond the rather retro styling) is that the foam seems concentrated more towards the knuckles, and not so much near the relatively thin fingertips. For boxing, that's great, but the finger padding may actually be a little thin for Muay Thai, which has a more hands-turned-out blocking style.If, however, a nice, higher-end boxing glove is what you're after and you want something a smidgen cheaper than competitors, you won't go wrong with the Ringside Pro Styles.

These are pretty great for a PS4 head seat. The mic works well, the audio is satisfactory and I LOVE that it comes with its own rechargeable powered amp!I found the surround sound effect to work well for first person shooters where surround sound makes an important strategic difference in game play (knowing where enemies are).However, these aren't audiophile-quality headphones by any means (they're good, but not great) and, in fact, I found volume to be a little quiet at the loudest setting unless I was using the battery powered "super human hearing" amp.Nevertheless, if you want a good value in gaming headset and don't mind not having thumping, impactful bass and crystal-clear audio, this is a great set of headphones to buy!

Jabra continues in their tradition of excellence with these headphones. I've been a big fan of their Bluetooth headsets in the past (like the Jawbone) and this is another excellent addition to their lineup!Cords are always a big hassle when running and I was delighted to try these out since you can simply recharge these, pop them in, and go about your workout without a cord flapping between you and the phone strapped to your arm or waist.The fit of the earbuds is solid, and it fortunately comes with a variety of earbud sizes to fit your personal size/tastes.The companion app is also nice, and does seem to improve audio quality with its default equalization, but the app is much less usable to me than my phone's native app, so I ditched it pretty quick.The only negative is that it's easy to forget to turn off, which results in the headphones running down their battery and intercepting audio of the YouTube videos I try to watch in bed! That's half my fault, though, so I can't ding them too much for that.Great headphones all in all!

For vegan protein, this is very, very good stuff.It tastes great, mixes well and has a wide variety of sources, none of which are cheap, estrogen-containing soy, so this seems to be a good vegan protein for men, too!They brag about having mushrooms in the ingredients, but what they don't mention is that one of the mushrooms is coryceps, which is a fairly effective athletic endurance supplement that I've taken by itself with some success!They didn't seem to skimp, and I like it!Here's the ingredients list, since it wasn't posted on the Amazon page at the time of this review:Organic Plant Protein BlendBrown Rice Protein, Quinoa, Amaranth, Mushroom Blend [Reishi, King Trumpet (Pleurotus eryngii), Lion's Mane (Hericium ernicaceus), Cordyceps, Himematsutake (Agaricus blazei), Turkey Tails, Shiitake, Maitake]22.3 g **Organic Greens BlendFermented Grass Blend (Barley Grass, Alfalfa Grass, Wheatgrass, Oat Grass), Spirulina, Chlorella3.41 g **Organic Fermented Fruit & Veggie BlendCarrot, Cranberry, Blueberry, Apple, Broccoli, Parsley, Spinach, Kale500 mg **Digestive BlendEnzyme Blend (Protease, Amylase, Glucoamylase, Invertase, Diastase, Lipase), Probiotics (Bacillus coagulans)

This is my first pair of shin guards as I started dabbling with Muai Thai, and I found them to be great for my needs.I'm 6'1", 215 lbs with long, skinnier legs and I found that these fit pretty well.The padding was adequate, and the color actually decently matches most of my other equipment.I'd say they're a great starter set at the very least!

We liked this. It appears generally well made, and we need it because our small kids still occasionally wet the bed.The bed bug protection feature is nice, too, with their populations spreading as much as they are.The downside to this design is that while other mattress protectors are more of a fitted sheet, this is designed to protect more area, which means it's a little harder to take on and off.Then again, you don't have to deal with the hassle of the "fitted sheet" popping off of the corner.Good buy, overall.
