But you can plug it in and charge it for 15 minutes and be able to shave your whole face and then some.It has a timer that tells you how long you have it turned on and how much battery you have left, that's awesome.It's very powerful, it shaves better than one plugged into the wall. And has a super close shave, like a blade.Cons:The price.He expected the trimmer to work better than it did.It should have a charger stand for the counter, for how beautiful it is, you should be able to put it on display instead of laying it down.It didn't come with a cleaning brush.In the end - they really do like the shaver but would not pay $$$.  Only time will tell if it outlasts it's price tag.

I really like this laptop.  I only use it for emails and quick searches so it works fine for both these things.  It's a great size and slim with a nice screen for viewing. I was worried about Win 10 since this was the first but it's a lot like 8 so that was easy as well.It's a great size to slip in a tote or work case and it's lighter than my original Toshiba.  Much lighter and compact to carry daily.

Love Huggies - not only are they affordable but I have always preferred them over the other name brands.  These Size 1s are tiny but will work perfectly for the newborn in the family.  Elastic is covered with inner material and seems 'soft' enough.  Absorbency is fine though we don't leave them on her any length of time.  A little tinkle does it but she seems happy in them....as far as we can tell.  I like the inner lining and adore the Winnie print!
Stunning faucet.  It's well made, heavy duty and will fit in any dcor.  Easy to set up on our vanity and so far it's working perfectly.

Love the Tena No Rinse wash cream for my brother.  He's wheel chair bound and is heavy to lift for a shower every day.  This works great and doesn't dry his skin like other creams I've tried.  First tried a sample from a nursing home and decided to purchase - it is that good for my brother.
Burned long and wick stayed straight without burying itself in the liquid wax.  Perfect for our Ball glass jar centerpieces.

Very happy with this product.  I've always used Scotts brand but this seems to be sprouting even in the driest area of our yard.  It rained the night I spread this and then was completely dry for days (not extremely hot, but very dry) and I've got noticeable new growth already in just 2 weeks.  Very pleased.

I really love this bag.  It's made of quality materials and is sturdy.  Has the tips on a flat bottom for easy resting and a few gold studs on the handle to set it off nicely.  The pockets inside are a plus - organization is at it's max because this isn't just an open bag with one small side pocket -they've truly thought of just about everything and made a few extra slots for it.  I'm holding back one star because it hasn't been used "hard" yet so only time will tell how the handles and seams hold up.  I also am not one for brand names so I'm really shy on the price.  I wish I could say it's worth $200 but honestly I just won't pay that for any handbag or tote.

Stunning timepiece - slightly involved with settings as the instructions are included for an alternate model and caused some confusion at first.  The inside workings create a brilliant face.  If I were to mention one negative remark it would be this -  It has a leather band but for this intricate face, I believe a metal band or even a smooth leather band would have enhanced the watch more.

Nice idea but arrived with broken candle tips so I was unable to try it.  And really looks cheap, seriously cheap.  I received this free for a review and I'm happy about that because if I paid money for it and counted on it for a party ---- I would be highly disappointed.

I love these tablecloths - They're durable and do have the intricate lace detailing.  The one thing I will mention is that food and debris get's into the design and can be hard to wash - however I have washed these on a gentle (warm) cycle and they're beautiful!

Son absolutely loves this belt.  He's 17 and says ... "Mom I don't need to wear a belt but this just looks great!"  The leather is strong, the buckle is too.  Nice quality!  Edit:  Came back to say that we realized the holes have grommets or are reinforced and they don't pull and stretch like most.

I was so anxious to get back to Acrobat after the default Lenovo on my system.  I'm not sure if I've gotten used to the Lenovo but I'm finding it difficult to get through this Adobe program.  It's like anything else - you have to be prepared for the learning curve and give it due time to grow on you.  As other users stated - I'm not one for the "cloud" for anything.  I like stand alone products that I do not have to rely on internet service so that option does nothing for me.  For my own personal use and home office, this item is a bit overwhelming and alot of functions are not needed.  Time will tell if this is user friendly but, as I said, be prepared to learn because it's not open and GO....

This looks phenomenal - well built and what the boys want!  Ages 6 and 8, this will be for Lucas' (6yr old) birthday in the coming month.  I will be back to let you know how it works after they give it a go.Things I can say at this point:  be prepared to buy batteries, lots of them.  It's 12 at the start and that's a hefty 'add on.'Be prepared for the kids to want all the additional characters and at $14.99 each - those will be hefty add ons too.At $100+ initially it's a bit pricey so think about your kids and if they're going to enjoy it longer than Christmas morn.Pluses -  they're going to get up and move!  Fortunately we have boys that play outdoors but for those of you that don't --- this is a way to integrate their 'gaming' habits with physical activity.

Always nervous when changing things that are hooked to the computers but this was almost as simple as it gets.  The one and only thing I hoped to get -- that my son can get wireless in the basement weight room & NOT use his phone time for tunes....and holy s***e it's spreading fast internet through this big house!  Totally amazed that the other routers we thought were good - weren't!

These are a really nice size and a heavy plastic.  We actually used them on a giant slip and slide we made this Summer.  They made it through 4 full hours of adults and children, full grown men, women and little ones too.  The one and only thing - they are awful to blow up without a compressor.  The safety in the stem is on the verge of being 'permanent' - can't even squeeze it to get air in more easily.  Other than that - worth the $$.  Wish I would have gotten different colors - all three were pink and the boys didn't care for that.
Absolutely loved Season 1 and had to have it as soon as it was released.  No issues and sent for delivery on release day.

Whew it's something to put together so right of the bat I would wish that it were at least partially 'folded' so it takes less effort to assemble.  It's sharp and modern looking but it is, in my opinion, flimsy for the price tag.  If you can get kids to work at the station then it's a good thing but my kids want to curl up in a comfy chair and read, not stand.  Not the best but as long as they're reading and retaining, I won't argue.I realize the benefits from 'standing' and working this is a great concept but it's just not sturdy enough for myself or my employees.  They also told me that it takes more space than they are willing to "give up" and they would rather stand to write on the racks than get on and off a seat that isn't an actual seat.All I can say is be sure it's really going to be used and then check all the reviews.  Some are much more expensive but the height and weight limits are higher and the item could be better made.

OMG this battery charger is the best thing going!  I started to try it and my dad came and decided that if I didn't want to keep it in my car - he was taking it.  Not only is it perfect for the big items like your car, lawn mower and boat motors but it has the usb and can charge the cell, the laptop and yes, my dad's vapor cigs too!  Good Lord - can't ask for a better gift for the guy in the family or the needed car accessory for the girls (and they don't even know they need it yet)!Again - great item, heavy weight, durable and charges just about anything you need in the car or at home.

I was offered the backpack for an honest review.  The construction and the canvas as well as the appearance is definitely a plus...love the look!However, it's small so if you're a college or high school student you'll need to search for a larger one.  Another thing IMO are the padded straps - they are very thick but if you can't carry a lot, then is that really an asset?  Last - the shoulder straps have the metal loops to slide straps for length.  In my previous experience this is a pain because the heavier the pack gets, the more they slide or pull.  It's well made, there's not disputing that but I would definitely make sure the size will be appropriate for your needs.

Buy Bulk & Go For It!  If you have the space to store freezer foods, live in the country where buying bulk is a necessity or a game hunter - this one's for you.  We do have venison to butcher once a year but this is particularly useful for bulk purchases from Sam's Club and Costco.  The name 'Game Saver' is not as straight forward as 'Food Saver' - and this is a food saver, you do not have to be a hunter to enjoy the benefits.Anyone that uses a sealer and loves it, this is out of the park.  My favorite benefit is the machine width that handles larger pieces of meat.It pushes through products and sealing like a champ.My least favorite part - it's bulky and big.  BUT you can't get a 15" width without some type of counter...It's not for the faint of heart.  If you only do minimal sealing then consider a smaller unit.  But if you're into cost savings and bulk buying - this deserves consideration.
The best vise-grips going.  This set has the two most used in our household so after losing my dad's pair, I found these and grabbed them.  They have the wire cutter on both and a tight hold.

I opened the pen and box and followed the directions.  Simply took the pen apart and plugged the end with USB in to the computer slot.  After charging I continued to follow directions and it works perfectly fine. The sound quality and video is acceptable for the pricing of the item.It's well made and sturdy, actually a bit heavy. The one and only thing that I've noticed is that is NOT a pen.  There is no tip in the bottom so if, for instance, you keep this in your pocket you have to make sure you have two in case someone wants to borrow 'a pen' else you'll hand them this bogus item and the jigs up.  Or if you're holding it in your hand as a pen, but actually to record, there is no tip for authenticity.

I was offered this in an exchange for truthful review.  In truth - it's amazing that something this small can record and playback with clarity.  I haven't tested the full 15 hours yet but that's an entire day of college classes plus more.  Long gone are the days of a big black microphone or bulky recorder on the desk to grasp notes and nuances.  Absolutely love recording college professors because it's amazing how you can pick up the more important tidbits by their phrasing and audio fluctuation (which will most likely land on an exam.)All in all it does what it states and is fun for kids and adults.  May be a bit overpriced in my opinion but just plain dandy !

A little awkward to use at first but once you get the hang of it - it's perfect.  Squeeze the juice from 1/2 lemons.  Just cut in half and put in cup then I have to use two hands to squeeze the juice.  What remains in the cup is the rind and the seeds.  This is a heavy duty kitchen gadget (not made cheap at all.)
This grater / zester is great!  It works just like it's supposed to and it's sharp.  I also like the quality plastic sheath that slides on it to protect while in the drawer.
Oh I love this stuff - the stress relief before bed clears my sinuses and I don't know if it helps me sleep but it damn well makes me feel calm when I'm in the shower cuz I just like the aroma!!

This Eureka is fine for quick pickups of lightweight dust and fine debris but it's just that - for quick pickups/spruce-ups.  I find this works fine between regular vacuum cleanings.  It's best for stairs and vehicles and over furniture but if you want a good vacuum for floors you'd be better off spending the money on a 'real' vacuum.What I like - easy to grab and lightweight to run on area carpet under table.  Switch to do tile with ease.What I don't like - it's a short handle at only 44" extended.  So even at 5'4", I seem to be bending to reach under the table.Cleaning it - hate it.  Says it has a cup and it does however all the dust and fine dirt sticks to the bag inside and doesn't drop in the cup.  It makes such a mess trying to clean off that bag using a brush or cloth.  VERY messy (so do it outdoors) and maybe this process will get easier with time but my first impression and suggestion to you - do more research before purchasing.  I can deal with the fine debris and hair quick pickups but cleaning that tank...hate it and my allergies dislike it even more.  I managed to spread the dust back into the air just to return to it's original place........the floor.

There's not much one can say about a crock pot - I received it yesterday and put in a roast overnight.  Works perfectly and there is one BIG plus on this pot - it actually has a 'warm' setting.  Those of us that use crock pots know that the low setting still cooks the crap out of your items.  This warmer setting will be a very nice feature for parties.  Nice design too!

Interesting concept - easiest set up and completely adjustable using the app.  My favorite "plus" is that they can be turned on before I get home at night or if I'm away.  Least favorite is the cost.  I was offered these for a review - I would not have spent this amount on two light bulbs.

Stunning lacey blouse to wear over a tank.  It's so pretty and the color is gorgeous.  Watch the colors vs lace patterns though - at the time of this review there are three different lace patterns on this one sale page. It's unfortunate that all the colors do not come in each pattern - I probably would have purchased more colors of this particular one.
Not the most expensive but sturdy and protect the knees when painting the deck - I can't ask for anything more!
Nice set of tools and the right price too!  I was told by my "handy guy" friend to get Channellock because they were good.  I always thought Craftsman was best...so only time will tell.

One of these is now holding my large scissors and two screwdrivers in the shop.  I would suggest getting the longer strips if you have more than that to hang because 12" isn't that long.  The other thing I wish - that it didn't have the writing on the front.  I have a craft painting shop and it's kind of pretty until you look at the counters and see these black bars with words telling me what the item is.  I could have gotten another brand that was solid color but opted for this because of price and reviews.

This Bissell is well made, light weight and is easy to understand and put together.  The battery charged in a few hours and I was able to test on the carpets stains.  It does wet the carpet so you want to stay off that area until it thoroughly dries.  It's much more convenient to move around than a full size cleaner but you spend a lot of time on your knees or basically standing on your head while you're working on spots.  I'll more likely use for our vehicles, furniture and stairs but not on the carpet.  If I have to scrub a spot, I'd just use a good cleaning solution and a brush then pat with a towel to soak up water - same thing at less cost.

Product offered free for a review - I like the dvd and the band idea - however the bands are flimsy.  The light weight bands feel like they'll snap at any time which is concerning when you're pulling them between your arms or legs.  The thicker bands won't budge.  The photo on the box is almost impossible because the bands aren't long enough to put around two legs and pull that far.  I think the bands need improvement.

Was asked to try the Brainwavz for an honest review.  What I like most would be the flat cord.  It's bendable and comfortable - the inner cords are protected and shouldn't split easily which is a great plus.  The buds themselves are comfortable but I do wish they had the outer ear piece to hold them in place.  I found them to be loose and falling out whereas if they had the c cup for around the ear they would be stable.The sound - it improves the sound of my iPhone so all in all I like them a lot!

Absolutely disappointed in sizing.Gorgeous material but order up 3 sizes at least.  In addition, the sleeves are stitched under the arms but after that inch of stitching the remainder of the seam down to the bottom is open.  So reach for something and you'll see your bra, side of torso.  Just seems like that should be stitched farther down the side seam.  And if it were true to size, we could have stitched it ourselves and kept it but we have to return because it's not even close to a 4X. I ordered larger size because of reviews - this is more like a 14 than a 22.  The bust is especially tight - def problem with sizing.
I love the aroma of this stuff!!!!  Wish I could find something a bit more affordable but until I do, I'll keep buying this one.
Nice belt for dress however for the larger man I wish the buckle had rounded edges (the pointed square edges aren't comfortable when sitting down and you're belt is pressing into your 'gut'.

Cabinet is ok but I was hoping for a bit more sturdiness.  Also the doors don't latch and stay closed - I'm using this outdoors and one bump and the doors open, the wind catches and then the cabinet is open to the elements.

At first glance I was a bit overwhelmed as we only use a small Oster for everyday things and a very large grinder for the canning season.  This item replaces almost every like appliance in the kitchen but it takes up the space of a large microwave.  The power is great and it does an incredible job.All removable pieces are dishwasher safe - so we washed everything before use.  One thing that I didn't like is the handle.  There is a black handle encased with a clear, larger one.  When I removed it from dishwasher - the clear handle had condensation (and water droplets) inside which tells me it will grow mold because there's no way to dry it.If you like a food processor (or the idea of one) and have the space, this is a nice unit.  Especially with the caddy that holds all the extra parts so they aren't flying around a cabinet or drawer.  If you've never used a processor - consider the smaller, easy to store and quick use gadgets like a flat grater, 2 cup chopper, mandolin, etc.  I love this processor but I won't be getting it out everyday when I need to slice some cucumbers for dinner or grate cheese for a salad.  So it won't be replacing the gadgets in my kitchen.  The smaller ones are easier to use, no assembly and quick to clean and put away (not to mention lifting!)What I like most - it does everything from dicing to slicing to grinding - potatoes to cabbage slaw.  I like the caddy that holds all the parts for storage and the suction cups on the base are a nice plus too.What I like least - the size. It's huge and not only is the main piece with cup and lid big but it has a 'caddy' that's bigger than the base to hold all the parts.  The other thing that is a disappointment - I thought this would be perfect to make our freezer pepper hash because of the big 4 cup bowl but the gadget that does the hash can only be used inside the 2 cup insert so that's a drawback for us.  This just means that I won't haul this big one out because I can do the same in my smaller 2 cup grinder...so there's no benefit in that area.Keep in mind we're working in a country 'farm' kitchen and we don't put a lot of stock into owning the 'new' gadgets - I suppose, all in all, I prefer the smaller single pieces than this all in one.  They're easier to clean, easier to store, lighter, and not complicated.  So if you can't afford a processor, don't worry about it - I've given you ample reason to stick with the more affordable, smaller tools.With that said - the Black n Decker processor is a perfectly good choice at a reasonable price if you just have to have one!

Gorgeous material and print - not a fan of the straps.  I thought they were plain straps but they're like a ruffle hanging from it and that I don't like.  In addition - the bust is small in my opinion.  This made it look tighter on front which is acceptable but it was also tight behind my arms and that 'back fat' thing was a complete turn off.  I think the chest needs more room while the waist is full enough for the size.  Best bet is to order a size larger for the bust and then the fullness in the drape would fall into place.
Absolutely gorgeous print and soft, silky type material unfortunately these were about 6 inches too long.

Absolutely love the hammered finishes - I have the hammered black on everything that needed paint!  I've been searching for the hammered white and thankfully found this spray - Rust-Oleum is losing one star because they don't offer this in a can (I don't like to spray items.)Anyway -  if you have old metal furniture, planters, tables that are rusty and pitted - this hammered paint is exactly what you need.  You can paint over the rust (just wire brush the loose debris from item) and the paint looks like it's getting air bubbles in it (and it is!)  Then the bubbles disappear and it appears like dimples in the paint and the finish is incredible.  This paint is amazing for hiding all the flaws on the item and the hammered gunmetal (black) is stunning.My new favorite paint for DIY projects of all kinds.  I've used it on wrought iron railing, outdoor metal stands and even on a wooden dresser.  I always strayed away from anything high gloss because you can see ever flaw in the finish.  This paint eliminates that problem.

The Little Guy, my daughter hasn't named it yet.  is great on all levels.  It is a very versatile toy for a broad range of age groups.  You could put it in front of a baby that has the ability to sit up on his/her own and they could clap and wiggle around to the songs. The flashing lights on the belly are very intriguing as well.The Amazon description states it's for 9 to 18 months so I wasn't sure if it would work  for my 2.5 year old - when it arrived, the package states 9 to 36 months - so please keep in mind that there's an error on the page and this item has a longer use span for kids.For my 30month old daughter it is very educational.  It teaches colors, the alphabet, and the freeze dance song is a great energy burner and a great tool to teach them that freeze means stop and they have to wait for the next cue.  I will certainly buy this for all of my friends' kids.  It was especially helpful when I was trying to make dinner and Hallie wanted to be held and was under my feet, she picked up Little Guy and worked up a sweat dancing.  I LOVE it!

My daughter is into anything coconut these days - sugar, milk and now we tried the syrup.  It's actually more the 'idea' that it's made from coconut than the taste.  Personally I would have liked some of that flavor.  We don't use much syrup but this is an alternative to regular syrup.  The use ratio is one to one --- and the counts are still high on this product so is there a benefit over all natural maple syrup?  It seems to (my opinion only) that any 'fad' can have the word organic slapped to it and people flock to the counters.

The HP-LINK AC1900 Wi-Fi Dual-Band Range Extender is just what I've been needing. I've tried several other, less expensive solutions, and none of them have worked for us. We live in a two-story condo and our modem is on the ground floor, leaving us with spotty Internet connectivity upstairs. The last extender we tried just made things worse.The TP-LINK set up very quickly and easily (contrary to other reviews which express frustration with the process, and I'm no tech guy) and within minutes was up and running and improving our Internet upstairs. I can now work at my desk top without suffering from high ping, It scarce needs be said that this also improves my online gaming experience. We can also use our smart phones more enjoyably.Upstairs prior to the TP-LINK, I had a ping of 38 ms and a download speed of 25.96 (supposed to be 64) and an upload speed of 3.10. After installing the TP-LINK, my numbers went to 19 ms, 27.12, and 3.15. If I connect directly to the TP-LINK with an ethernet cable plugged into its Gigabit Ethernet port, my numbers go to 11 ms, 35.52 and 3.21. A subsequent firmware update for my Netgear router was just icing on the cake, and I now have respectable Internet throughout the house.I place the TP-LINK outside my bedroom door, making it close to all the rooms upstairs. It sits on its base (as shown) or on its side equally well. I put it there for convenience. I had previously placed it in our bedroom but I did not move it because of what another reviewer called "blinding status lights" (I didn't think the lights were at all annoying, and neither did my wife, who normally abhors any lights at night).Highly recommended and well worth the price.

I owned an iHealth Edge and loved it, until the strap opened up and it fell off and was lost. So when I saw the scale, I was more than wiling to try it. I still have the iHealth app on my phone and it seemed therefore a good match.The scale is slim, not overly large (about a foot square) and lightweight (about 5.5 pounds) and attractive to boot. The digital read out is easy to see day or night. It is no problem finding a spot to keep it when not in use. We also have a Weight Watchers scale and testing the Core Body Analysis Scale I found that the iHealth consistently weighs me in at .5 to 1.5 pounds less than the WW scale. It weighs my wife more inconsistently. I don't know why. I don't know which is more accurate.The iHealth scale's instruction manual is pretty slender, as most are these days; they want you to use their online manuals, in this case found at http://www.ihealthlabs.com/files/3614/4425/9451/HS6-OM.pdf, (Quick Start Guide here: http://www.ihealthlabs.com/files/8114/4191/0002/HS6-KSZP01_V2.0.pdf) but you can get it set up easily enough and linked to your iHealth app fairly easily as well.So far so good. The only problems I have had is getting it to actually work like its supposed to. I can't get the scale to measure my body mass index, and register my weight on the app (which is the point after all). You are supposed to be bare-footed and to stand on the sensors. No matter how many times I or my wife try, it fails to register this reading.The instructions offer no help in this regard, nor can I figure out why my weight won't show on the app, even though the app synced with the scale.I appealed to the online owner's manual but it is the same size and uselessness as the manual.No matter how often I try, it won't work. Which renders the Core Body Analysis Scale a basic scale for more money than you should have to pay for a basic scale.I think it would be great if it actually did what it was supposed to do, but it doesn't, and therefore I cannot give it more than 2 stars.

This is just a great soundtrack. I used to watch this movie growing up, back in the days before cable TV and I can remember how much you could look forward to these things before the era of instant gratification. It was always and literally a rare treat. I used to have an LP of the soundtrack and to have it again on CD is amazing. It is not only highly evocative and powerful, but it brings back happy memories of enjoying a great film.These days, I like to listen to soundtracks like this while I read Roman history or even while I play games like Total War: Attila as music to build empires by.This is an excellent quality recording and I know you'll enjoy it.

It is difficult to know how to review this product, because unless you experience upset stomach, which I do not, or pump iron, which I do not, it is difficult to know if it is doing anything being giving you a slight energy boost, which I can get much more pleasantly from a V-8 energy drink. Perhaps I simply do not use enough of it to make an appreciable difference.I like to make smoothies and shakes in the morning to get my day going, which is what brought me to try this product. We use a variety of powders  (see below) for this and I put the ingredients in rice milk, when I can get it, though lately I have had to substitute "rice drink" thanks to my local grocery stores.Maca powder, the packaging says, is "high in protein, fiber, vitamin C, B vitamins, calcium, iron, potassium, copper, manganese and fatty acids." However, if you look at the Nutrition Facts more closely you see that in fact it has only 2% of your Vitamin C, 2% of your iron, 2% of your calcium, and only 1 single gram of protein (also only 1 gram of fiber).I don't know what this company thinks of as "high" but this product is not it. If my blood sugar were crashing and I needed a pick-me-up quick, this would not be the powder on my shelf I would choose. You would have to use a lot of powder to match what I get from my VEGA All-in-One Nutritional Shake powder (which I also reviewed here) - about 10 tsp by my calculations.You might also want to note that if you're allergic to peanuts, this product is packaged in a facility that handles tree nuts.I have read the other reviews, about how the Maca powder smells like yellow cake mix (it does not - it made me gag). I do not recommend taking a breath - the smell once the package was opened permeated the air of my kitchen. I put a teaspoon in a glass of rice drink and stirred it up. There was apparently just enough liquid - I had to top of the glass to get the powder to fully dissolve. I stirred it well and took a sip and though the taste is unpleasant, it is less unpleasant than the smell. I gulped it down to minimize the effect but still have to drink water afterward to wash the taste out of my mouth.I feel as a result that the powder is best mixed with something else to hide the taste, and that is easy enough to do with the addition of fruit or bananas, and with other powders. I do not recommend drinking it alone. I have not tried it in baking simply because I am on Weight Watches and bread is very expensive in points.In the end, I gave it three stars as "just okay" because, taking T. Lane's review about the identity of the product and my own experiences, I cannot say anything more positive about it than that. It works if you need more energy; it's just that I can think of more pleasant sources of that energy.

Gone are my days of owning big stereo systems. In the digital age, I use small Bluetooth speakers around the house, sync them with my phone and play tunes that way, as often as not. I still have a CD player but I use it less often, and it is downstairs. For my office upstairs, something like this is very useful.I can go upstairs, sit at my desk, open up Amazon Music on my phone and play from my own offline library or from Prime Music. And this is better quality sound than the smaller blue tooth speakers I have. One reviewer was critical of the base but I found it perfectly adequate. That might depend on what kind of music you listen to and your own tastes.Additionally, it gives me the ability to talk on the phone without having to hold it, which would interrupt my work. It features:Bass Reflex Speaker System delivers a powerful, deeper bassWireless music streaming via BluetoothBuilt-in microphone for hands-free phone callsBuilt-in rechargeable battery for music playback anywhereUp to 5 hours music playbackAdditionally, it's reasonably priced and not bad to look at, meaning it won't look out of place on a shelf or window-ledge. It's only a little more than a foot long and half a foot wide, so it doesn't take up a lot of space.I agree with the reviewers that the instructions are a mess. They typically are these days, more like hieroglyphics than intelligible directions. But I got it set up according to what seemed common sense and it didn't take long. I didn't take the sticker off the front so I don't know if that experience is common to all. It didn't really bother me much.You can certainly buy more expensive Bluetooth speakers, but you get your money's worth with the Philips BT3080. I give it 5 stars.

This is a great book, very easy to read, and very informative on a wide variety of topics and historical periods going all the way back to before Europeans trod North American soil.The Longest Trail is a collection of Alvin M. Josephy, Jr.'s writings, each article introduced with a brief commentary by the editors, putting the piece in context. They come to this collection from various sources: A Continent Awakes comes from the book "500 Nations" (1994) while Tecumseh: The Greatest Indian was published in 1961 as part of Josephy's book, "The Patriot Chiefs" and Cowplanter, Can You Swim? is taken from his 1982 book "Now That the Buffalo's Gone."I came of age on books like "Red, White and Black" (1974) by Gary B. Nash and "Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee" (1970) by Dee Brown, books which really introduced me to Native Americans as something other than movie antagonists. If you haven't yet discovered that Native Americans belong in American history, you should pick up a copy of The Longest Trail and find out why it is so important that they become part of our historical landscape. If you are already aware, read The Longest Trail anyway, as it is full of rich detail and insights that will only deepen your understanding.All of the included essays are excellent and display the breadth of Josephy's interests. You can read them in order, as I did, or skip around to the subjects that interest you most. There is something for everybody interested in Native American culture, history, and politics. It is a book that belongs on every historian's (professional or amateur) shelf. Highly recommended and easily 5 stars alone for the obvious love and compassion Josephy shows for his subject matter.

My son likes the WWE and he has both the Rumblers, which I no longer see in stores, and the larger 9" figures, like this one. He is also a big fan of the X-Box 360 versions of the WWE games. One of his favorite things about those games has been creating his own wrestler and outfitting him, so when he saw these new Create a WWE Superstar sets, he was very excited.He sat down right away and began to fashion various forms of Triple H, and played with his figures, which he hadn't done for awhile. There are several other of these sets he said he'd like and I told him to add them to his Christmas list. The various pieces seem to snap on and off fairly easily. He had no problem with any of them, and he showed me how easily Triple H could be transformed by swapping out just a couple of pieces, like boots and helmet.The face is even a reasonable likeness of Triple H and they certainly captured his build.It's a neat idea and I can't imagine other kids not liking it as much as my son. Recommended. Five stars.

I am unable to give a comprehensive review of this product as I turned out to be one of those people who gets unpleasant gastric side effects.I did do some research and I saw that the strength of these tablets is in the recommended range (70% HCA - recommended was 60%), and I don't know what to make of the potential hazards of taking supplements like this, so I won't address that here. I didn't plan on taking this long term anyway, so wasn't really concerned about that.However, I did take it for two weeks and I did not notice any reduction in appetite between meals. I am on Weight Watchers and already losing weight, but because the meals are smaller and there is less snacking as part of the diet, I wanted something to suppress my appetite in between (and if possible increase my chances of losing weight).One problem with supplements like these is being able to know when you are going to eat, so you can take them sufficiently in advance of your meal. I don't always know when I'm going to be able to eat so my experience might have been affected by this fact.I did not see either of these things during my two weeks using it so either I did not take it long enough, I didn't take enough (as another reviewer pointed out) or it simply didn't work for me. Given my experience, I gave it two stars.

Spike is pretty cute, as most Beanie Boos are. Of course, his spikes are really a bit of a mess unless you carefully brush them out, sticking up all over the place, and you can't really see his face as well as you can in this photo because it is pressed to the floor or whatever surface he is sitting on, but kids will love it and if you have him on a shelf at eye-level he will do his best to steal your soul with his sparkly eyes.

I was a long-time PhotoShop user. Then I switched to PaintShop Pro when X6 came out. It was a learning curve for me, and I still don't feel like I've attained my level of skill from PhotoShop days, but I've become familiar with the program and enjoyed using it. Now that X8 has come out, I've upgraded rather than switching back to PhotoShop.It's not that PhotoShop is easier to use. As another reviewer has said, PaintShop might actually be easier. It's just a matter of familiarity. The software installs quickly and there are some freebies you can download as well. It's a pretty straight-forward proposition getting started (there is also a pdf manual) and it's not a huge departure from X6, so if you are used to the previous versions you can easily step into X8. If you need help, as always, there are a plethora of sites with tutorials and how-to's.There are some obvious improvements, like text wrapping. This is a great feature. You could take an image from the web, for example, select the shape using the "magic wand tool" and then begin typing inside it. The text will automatically wrap to fit (make sure the font is neither too large nor too small to do the job). Or you could copy text from somewhere and paste it into the shape. it may take a moment or two depending on the length of the block of text, but it will appear in the selected shape.I don't know if X8 is actually faster than X6, because I am not using the same computer, but it does seem to operate smoothly and without long delays loading. If you liked PaintShop Pro before it is safe to say you will like this latest upgrade. It is certainly a powerful and versatile tool and I cannot imagine lacking anything you might need.It is also a bit less expensive than PhotoShop, which never hurts, and I've yet to find anything I could do on Photoshop that I can't do on PaintShop once I become familiar with how to do it. Like I said, it's just a matter of becoming familiar with the new software and that requires using it. I'm enjoying it immensely and I think you will too.

I ordered this for my wife, so that she could bring some order to her things that otherwise accumulate on the bathroom counter or under, or which have remained unused since we moved for want to space.It is easy to set up. It is completely assembled. All you have to do is attach the two hooks to the back, which hang it from the door (it also comes with brackets, anchors and screws so you can mount it on the wall). The final step is attached some of that pull-away tape to the bottom of the cabinet so that it does not bounce around on the door when in use. The hooks are adjustable so you can put the unit where it works best for your height.It is quite spacious, which is nice, but the space is somewhat wasted in that you can only put the shelves and storage bins in particular places, or they will come into conflict with the racks on the door. They have little holes, making it look like you can move them around, but you can't. So if you have grand dreams of flexibility with this set, drop them now or face disappointment.This limitation means that you cannot set it up to match the particular items you want to put in there, and some may not fit. This is the problem my wife ran into. So while it does help your organizing, it is not the absolute answer to it, which is why it gets 4 stars instead of 5. On the other hand, the mirrored door was well-received and the little mirror inside at face level is also nice. Finally, the door locks and you receive two keys. Something to keep kids out, if nothing else (or roommates, I suppose).All in all, a decent unit and worth the money, but it's a shame they didn't make the interior more flexibly designed.

This is good lotion. Like some of the other reviewers, I've tried many different lotions. Some are annoying because of the scent, some just don't see to do anything. But this stuff works. I mean, it makes a noticeable difference. My skin doesn't get easily irritated but my wife's skin is sensitive and she has noticed an immediate relief from this even after one use.My son has a mediport and keloids from several surgeries and he is always scratching, which isn't good around a mediport, and we are using this on him as well.I like the fact that it isn't scented and that you don't feel like you have to re-apply it several times a day. Like another reviewer I like that it's thick but I didn't notice the greasy residue thing. I thought it absorbed well and that was one of the things I liked about it.I think its well worth $6 and I certainly plan on keeping this lotion on hand, especially with a hot summer coming up.

This is a great Viking axe. It is identical to Ragnar's on the television series. It comes with a display rack. You will have to screw the hooks in that hold it, and the plate has an adhesive backing, which you will have to apply to the rack. It also comes with a certificate of authenticity. This was a limited edition so I don't know how long it will be available, but they do make a less expensive version with a less attractive display rack. I don't know if the axes are identical, however.It is about 2.5 pounds and has a nice feel in your hand. The blade is not sharpened and the axe head is a little loose, so if you wanted to make this an actual weapon it would take some work. I plan to slip mine into a frog and wear it to the Renaissance Festival as part of my woodsman's outfit, when it is not hanging on the wall to admire. All in all, it's as beautiful a reproduction as I've ever seen and well worth the money spent.

I absolutely love this loveseat. It is not only beautiful, but exquisitely comfortable. We replaced an old sectional we had when we received this, and bought the matching recliners to go along with it because we liked this so much. It is a huge upgrade in our livingroom. It was painful to get up from the old sectional recliner, but this loveseat is firm and comfortable and I don't find myself sinking into it, and having the feeling that I'm climbing uphill to get out.The pillows are also very comfortable, if a bit large for the loveseat, but I don't mind their size as much as I thought I would. The fabric is attractive and comfortable and the leather backs even softer.The loveseat is 66 inches long and the seating area is 44 inches, with the cushions being 21 inches deep. Plenty of room for two people. It is not only comfortable to sit on, but comfortable to lie on as well. My feet dangle over the arm, but the arms are soft. I fell asleep the other night reclining on this loveseat and had no discomfort at all an hour later when I woke up.The loveseat arrived in a large, heavy box. It was protected by a thick plastic wrap. The feet were in a separate bag tied with leather straps over the top. They were easy to screw into place. The pillows were also in a separate bag. This loveseat is heavy and it took two of us, me and the delivery man, to bring it into the house (out of the box).As a side-note, we went to Ashley furniture to look at this while we were waiting for delivery, and Ashley does not sell this exact set. This is apparently made by them specifically for Amazon.com. They do have something similar under another name. But it was cheaper for us (even with them on sale at Ashley) to buy the matching recliners from Amazon thanks to Amazon Prime.Delivery was expensive through Ashley (not to mention a 2-4 week wait) and we would have had to pay extra to have them haul away our old sectional. We gave it instead to a friend to use in her basement for extra seating. Amazon got the loveseat and the recliners to us in a couple of days, again, thanks to Prime.I highly recommend this loveseat. By all means, check it out at Ashley if you want to see how terrific it is, but order from Amazon. It's far less of a hassle and you'll have it much more quickly.

My son likes this towel and that is the important thing here. I personally think it is a little thin, but I've not owned a beach towel in many years and haven't seen one in stores yet this spring to compare this too. I do know that even the cheapest of bath towels is thicker than this, and that for $22 I can get a much nicer bath towel than I've ever bought.On the other hand, this is terry cloth and and so it is absorbent, it's light and can be easily folded and rolled to fit into a small bag, it's big enough for a kid and it's got the Avengers on it, and it's not for me. These are things that you must take into account when buying a beach towel for your child. And its meets all those criteria. He needed a towel he could take to school for swim classes and not get teased about, and I can honestly say, purpose accomplished.I can't in good conscience give it 5-stars simply because it is so thin, but that might be just me being unfair, or maybe just a difference in preferences. The point is, that if he saw this in a store and he needed a beach towel, I would not be averse to buying it for him. Most beach towels here at Amazon seem to be between 12 and 20 dollars so the price of this one is not outrageous.

These are a huge hit in my house. My wife and son compete to see who can eat them. Of course, getting kids to eat things that are good for them is not easy, but if the food tastes good, the problem is solved. And these taste good. My 10-year-old's first comment was, "There is a lot of fudge ton this!" And indeed, there is a very thick layer of chocolate on top.My wife likes the fact that they do not have a medicinal aftertaste and that while having a lot of flavor, the taste doesn't overwhelm you - there is a nice blend of peanut butter and chocolate. You definitely get your money's worth where chocolate is concerned. Oh, and they are gluten free as well, and finding good-tasting gluten-free products has not been easy.You get bars not only chock full of tasty goodness, but healthy goodness. We also use Vega's All-in-One Nutritional Shake (which I have also reviewed here) and are very happy with both these products, because they always seem to have more of what's important, and less of what's bad for you.For example, my son has been taking Special K Protein snack bars to school with him. These have 4 g. of protein. The Vega One bars have 13 g. of protein. This is as much as a Totino's pizza. So it is literally as much as you can get from many meals, if you look at various processed foods. The Vega One bar has 3 g. of fiber while Special K has 4 g., but the Vega One bar adds probiotics, Omega-3, and antioxidants in addition to the vitamins.The Special K bars have no Vitamin A but Vega One has 32% DV; Special K has no Vitamin C but Vega One has 33% DV; Special K has 2% Calcium while Vega One has 22%, and so on. Down the line, pitted against every other product we have used, Vega One wins hands down. Even the protein powder my wife brought home from a nutritionist is out-shined by the Vega One product.I highly recommend these bars. We are trying some of their other flavors because we liked this one so much. Highly recommended. Would give it more than 5 stars if possible.

No other way to say it: I love this book. I am a fan of dystopian futures (at least in fiction!) and this one does not disappoint. You have elements of sci fi, horror, zombies and even the apparently supernatural (remember that anything technologically advanced enough seems like magic). You have a hardy and determined band of survivors and implacable enemies (not just one alien race, but two), and a quest. It doesn't get better than a combination like this, and McCammons' telling is masterful.The protagonist is a young boy, of about 14 or 15, named Ethan, who does not remember where he came from or how he came to be running, feeling the terrible enemies fighting around him. Though his role is central to the story, he is far from alone, as we meet other survivors along the way. On either side stand warring alien races, the Gorgons and the Cyphers, as the humans have come to know them. There are also the Gray Men, cannibals who resemble zombies but who are far more terrible both in appearance and abilities.The humans must fight through the alien landscape earth has become, and their adventure is not for the faint of heart. This story is graphically violent and the reader is not spared the horrors of war. The story is full of action, free of awkward info-dumps, and long on character development. I thought the dialog excellent and the motivations and reactions of the characters believable, given the circumstances. This is a thrill-a-minute ride and you won't want to put the book down.

This is a neat little Bluetooth speaker. I was attracted to it not only by its size but by being able to use it for a phone speaker. There are times I want to use my cell phone speaker but the sound is not good enough to make for easy conversation, particularly if there is background noise. I have used this, however, and can hear quite clearly.There is a small amount of distortion or echo in the other person's voice but you can hear them. The only downside seems to be that unless you are very close to the speaker, or speak loudly, your voice doesn't carry as well to the person calling you. Then again, some voices carry better than others and I'm not one of those with a booming voice. I'm not sure how do-able a conversation would be if you're any distance from the device. I have not tested it with everybody or under all conditions. I'm sure the other person's phone has an effect on sound quality as well.That aside, the quality of music is great, and that is still its primary use. I use it for listening to music on my phone, or for plugging my mp3 player into it using the jack. The batteries run for a long time on a single charge (10 hours they say) and I've gone pretty close to that without needing to recharge. The music can get quite loud without any noticeable distortion, and in fact, I have not been able to turn it up all the way because it's much too loud.It comes with a handy little draw-string sack that holds the speaker and cords, so you can easily carry it with you wherever you go, and can pack it into a bag or purse or backpack. It works well in a car too if you don't have an older car or lack a jack for your mp3 player. In a saturated Bluetooth speaker market, I'd still say the RND Ripple Wireless speaker is well worth the price.

I have used various nutritional supplements. Because of heart disease I have to watch my weight and what I eat. For example, I've used Muscle Milk, which offers 32 grams of protein in two scoops (I use one, so 16 grams). By comparison, Vega offers 20 g of protein in one scoop. It also tastes better. The calories are about the same, but Vega also gives you a lot less sodium (25 g vs. 80 g).They do not contain the exact same vitamins, but where a comparison can be made, Vega is equivalent to or superior to Muscle Milk, for example, 90% daily value of vitamin A compared to 15%. Vega also has less sugar than Muscle milk, though both contain negligible amounts, and sugar, they are saying now, is the big killer.I like to mix my shakes using rice milk because I am lactose intolerant and we sometimes throw in things like bananas and kale and fruits of various types. I have found that taste-wise, Vega more than holds its own. I am very happy with Vega and will be buying it from now on in place of Muscle Milk. I think it is well worth the price and highly recommend it to anyone watching their nutrition for health, exercise or weight control.

This is a decent piece of furniture for a kids room. It's fairly heavy and bottom-heavy at that, so it seems less likely to tip than other pieces I have seen. The bins at the bottom are a nice touch, esp. for a younger child with lots of loose toys you might want to quickly gather up and put someplace. My son's is full of wrestling action figures and a couple of wrestling rings. They are surprisingly spacious. I have to say I was impressed by that.As for the assembly, two of the part which came with mine were damaged, a chip in the bottom piece (barely visible when assembled) and one of the decorative pieces on the bottom, which is a little more visible but not glaringly obvious. I can only assume they were broken before packing because the way these pieces were placed in the box, I don't see how they could have been damaged after.The instructions were so-so but then they usually are. One step seemed to be missing entirely, and when I went back and checked, I still could not find it. There is, as usual, minimal printed instructions, but the illustrations make the steps reasonably clear. It fit well together, all the hardware was there, and all I needed was a hammer and Phillips head screwdriver.I didn't have to work very hard to get pieces aligned. There were some other places where the finish was cracked or scuffed but these are barely noticeable. All in all, as I say, a reasonable piece of children's furniture.The only real downside is that the price is somewhat high, I think. I don't often spend that much on a piece of furniture I have to assemble myself, but I can't deny it looks good against the wall. And the frame at the bottom where you can put photos or other pieces of art is a nifty idea, so your child can personalize it. My son was impressed by that. And now he has a nice looking shelf to hold his movies and books, and I am able to throw out a couple of smaller units I've had for a decade or so that are far less attractive. Despite the price, I do recommend it.The only reason I do not give the unit 5 stars is because of the scuffs, chip and broken piece.[Update 3.20.15] I contacted the manufacturer about the damaged pieces and replacement parts were sent out immediately and arrived on my porch in a matter of days. I am changing my rating from four stars to five as a result.

I really enjoyed this book. It's a young adult book but I liked the plot outline and I have to say it lived up to its promise. It's a light read. Despite what the back cover says, this is not Steven Erikson or George R.R. Martin, and the political intrigue is mostly second- or third-hand. Though the plot is not overly complex, it holds together well, and the setting is a familiar one - a sort of alternate history/fantasy Tudor England. The story is well-told, the pace is brisk, there is character development, and the actions and dialog more than the descriptions tell the story.Elizabeth Grey is a Witch Hunter, and she is very good at her job. She apprehends not only witches, but revenants (dead people who refuse to be dead, live forever and are extremely powerful), necromances, wizards, and all others who fall under the purview of Tablet XIII of the law. She does her job willingly and efficiently though it leads to the deaths of many, burned at the stake.  One day, she is accused of being a witch herself and thrown in prison to wait her turn to burn.Since the book's jacket gives this away, I'm not offering up a s spoiler when I say the realm's great enemy, the witch Nicholas Perevil, is the one to rescue her, not her best friend and fellow witch-hunter, Caleb. So off she goes to discover that all in the world is not as it had seemed, and that the world is not black and white, but nuanced in ways she could not have imagined. Perevil has a dangerous mission in mind for her, that will help not only him but everyone else - including herself.I like that Boecker wastes no time with lengthy descriptions, though I'd like to know a bit more about the world (France is called Gaul - so what else is different on the Continent?), and she works as briskly with magic, letting you see how it works rather than explaining it. There are both positives and negatives in her approach, but it works because the story does not bog down at all, but moves more at the pace of a Jason Bourne movie.As I said, I really enjoyed it. It's a light and easy read, the characters are likable, the dialog well done, and it met all my expectations. It's a quick one though, so I hope the author gets to work and offers us some more about these characters and their world. There is romance enough for teens, but not enough to ruin the book for the rest of us, and like everything else, it is well done.

I ordered these because my son has to spend several hours each week in a clinic. He had worn out his old earbuds and could not rely on the hospital having a pair available. I didn't want to transport the headphones he uses at home because they don't fit well into his tablet bag. I thought these would be cheap but serviceable, but it turned out they are better than the headphones he uses at home.This is not only because they fold up and are small enough to transport without worrying about damage, but because the sound quality is better. His old headphones are Sony MDR-ZX100, which, I think, are actually more expensive (by a dollar or two) than the Pioneer. But he swears by the Pioneer sound quality (he called it "HD sound") and uses them exclusively.So definitely worth the money I would say, if you're looking for an affordable set of headphones.

I want to start off by saying I did not finish reading this book. I got half way through it and lost interest in the characters and the story line. For me, this always signals the ultimate failure of a book. Sometimes, as in this case, reading something that really was well written - Tigana, by Guy Gavriel Kay - exposed this book's many weaknesses.At the half way point, there was no connection established between the Celtic witch and the ceramic artist. The Ceramic artist Tilda was still mourning her lost husband and had not encountered a "new love" although she had just started spending time with a young man from the village, but since he is the only person she is spending time with, there is an assumption at this point, that he is the love interest in the second half of the story.At the half way point, the only animal that is drawn to Tilda is a dog. The only "power" that Tilda has encountered is her ability to short out the electrical system of anything she is close to, including her entire house which makes heating and lighting a trick.The level of depression and grief that Tilda is going through makes this book heavy to trudge through and she isn't sympathetic enough to make it worth the effort.Since Tilda is a ceramic artist, and Seren is a Celtic shaman, I don't know at this point who the "Silver Witch" in the title is referring to. Perhaps that is revealed in the last half of the book but at this point it is more like two separate stories set in the same location separated by generations, rather than two lives connected in some way across the years.I really think that there is a "tipping point" in any book, a point at which something has to happen, where the protagonist has to come to a decision or take some action (for me, this was the failure of Robert Jordan's saga of endlessly whining characters). Paula Brackston still had not arrived at that point when I gave up, and it was long overdue.So all I can say is, if you chose to read this book, do so eyes wide open and at your own risk. It may be a great finish if you can get past the severe depression and lack of interest in the first half. I just couldn't wait for any potential payoff at the end that was by no means guaranteed.

Tzvetan Todorovs "The Inner Enemies of Democracy," is an interesting book. Todorov, who grew up in Communist Bulgaria, is not interested in the threat of totalitarian regimes, which has disappeared with the collapse of the Soviet Union, or in the threat of Islamic terrorism, which he says is not a credible candidate for the role of enemy that was formerly held by Moscow.He is interested instead in the threats to democracy that exist because of democracy itself. Democracy, he says, cannot be reduced to a single characteristic but is the balance of several principles, arguing that,The people, freedom and progress are constituent elements of democracy, but if one of them breaks free from its relationship with others, thus escaping any attempt to limit it and erecting itself into a single principle, they become distinct dangers: populism, ultraliberalism, and messianism. Those inner enemies of democracy.This is not an exhaustive list, he says, for those who might be looking for mention of theocracy or corporatocracy, but only those he is interested in having spent a third of his life in a totalitarian state.He singles out populism and demagoguery, and what he calls political messianism, which is a lot like religious messianism, only that it lacks a messiah. Its holy focus is not heaven, but a sort of heaven on earth.As examples, he points to the French Revolution, Marxism/Communism, and imposing democracy by bombs, a category made familiar to Americans since the Wilsonian principle of making the world safe for democracy. Here his warning is that justice is highly selective and that there is no justice which can be found through war, asking if it is okay to kill hundreds to save a few.Todorov paraphrases French Revolutionary Saint-Justs spirited activism, saying that Once the good has been attained, it will of course need to be perpetuated. And how it has been perpetuated, by the French Revolution, by the Communists, and, of course, by the United States of America.This brings him to a discussion not only of Afghanistan and Iraq, but what is called neoliberalism and ultraliberalism, which he says, in its devotion to unbridled economic forces, violates the basic principle of liberal thought, which is the limitation of one power by another.Ultraliberalism and totalitarianism are not, he says, as radically opposed as their adherents claim. Ultraliberalism, Todorov tells us pointedly, is not only totalitarianisms enemy, but its brother.What we need is a restoration of that balance, not a revolution driving one principle over all others. The desire for wealth is not the supreme good of the human being, he says, a sharp rebuke to some of the more potent forces at work in America. Ayn Rand, for Todorov, is a propagandist.There is a lot to absorb here, and I cannot do justice to the complexities of Todorovs argument, but this is an important book, a thought-provoking book, and one well worth reading given the state of our democracy and our place in this world we have done so much to shape.

There are a few things wrong with this object.For one thing it is stomach remedy pink (which was the only color available on the Vine program). It is slightly cylindrical and rounded at the tip. Therefore it looks like a "comfort device" my wife or other women would use, rather than pepper spray.This not just my opinion, but having handed it over to my wife, who was, after all, mostly likely to need such a device - she received several comments along those lines from others that have seen it on her key chain and were shocked that she would dare have such a device out in public.I know. I'm still laughing.On the flip side, a quick test revealed that the jet stream does reach about 5 or 6 feet. I have seen other reviewers complain about the limited range but it seems to me a human aggressor would at least be within this range. It came out in a stream, like a wasp knockdown spray, so it would certainly do something if it hit somebody. I haven't tasted the formula for obvious reasons, so I don't know if it is potent or effective (opinions seem to vary by review).One other concern is that there is no lock on the trigger, so accidental discharge is potentially possible. My wife hasn't had that problem yet, but it is something she is on the watch for. It is probably worth having, and the compact design is nice, but please, put some sort of safety on it so the user doe snot suffer an accidental discharge.  And maybe put a hazardous chemical sign on it so people don't think it's something it's not.

Amazing device. It plugs right into the micro-USB port on your phone (where you plug it in to recharge it) and presto! You have thermal images. I did have to download the app first, and in fact, if I have one complaint it is that the device did not come with any instructions at all. To use it, you simply open the app and you can start checking things out.As an example of how useful this camera is, this is my front door. I live in Wisconsin. I think you can see the obvious problems. I have cold air coming in all around the door, through the window above the door, and through my switch plates next to the door. I have always known cold air was getting in, because I can feel the draft, but this is awful.According to the website, the following android devices are compatible with the android version I have:Samsung Galaxy S3Samsung Galaxy S4Samsung Galaxy S5Samsung Galaxy Note 2Samsung Galaxy Note 3Samsung Galaxy Note 4Samsung Galaxy Note EdgeMotorola Moto X (1st and 2nd gen)Motorola Moto GThe camera comes with a nice protective case with a metal ring so you can attach it to a lanyard. The case snaps securely shut and the camera fits inside snugly. I am very happy with this thermal camera, and I highly recommend it if heating or cooling costs are an issue for you. You can really - and readily - find all the trouble spots, not to mention clogged drains.

I love this film, and except for a small bit of romance thrown in, it is all history and action, focusing on the actions of the British pilots and high command, but not ignoring the German pilots and high command. This was filmed back in a day when filmmakers still had access to German aircraft, and the actual planes make a big difference over the modern use of CGI. It doesn't hurt at all that the film has an all-star cast, the likes of which would be too expensive to assemble today.Besides the top-billed Michael Caine, there is Trevor Howard, Harry Andrews, Curd Jrgens, Ian McShane, Christopher Plummer, and Laurence Olivier as Air Chief Marshal Sir Hugh Dowding.The movie is beautifully filmed, well-paced, the acting above any criticism, and the score is one of the best, and the action sequences are spectacular, even given the improvements in CGI explosions since 1969 (nothing, I am sure, George Lucas couldn't fix). I saw this movie in the theater with my father in 1969, and it has always been one of my favorite films of that decade. This is a good copy, and highly recommended to all those fascinated with World War II aerial combat and history.

This is another one of those songs from 1967 that stick in my memory, along with Incense and Peppermints by Strawberry Alarm Clock. I used to listen to these songs at night, transistor radio snug against my ear, sound turned down real low. This is a good recording of the song and if I close my eyes, I am transported back, minus all the AM static. When people say "Classic Rock," it is this music that first comes to mind.

I grew up listening to this music and Incense and Peppermints, which was #1 in 1967 when I was 10 years old (my son's age now) was one of my favorite songs. Another favorite song was I Think We're Alone Now, by Tommy James and the Shondells, which reached #4 that year.I can remember sneaking the old transistor radio into bed with me at night, and turning it up just loud enough to hear if I put my head to it. Hearing this song again really brings back memories of a time I did not really understand all that well, and now, as I listen to it, I have a much better understanding of what was really going on outside my snug, conservative home in the suburbs.The intro and dialogue by Good Morning Vietnam's Adrian Cronauer (the real one, not Robin Williams). Highly recommended for those who want to take a trip down memory lane.

This is a beautifully evocative soundtrack. I listen to it as background music when I am writing, because even the music from the action sequences is not jarring, as is so often the case with soundtracks. My one complaint is that I discovered that there is a longer version of the soundtrack available on iTunes, a fact I only discovered a day or two after downloading this version of the soundtrack from Amazon. The iTunes version has an additional 13 tracks. One of these missing tracks is "Crater Lake," which is some of the most beautiful music in the film, where Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) returns to his secret refuge. How this piece could have been excluded from the soundtrack is beyond me. But if you don't need every last track, the 6.99 price here is perhaps easier on your pocketbook than the 12.99 for the deluxe edition soundtrack.

I have not had the opportunity to try this product on my car, as they have not helpfully broken down, despite a mechanic leaving the lights on in my wife's car. Not that I am complaining, mind you. I can tell you that this is handy for more than recharging your car battery, however. It is not only something you can use to recharge your technology, your tablet or cell phone, but it functions as a very bright light.They do not lie when they say it is light and compact (about two-and-a-half pounds and about 8 inches long). It is. It is nothing compared to cables you can buy at Big Box Retailers, taking up no space at all. You can easily slip it under your seat for storage. The dual LED flashlight with 7 light modes, including SOS, Blink and Emergency Strobe, works as advertised.While I hope never to have the need to use it to jump start my car, I will certainly update this review if I do. Meanwhile, based on its features I can judge, I highly recommend this charger.

Fire and Movement: The British Expeditionary Force and the Campaign of 1914 by Peter Hart is an absolutely splendid book, readable and accessible. And most importantly of all, it challenges many of our long-held assumptions - that is, things we are certain we know - about the First World War. And what better time to examine the first critical year of 1914 than the war's centennial?If you are familiar with Peter Hart's The Great War: A Combat History of the First World War (2013) then you know what to expect.  In The Great War, Hart challenged the idea that nobody came up with any new ideas about how to fight the war, and he continues that thesis in Fire and Movement, though focused now on the British Expeditionary Force, or BEF.Not only that, but he demolishes the belief held by many that the BEF trounced the Germans at the Battle of Mons, in the opening stages of the German advance across Belgium and into Northern France. In fact, Hart tells us, far from being mowed down in droves, German casualties were actually fewer than the British. The truth of the matter is that the British were not prepared to fight the war they in which found themselves, and this is never more true than of the commander of the BEF, Sir John French, who seemed to think he walked upon a Napoleonic battlefield.The account is bolstered by the accounts of those who actually fought in these battles, from Sir John French on down to the lowest private. Most of it is told from the British perspective, but there are episodes as seen from the German ranks as well as the French. These accounts provide clear and compelling evidence that many of those things we have long held to be true, are anything but.Hart carries us through the dust-up at Mons, through the haphazard British retreat to the Battle of the Marne, the Battle of the Aisne, the Race to the Sea, and then on to Ypres and the inevitable stalemate and the Christmas Truce. Hart takes us not only through the battles themselves, but into the trenches, giving us a firsthand look at what life was like for the men condemned to fight this war.He tells us of experiences with new technologies, like the airplane and the wireless, and the halting but determined efforts of visionaries to employ these new technologies as well as the stubborn refusal to employ them by the more conservative and hidebound officers who did not realize that the day of the cavalry was passing before their eyes.Through it all we see that the British were not the heroes of myth (though there was certainly heroism enough) and the Germans were neither the monsters nor the perfect military machine, though they were by far the more skilled of the armies involved. There was good and bad on both sides, atrocities committed by British and German alike. Hart tries to avoid hindsight as he presents his case, providing the evidence in the context of the war itself, though he provides some worthwhile observations in his Epilogue.If you enjoyed The Great War, you will enjoy Fire and Movement, and likewise, if you are interested in the First World War, you will benefit from the clear-headed observations of Peter Hart, as he brings to life the war that in large part is still responsible for the world we find ourselves living in today.

On the up side, it does chop most of the items in the container. On the down side, even though it advertises even results every time, the actual results are anything but even. I put red peppers in the chopper and it made a wet pulpy mess instead of nice diced chunks. It basically mutilated the produce rather than chopping it and that was in spite of pulsing it on the single setting not holding down the double setting.I would not recommend this device.

I am not sure what the fuss it about with this dispenser. While it is nice - in both function and appearance - it is not great. It is certainly not worth $12.99.This is what is advertised (my comments in parentheses):Easy, one-handed dispensing of soap or lotion (isn't any dispenser one-handed?)Generous opening for easy refilling (granted, the opening is wide and that's a plus and the lid is easy to screw on and remove)Sized to fit on bathroom or kitchen sinks (it fits comfortably beside my kitchen faucet)Non-skid base prevents slipping (there is no non-skid base. It is simply the same material as the rest of the container)10 oz capacity (10 oz is okay with me. I buy Method in a bag and what remained in my old dispenser about filled this one up)The best thing I can say about this dispenser is that the opening is larger so pouring is easy but honestly, pouring from a bag of Method isn't all that hard in a cheap dispenser. And while the lid attaches easily and is also easy to remove, I never had a hard time with the cheap ones. I suppose if you have arthritis is might be an improvement but I have no way to test that assumption.By the way, I saw another review that said the soap does not always come out. I thought that was going to be a problem for me as well. I ended up pumping about 30 times to get the soap to come out, which seems excessive to me. If I have any problems down the road, I will not them here.Update [12.10.14] I previously stated that "I certainly would not pay $12.99 to buy more of these." I can now revise that statement to say I would absolutely pay $12.99 for one of these. I have tried several other cheaper brands and most of them have seepage. This one never leaks. I wish I had one for every room.

The first thing I noticed about the bars was the smell of toffee. It was appealing until I actually put the bar in my mouth. Then the taste was more chemical and less like toffee.I ate the first bar slowly so I was able to power through the chemical taste, but I didn't get half way through the second bar (different day) because it was so unappealing.I think the quality is inconsistent too because on the first bar there were really hard elements that had me concerned for my teeth, but the second bar didn't have those elements.I wouldn't recommend these to someone who was on a diet because diets allow limited amounts of food and each bite should be spectacular. This doesn't qualify as spectacular. Underwhelming fits better.

I ordered this keyboard as an alternative to my Belkin, which I use with my Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.3. My thinking was that the Belkin makes my tablet rather heavy to carry around. Sure, it folds around the tablet like a case and can be opened up to support the keyboard while you type or watch videos or a film or whatever, but the weight can be off-putting when you want to hold it. I thought the Mad Catz would provide way to keep the tablet in a lighter protective case while taking no more time to set up for typing. That's essentially what I got. So far so good. It also paired quite easily with both my phone and my tablet.The first thing you will notice is that the new keyboard is very small and weighs almost nothing.If you take it out of its protective sleeve (a neat feature) and set it atop the Belkin, it's about the same length and only about half the width. This means that the keys are small and more closely spaced. There is not a lot of difference, about a half-inch on the Belkin and 1/8" of an inch less than that on the Mad Catz, but when you're talking small keys, that 1/8 inch can make a big difference, especially if, like me, you have large fingers. It makes for clumsy typing.I am a fairly fast typist, about a hundred wpm, so I know where the keys are and can do a sort of modified "hunt and peck" on my Belkin, not really resting my fingers over the keys which are already too small for them. I can't do this as easily on the Mad Catz and I make more mistakes. The back lit keyboard makes up for this to a degree, because now I can type in the dark, but it's a trade-off I can't easily rate. It certainly isn't enough of an argument to discount the Mad Catz for the reasons I shall explain below.One thing that Mad Catz has that the Belkin does not is mouse buttons and a very tiny track (OFN) pad. You can left or right click your imaginary mouse on the keyboard and move the cursor around on the OFN sensor, which is right between them. This is a nice feature and allows you to navigate your touch screen without having to touch it.The Mad Catz also comes with a folding device stand. The battery holds a 30-hour charge, and it comes with a Micro USB charge cable.The device stand is nice. I can put my Samsung Galaxy S4 on it, even while it is in its Otterbox protective case and it stays put. More amazingly, I can put my tablet on the device stand even inside its Belkin keyboard case. That's really something. That also means that I can haul my Mad Catz along with me along with the Belkin and use whichever is most useful at the time (for example, in a dark room I'd choose the Mad Catz). So amazing versatility.Let's face it - no little keyboard is going to be as easy to type on as a full-size keyboard so you have to choose based on various factors that have nothing to do with ease of typing, and the Mad Catz wins handily where these are concerned. Other than size, which as I say, you really have to set aside because they're all going to be small, it really has no negatives.
